item.title: 6. Protocol and Server
item.description:
As you know, the Telnet protocol is an application layer protocol that allows you to remotely connect to another computer as a virtual terminal. You can use Telnet to log in to another computer and manipulate its system.
Telnet uses port 23 as a WellKnown port. Below is the Telnet execution process.

First, you are asked to provide the name of the user you want to log in as.
Then, you are asked for a password. The password is not displayed in the CMD.
If the login is successful, a welcome message appears.
frank@bento:~$ Here, $ indicates that it is not a root terminal.

It is a vulnerable protocol because all input values â€‹â€‹are sent in plain text.
Currently, the SSH protocol is mainly used for security.
Question:
What port does the telnet command with default parameters attempt to connect to?
Answer: 23


HTTP is a protocol used to transmit web pages.
The image below shows the process by which a web server serves HTML.

To use the HTTP protocol, an HTTP server and client are required. The DNPQ server provides a set of specific files for web browsers.
The commonly used servers are
Apache
IIS
Nginx
.
The browsers are

Google's Chrome
Microsoft's Edge
Mozilla's Firefox
Apple's Safari.
There is also a way to request a web page using Telnet. It is as follows.

Question:
Start the connected VM. Connect to 10.10.36.60 80 using Telnet in the AttackBox terminal and search for the file flag.thm. What does it contain?
Answer: THM{e3eb0a1df437f3f97a64aca5952c8ea0}


File Transfer Protocol (FTP) is intended for transferring and sharing files between systems. The process of using FTP is as follows:

I connected to the FTP server using a Telnet client. Since the FTP server listens on port 21 by default, I had to tell the Telnet client to try to connect to port 21 instead of the default Telnet port.
I had to provide a username along with the command USER frank.
Then I provided a password along with the command PASS D2xc9CgD.
I was able to log in because I provided the correct username and password.

I will explain the arguments used above.
STAT: Provides some additional information.
SYST: Displays the system type of the target.
PASV: Switches the mode to passive.
TYPE A: Switches the file transfer mode to ASCII.
TYPE I: Switches the file transfer mode to binary.
FTP has two modes.

Active: In active mode, data is transferred through a separate channel starting from port 20 of the FTP server. - Passive: In passive mode, data is transmitted through a separate channel starting from the FTP client port above port number 1023.

The above is a picture depicting the actual FTP operation process.
Below is the process of downloading files directly. I listed the files using Ls and converted them to text files in ascii. And I received the files using get FILNAME.

Since FTP sends login credentials in plaintext along with commands and files, FTP traffic can be an easy target for attackers.
Question:
I'm connecting to a VM using an FTP client and trying to recover a flag file. What is the flag?

Username: Frank
Password: D2xc9CgD
Answer: THM{364db6ad0e3ddfe7bf0b1870fb06fbdf}


To understand SMTP, you must first understand email. Email delivery over the Internet requires the following components:

Mail Submission Agent (MSA)
Mail Transfer Agent (MTA)
Mail Delivery Agent (MDA)
Mail User Agent (MUA)
The above terms may be difficult, so I will explain them with a picture.


A Mail User Agent (MUA), or simply an email client, has an email message to send. The MUA connects to a Mail Submission Agent (MSA) to send the message.
The MSA receives the message and checks for errors before forwarding it to a Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) server, which is usually hosted on the same server.
The MTA sends the email message to the recipient's MTA. An MTA can also act as a Mail Submission Agent (MSA).
In a typical setup, an MTA server also acts as a Mail Delivery Agent (MDA).
The recipient uses an email client to collect the email from the MDA.
To break down the above process a bit more simply, it goes like this:

You (the MUA) want to send a piece of mail.
A postal worker (the MSA) checks the mail for any issues before accepting it at your local post office (the MTA).
The local post office verifies the destination of the mail and forwards it to the correct country post office (the MTA). 4. The post office (MTA) delivers the mail to the recipient mailbox (MDA). 5. The recipient (MUA) checks the mailbox regularly to see if there is new mail. They check for new mail and take it.
In the same way, communicating with an HTTP server requires a protocol, and communicating with an MTA and MDA requires an electronic mail protocol. The protocols are as follows:

Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP)
POP3 (Post Office Protocol version 3) or IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)
Of these, SMTP is used when communicating with an MTA server. Since SMTP uses plaintext, where all commands are transmitted without encryption, it can act as an email client that connects to an SMTP server and sends messages using a basic Telnet client.
The MTP server listens on port 25 by default. I connected using Telnet to see the basic communication with the SMTP server. Once connected, issue an email hello hostname and start typing.

You can connect to smtp using telnet in the same way as above.
Question:
Using AttackBox terminal, connect to SMTP port of target VM. What flags can you get?
Answer: THM{5b31ddfc0c11d81eba776e983c35e9b5}


POP3 is a protocol used to download email messages from an MDA server, as shown in the figure below.
The mail client connects to the POP3 server, authenticates, and optionally downloads new email messages before deleting them.

The example below shows what a POP3 session looks like when done via a telnet client. First, the user connects to the POP3 server on the default POP3 port 110. Authentication is required to access email messages. The user authenticates by providing his username USER frank and password PASS D2xc9CgD. He gets a STAT response using the command

Question:
Connect to VM( ) on 10.10.36.60 POP3 port. He authenticates by using username frank and password D2xc9CgD. What is the STAT response you get?
Answer: +OK 0 0
How many e-mail messages can be downloaded via POP3 from 10.10.36.60?
Answer: 0


IMAP is more sophisticated than POP3. IMAP allows you to keep your e-mail synchronized across multiple devices (and mail clients).
Question:
IMAP allows you to keep your e-mail synchronized across multiple devices (and mail clients).
Answer: 143
Summary
It's a good idea to remember the default port numbers for common protocols. Here is a summary of the protocols, listed alphabetically, along with their default port numbers.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ë„¤íŠ¸ì›Œí¬ ë³´ì•ˆ/Eng/ 6. Protocol and Server.md

item.title: 3. Nmap Live Host Search
item.description:
When gathering information about a network, we need an efficient tool to handle repetitive tasks and answer the following questions:

Which systems are up and running?
What services are running on these systems?
For this purpose, the tool we will use is Nmap. We will actively explore systems and services using Nmap. Nmap was created by network security expert and open-source programmer Gordon Lyon (Fyodor) and was released in 1997. Nmap, short for Network Mapper, is free open-source software released under the GPL license. Nmap is an industry-standard tool for network mapping, live host identification, and service discovery. The Nmap scripting engine can further extend its capabilities, from fingerprinting services to exploiting vulnerabilities. Nmap scans typically follow the steps shown in the diagram below, though most are optional and depend on the command-line arguments provided.


Let's review a few terms. A network segment is a group of computers connected using a shared medium. For example, the medium could be an Ethernet switch or a WiFi access point. In an IP network, a subnet usually refers to one or more network segments connected together and configured to use the same router. A network segment represents a physical connection, while a subnet represents a logical connection.
The following network diagram shows four network segments or subnets. Typically, systems are connected to one of these network segments/subnets. A subnet, or simply subnet, has its own IP address range and is connected to a broader network via a router. Each network may have a firewall to enforce security policies.

The above diagram shows two types of subnets.

A contained subnet can use a subnet mask of /16, meaning 255.255.0.0. This subnet can accommodate about 65,000 hosts.
A subnet mask of /24 means 255.255.255.0, indicating that this subnet can have about 250 hosts.
For more details about subnets, refer to Task 2 of the Introduction to LAN room.
As part of active reconnaissance, we aim to gather more information about a group of hosts or a subnet. If you are connected to the same subnet, you can expect the scanner to rely on ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) queries to search for live hosts. ARP queries aim to retrieve hardware addresses (MAC addresses) to enable communication through the link layer. However, you can infer that a host is online by using this method. (We revisit link-layer in Task 4.)
If you are on Network A, you can only scan devices within that subnet (10.1.100.0/24) using ARP. Suppose you are connected to a different subnet than the target systemâ€™s subnet. In that case, any packets generated by the scanner will be routed through the default gateway (router) to reach systems in another subnet. However, ARP queries are not routable and thus cannot pass through a subnet router. ARP is a link-layer protocol, and ARP packets are bound to their respective subnets.
To start the network simulator, click the "View Site" button. You will use this simulator to answer the questions in Tasks 2, 4, and 5.
Practice
Packets are sent with the following details:

From computer1
To computer1 (to indicate broadcast)
Packet type: "ARP request"
Data: computer6 (requesting the MAC address of computer6 using an ARP request)
How many devices can see the ARP request?
Answer: 4
Did computer6 receive the ARP request? (Yes/No)
Answer: No
Packets are sent with the following details:

From computer4
To computer4 (to indicate broadcast)
Packet type: "ARP request"
Data: computer6 (requesting the MAC address of computer6 using an ARP request)
How many devices can see the ARP request?
Answer: 4
Did computer6 respond to the ARP request? (Yes/No)
Answer: Yes


You can specify targets to scan against your attack target. Typically, you can provide a list, a range, or a subnet. Examples are as follows:

List: Scans three IP addresses: MACHINE_IP scanme.nmap.org example.com.
Range: Scans 6 IP addresses: 10.11.12.15-20, meaning 10.11.12.15, 10.11.12.16, â€¦, and 10.11.12.20.
Subnet: Scans 4 IP addresses: MACHINE_IP/30.
You can also provide a file as input for the target list with nmap -iL list_of_hosts.txt.
To verify the list of hosts that Nmap will scan, use nmap -sL TARGETS. This option provides a detailed list of hosts that Nmap will scan without actually scanning them. However, Nmap will attempt a reverse DNS lookup on all targets to obtain names. Names can reveal various information to the penetration tester. (If you don't want Nmap to query the DNS server, you can add -n.)
Practice:
What is the first IP address that Nmap will scan if given the target IP address?
Answer: 10.10.12.8
If the following range is provided, how many IP addresses will Nmap scan? (Target IP address and range)
nmap -sL -n (with the target IP address and range)
Answer: 6400


Let's take another look at the TCP/IP layers shown in the diagram below. We can use protocols to discover live hosts. Starting from the bottom up, we can use:

ARP at the Link Layer
ICMP at the Network Layer
TCP at the Transport Layer
UDP at the Transport Layer

Before discussing how scanners can use each of these, let's briefly review these four protocols. The purpose of ARP is singular: to send a frame to the broadcast address of the network segment and request a specific computer with a particular IP address to provide its MAC (hardware) address in response.
ICMP has many types. ICMP ping uses type 8 (echo) and type 0 (echo reply).
To ping systems on the same subnet, an ARP query must be performed before the ICMP Echo.
While TCP and UDP are transport layer protocols, for network scanning, the scanner can send specially crafted packets to a standard TCP or UDP port to check whether the target responds. This method is particularly effective if ICMP Echo is blocked.
If you closed the network simulator, click the "View Site" button in Task 2 to reopen it.



Overview:
How do you know which hosts are running? Itâ€™s crucial not to waste time port scanning offline hosts or unused IP addresses. There are several methods to search for online hosts. If no host discovery option is provided, Nmap follows these approaches to find live hosts:

If a privileged user attempts to scan a target on the local network (Ethernet), Nmap uses an ARP request. A privileged user is root, a .sudoers, or someone using sudo.
If a privileged user attempts to scan a target outside the local network, Nmap uses ICMP Echo requests, TCP ACK on port 80, TCP SYN on port 443, and ICMP Timestamp requests.
If an unprivileged user attempts to scan a target outside the local network, Nmap relies on sending SYN packets to ports 80 and 443 for a TCP three-way handshake.
Nmap, by default, uses ping scan to find live hosts and then only scans those live hosts. To search for online hosts without performing a port scan using Nmap, use nmap -sn TARGETS. Letâ€™s dive deeper to gain a clear understanding of the various techniques used.
Practice:
ARP scanning is only possible if you are on the same subnet as the target system. In Ethernet (802.3) and WiFi (802.11), you need to know the MAC address of the system before communicating with it. The MAC address is required in the link-layer header, which includes fields like the source MAC address and destination MAC address. To obtain the MAC address, the OS sends an ARP query. Hosts that respond to the ARP query are operational. ARP queries only work if the target is on the same subnet as the user, meaning on the same Ethernet/WiFi. During an Nmap scan of the local network, you should expect to see many ARP queries generated. To perform an ARP scan without a port scan using Nmap, use nmap -PR -sn TARGETS, where -PR indicates that only ARP probing is desired. The following example shows Nmap using ARP to search for hosts without a port scan: nmap -PR -sn MACHINE_IP/24 is executed to discover all live systems on the same subnet as the target machine.
Penetration Tester Terminal

(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PR -sn 10.10.210.6/24 ë³µì‚¬Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-09-02 07:12 BST ë³µì‚¬Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-210-75.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.210.75) ë³µì‚¬Host is up (0.00013s latency). ë³µì‚¬MAC Address: 02:83:75:3A:F2:89 (Unknown) ë³µì‚¬Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-210-100.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.210.100) ë³µì‚¬Host is up (-0.100s latency). ë³µì‚¬MAC Address: 02:63:D0:1B:2D:CD (Unknown) ë³µì‚¬Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-210-165.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.210.165) ë³µì‚¬Host is up (0.00025s latency). ë³µì‚¬MAC Address: 02:59:79:4F:17:B7 (Unknown) ë³µì‚¬Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-210-6.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.210.6) ë³µì‚¬Host is up. ë³µì‚¬Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (4 hosts up) scanned in 3.12 seconds ë³µì‚¬













This command generates many ARP queries that can be observed using tools such as arp-scan, tcpdump, Wireshark, or similar tools. We can observe the traffic pattern and packet capture for such traffic with arp-scan and nmap -PR -sn. Below is the Wireshark output.

If you have closed the network simulator, click the "View Site" button in Task 2 to display it again.
Problem:
Send a broadcast ARP request packet using the following options:

From Computer1
To computer1 (indicating broadcast)
Packet type: "ARP Request"
Data: Try to reach all 8 devices on the network (excluding computer1) (computer2, computer3, computer4, computer5, computer6, switch1, switch2, and router).

Overview:
You can ping all IP addresses in the target network and see who responds to our ping request (ICMP Type 8/Echo) with a ping response (ICMP Type 0). Sounds simple, right? While this is the simplest method, it is not always reliable. Many firewalls block ICMP echo requests. Recent versions of MS Windows are configured with host firewalls that block ICMP echo requests by default. Remember that ARP queries take precedence over ICMP requests when the target is on the same subnet.
To search for live hosts using ICMP echo requests, add the -PE option to nmap -sn (remember to add it to avoid port scanning). The ICMP echo scan works by sending ICMP echo requests and expecting the target to respond with ICMP echo replies if it is online.

Practice:
In the example below, the subnet of the target was scanned using nmap -PE -sn MACHINE_IP/24. This scan sends ICMP echo packets to all IP addresses in the subnet and expects replies from live hosts. However, it is important to remember that many firewalls block ICMP. The output below shows the results of scanning a Class C subnet on a virtual machine using AttackBox.
Penetration Tester Terminal
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PE -sn 10.10.68.220/24
Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-09-02 10:16 BST
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-50.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.50)
Host is up (0.00017s latency).
MAC Address: 02:95:36:71:5B:87 (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-52.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.52)
Host is up (0.00017s latency).
MAC Address: 02:48:E8:BF:78:E7 (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-77.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.77)
Host is up (-0.100s latency).
MAC Address: 02:0F:0A:1D:76:35 (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-110.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.110)
Host is up (-0.10s latency).
MAC Address: 02:6B:50:E9:C2:91 (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-140.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.140)
Host is up (0.00021s latency).
MAC Address: 02:58:59:63:0B:6B (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-142.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.142)
Host is up (0.00016s latency).
MAC Address: 02:C6:41:51:0A:0F (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-220.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.220)
Host is up (0.00026s latency).
MAC Address: 02:25:3F:DB:EE:0B (Unknown)
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-68-222.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.68.222)
Host is up (0.00025s latency).
MAC Address: 02:28:B1:2E:B0:1B (Unknown)
Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (8 hosts up) scanned in 2.11 seconds
ìŠ¤ìº” ì¶œë ¥ì€ 8ê°œì˜ í˜¸ìŠ¤íŠ¸ê°€ ì‘ë™ ì¤‘ì„ì„ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë˜í•œ MAC ì£¼ì†Œë¥¼ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ëŒ€ìƒì´ ìš°ë¦¬ ì‹œìŠ¤í…œê³¼ ë™ì¼í•œ ì„œë¸Œë„·ì— ìˆì§€ ì•ŠëŠ” í•œ ëŒ€ìƒì˜ MAC ì£¼ì†Œë¥¼ ì•Œ ê²ƒìœ¼ë¡œ ê¸°ëŒ€í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ìœ„ì˜ ì¶œë ¥ì€ Nmapì´ ìˆ˜ì‹ í•œ ARP ì‘ë‹µì— ë”°ë¼ ì´ëŸ¬í•œ í˜¸ìŠ¤íŠ¸ê°€ ì‘ë™ ì¤‘ì„ì„ í™•ì¸í–ˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ICMP íŒ¨í‚·ì„ ë³´ë‚¼ í•„ìš”ê°€ ì—†ìŒì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ëƒ…ë‹ˆë‹¤.
ìœ„ì˜ ìŠ¤ìº”ì„ ë°˜ë³µí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ¬ë‚˜ ì´ë²ˆì—ëŠ” ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì„œë¸Œë„·ì— ì†í•œ ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì—ì„œ ìŠ¤ìº”í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê²°ê³¼ëŠ” ë¹„ìŠ·í•˜ì§€ë§Œ MAC ì£¼ì†Œê°€ ì—†ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.
ì¹¨íˆ¬ í…ŒìŠ¤í„° í„°ë¯¸ë„
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PE -sn 10.10.68.220/24
Starting Nmap 7.92 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-09-02 12:16 EEST
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.50
Host is up (0.12s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.52
Host is up (0.12s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.77
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.110
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.140
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.142
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.220
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.222
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (8 hosts up) scanned in 8.26 seconds
The ICMP timestamp scan works similarly to the previous ICMP scan but sends numerous ICMP timestamp requests to all valid IP addresses in the target subnet. As seen in the Wireshark screenshot below, a single source IP address sends ICMP packets to all possible IP addresses to discover online hosts.

Similarly, Nmap uses the Address Mask Request (ICMP Type 17) and expects an Address Mask Reply (ICMP Type 18). This scan can be enabled optionally with -PM. As shown in the figure below, live hosts should respond to ICMP Address Mask Requests.

To perform a live host scan using ICMP Address Mask, run the following command: nmap -PM -sn MACHINE_IP/24. Based on the previous scan, you know at least 8 hosts are up, but this scan returned nothing. This is likely because the target system or firewall in the path is blocking these types of ICMP packets. Therefore, it's essential to learn multiple methods to achieve the same result. If one type of packet is blocked, always try another type to search the target network and services.
Penetration Tester Terminal:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PM -sn 10.10.68.220/24
Starting Nmap 7.92 (https://nmap.org) at 2021-09-02 12:13 EEST
Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (0 hosts up) scanned in 52.17 seconds
No responses were received, and no hosts could be determined as online, but note that this scan sent ICMP Address Mask Requests to all valid IP addresses and waited for responses. As shown in the screenshot below, each ICMP request was sent twice.

Questions:

What option instructs Nmap to use ICMP timestamp to discover live hosts?
Answer: -PP
What option instructs Nmap to use ICMP Address Mask to discover live hosts?
Answer: -PM
What option instructs Nmap to use ICMP Echo to discover live hosts?
Answer: -PE
6. Host Discovery Using TCP and UDP
TCP SYN Ping
You can send packets with the SYN (synchronize) flag set to a TCP port (default is 80) and wait for responses. Open ports should respond with SYN/ACK (acknowledge), while closed ports will result in an RST (reset). In this case, you only check if you receive a response to infer if the host is up. The specific state of the port is not important. The following image reminds us how the TCP 3-way handshake typically works.

To use TCP SYN ping with Nmap, you can do so by specifying the port number, range, or list after the -PS option. For example:

-PS21 targets port 21.
-PS21-25 targets ports 21, 22, 23, 24, and 25.
-PS80,443,8080 targets ports 80, 443, and 8080.
Privileged users (root and sudoers) can send TCP SYN packets, as shown in the following image, without needing to complete the TCP 3-way handshake even if the port is open. Unprivileged users will have to complete the 3-way handshake if the port is open.

Run nmap -PS -sn MACHINE_IP/24 to scan the target VM subnet. As seen in the output below, five hosts were discovered.
Penetration Tester Terminal:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PS -sn 10.10.68.220/24
Starting Nmap 7.92 (https://nmap.org) at 2021-09-02 13:45 EEST
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.52
Host is up (0.10s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.121
Host is up (0.16s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.125
Host is up (0.089s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.134
Host is up (0.13s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.220
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (5 hosts up) scanned in 17.38 seconds
As seen in the figure below, we observe network traffic in Wireshark, and Nmap sent TCP packets to common TCP ports. In this case, it used TCP port 80. Any service receiving on port 80 should respond to indicate that the host is online.

TCP ACK Ping
As you might guess, this sends packets with the ACK flag set. To perform this, Nmap must be run with privileges. Attempting this with unprivileged accounts will cause Nmap to try the 3-way handshake.
By default, port 80 is used. The syntax is similar to TCP SYN ping. You should specify the port number, range, or list after the -PA option. For example:

-PA21 and -PA21-25
-PA80,443,8080
The following image shows that all TCP packets with the ACK flag should respond with TCP packets with the RST flag set. Since the ACK flag is in packets not part of an ongoing connection, the RST flag is set in the response. This response is used to determine if the target host is up.

Run sudo nmap -PA -sn MACHINE_IP/24 to search for online hosts in the target subnet. The TCP ACK ping scan detected 5 hosts up.
Penetration Tester Terminal:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PA -sn 10.10.68.220/24
Starting Nmap 7.92 (https://nmap.org) at 2021-09-02 13:46 EEST
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.52
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.121
Host is up (0.12s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.125
Host is up (0.10s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.134
Host is up (0.10s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.220
Host is up (0.10s latency).
Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (5 hosts up) scanned in 29.89 seconds
As shown in the figure below, we can see many packets with the ACK flag set and sent to port 80 of the target system. Nmap sends each packet twice. Systems that do not respond are either offline or inaccessible.

UDP Ping
Finally, you can use UDP to check if a host is online. Unlike TCP SYN ping, you would expect no response when sending UDP packets to open ports. However, if you send UDP packets to closed UDP ports, you will receive ICMP "Destination Unreachable" errors. This indicates that the target system is up and reachable.
The following image shows UDP packets sent to open UDP ports, which do not trigger a response. However, sending UDP packets to closed UDP ports can trigger a response indicating the target is online.


The syntax for specifying ports is similar to TCP SYN ping and TCP ACK ping. Nmap uses -PU for UDP ping. The command nmap -PU -sn MACHINE_IP/24 will search for online hosts in the subnet.
Penetration Tester Terminal:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -PU -sn 10.10.68.220/24
Starting Nmap 7.92 (https://nmap.org) at 2021-09-02 13:47 EEST
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.52
Host is up (0.10s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.121
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.125
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.134
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap scan report for 10.10.68.220
Host is up (0.11s latency).
Nmap done: 256 IP addresses (5 hosts up) scanned in 16.92 seconds
As shown in the following image, the result of the UDP scan was similar to the TCP scan. The scan returned 5 hosts as online.
Questions:
What option instructs Nmap to use TCP SYN ping to discover live hosts?

Answer: -PS
What option instructs Nmap to use TCP ACK ping to discover live hosts?
Answer: -PA
What option instructs Nmap to use UDP ping to discover live hosts?
Answer: -PU

By default, Nmap performs reverse DNS lookups on online hosts. Since hostnames can reveal a lot of information, this can be a useful step. However, if you want to skip this step and avoid sending these DNS queries, you can use the -n option.
By default, Nmap will find online hosts. However, you can also query DNS servers for offline hosts by using the -R option. If you want to use a specific DNS server, you can add the --dns-servers DNS_SERVER option.
Question:
What option instructs Nmap to use reverse DNS lookups on all hosts?
Answer: -R

In this section, you learned how ARP, ICMP, TCP, and UDP can be used to detect live hosts. Any response from a host indicates that the host is online. Below is a brief summary of the Nmap command-line options we covered:

If you are only interested in host discovery without port scanning, you should include -sn. Omitting it means Nmap will perform a port scan by default.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ë„¤íŠ¸ì›Œí¬ ë³´ì•ˆ/Eng/3. Nmap Live Host Search.md

item.title: 4. Nmap Basic Port Scan
item.description:
Finding accessible ports and services is important in network security. In this lesson, we will cover the process of finding out information about them.



Ports are often associated with services using specific port numbers. These ports are called well-known ports. For example, http is 80, ssh is 22, etc.
There are two states for a port.
Open: If there is a service listening on that port.
Closed: If there is no service listening on that port.
However, in real situations, packets may be blocked by a firewall even if the port is open. Therefore, Nmap considers the following six states.

Open : Indicates that a service is listening on the specified port.
Closed : Indicates that the port is accessible, but no service is listening on the specified port. Accessible means reachable and not blocked by a firewall or other security appliance/program.
Filtered : Indicates that Nmap cannot determine whether the port is open or closed because the port is inaccessible. This condition is typically caused by a firewall that prevents Nmap from reaching that port. Nmap packets may be blocked from reaching the port, or responses may be blocked from reaching the Nmap host.
Unfiltered: Nmap can access the port, but cannot determine whether the port is open or closed. This state occurs when using the ACK scan -sA.
Open|Filtered: This means Nmap cannot determine whether the port is open or filtered.
Closed|Filtered: This means Nmap cannot determine whether the port is closed or filtered.
Question:
What service uses UDP port 53 by default?
Answer: DNS
What service uses TCP port 22 by default?
Answer: SSH
How many port states does Nmap consider?
Answer: 6
What are the most interesting port states to detect as a penetration tester?
Answer: Open


TCP connection scans work by completing the TCP 3-way handshake. In a standard TCP connection setup, the client sends a TCP packet with the SYN flag set, and the server responds with a SYN/ACK if the port is open. Finally, the client completes the 3-way handshake by sending an ACK.

We are not interested in establishing a TCP connection, but rather in checking whether a TCP port is open. Therefore, we will send an RST/ACK to terminate the connection as soon as the state is confirmed. You can choose to perform a TCP connection scan using -sT.

Note that if you are not a privileged user (root or sudoer), scanning TCP connections is the only option that will detect open TCP ports.
In the following Wireshark packet capture window, you can see that Nmap is sending TCP packets with the SYN flag set to various ports (256, 443, 143, etc.). By default, Nmap will attempt to connect to the 1000 most common ports. A closed TCP port responds to a SYN packet with an RST/ACK, indicating that it is not open. This pattern is repeated for all closed ports when attempting to initiate a TCP 3-way handshake.

We can see that port 143 is open, so it responds with a SYN/ACK, and Nmap sends an ACK, completing the 3-way handshake. The figure below shows all the packets exchanged between the Nmap host and port 143 on the target system. The first three packets are the TCP 3-way handshake that completes. The fourth packet is then broken down into RST/ACK packets.

To illustrate (TCP connection scan), -sT The following command example returns a detailed list of open ports.
Penetration Tester Terminal pentester@TryHackMe$ nmap -sT MACHINE_IP Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-08-30 09:53 BST Nmap scan report for MACHINE_IP Host is up (0.0024s latency).
Not shown: 995 closed ports
PORT    STATE SERVICE
22/tcp  open  ssh
25/tcp  open  smtp
80/tcp  open  http
111/tcp open  rpcbind
143/tcp open  imap
MAC Address: 02:45:BF:8A:2D:6B (Unknown )
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 0.40 seconds
-F Enables fast mode and can be used to reduce the number of ports scanned from 1000 to the 100 most common ports.
It is worth mentioning that you can also add the -r option to scan ports in sequential order rather than random order. This option is useful for testing whether ports are opened in a consistent way when the target boots, for example. Useful.
Problem:
Start the VM. Open AttackBox and run nmap -sT MACHINE_IP via terminal. A new service was installed on this VM since the last scan. Which port numbers were closed in the scan above? Is it now open on this target VM?
Answer: 110
What is Nmap's guess about the newly installed service?
Answer: POP3
Unprivileged users are limited to connection scans. However, the default scan mode is SYN scan, which requires a privileged (root or sudoer) user to run. SYN scans require the TCP 3-way handshake to complete. There is no connection. Instead, it disconnects when it gets a response from the server. This reduces the possibility of the scan being logged since it does not establish a TCP connection. You can select this scan type using the option -sS. The figure below shows a TCP 3-way Shows how a TCP SYN scan works without completing the handshake.
The following screenshot from Wireshark shows a TCP SYN scan. For closed TCP ports, the behavior is similar to that of a TCP connection scan. Similar to the action.

To better see the difference between the two scans, consider the following screenshots. In the top half of the following figure, we see a TCP connection scan - sT traffic. Every open TCP port requires Nmap to complete the TCP 3-way handshake before closing the connection. In the bottom half of the following figure, we see a SYN scan. You can see that there is no need to complete this -sSTCP 3-way handshake. Instead, Nmap sends an RST packet when a SYN/ACK packet is received.
TCP SYN scan is the default scan when running Nmap as a privileged user, as root, or using sudo. This is a very stable choice. It successfully found open ports previously found by TCP connection scan, but the TCP connection with the target was not fully established. Penetration Tester Terminal pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -sS MACHINE_IP Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-08-30 09:53 BST Nmap scan report for MACHINE_IP Host is up (0.0073s latency).
Not shown: 994 closed ports
PORT    STATE SERVICE
22/tcp  open  ssh
25/tcp  open  smtp
80/tcp  open  http
110/tcp open  pop3
111/tcp open  rpcbind
143/tcp open  imap
MAC Address: 02:45:BF:8A: 2D:6B (Unknown)
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 1.60 seconds
Problem:
Start the VM. Some new server software has been installed since the last scan. Using the terminal on the AttackBox, nmap - sS MACHINE_IP. What are the new open ports?
Answer: 6667
What is Nmap's guess about the service name?
Answer: IRC


UDP is a connectionless protocol, so it does not require a handshake to establish a connection. UDP There is no guarantee that a service listening on a port will respond to the packet. However, if a UDP packet is sent to a closed port, an ICMP port unreachable error (type 3, code 3) is returned. You can select UDP scanning using the option can be combined with -sU. Also can be combined with other TCP scans.
The following figure shows that if you send a UDP packet to an open UDP port, you cannot expect a response. Therefore, even if you send a UDP packet to an open port, you will not know anything.
![](https://blog.kakaocdn.net/dn /c6Wulk/btsk8LIbWjw/GFcOhcZTNMkkMsuVU8WH2K/img.png)
However, as you can see in the image below, I expect an ICMP packet of type 3, destination unreachable and code 3, port unreachable. That is, no response is generated. A UDP port that is not open is one that Nmap marks as open.
In the Wireshark capture below, all closed ports are unreachable ICMP packet destinations (port unreachable). You can see that it is generating .

Starting a UDP scan against this Linux server proved worth it, and indeed, port 111 was open. . On the other hand, Nmap cannot determine whether UDP port 68 is open or filtered. Penetration Tester Terminal pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -sU MACHINE_IP Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-08-30 09:54 BST Nmap scan report for MACHINE_IP Host is up (0.00061s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed ports
PORT    STATE        SERVICE
68/udp  open|filtered dhcpc
111/udp open          rpcbind
MAC Address: 02:45:BF:8A:2D:6B (Unknown)
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 1085.05 seconds
Problem:
Start the VM. Using the terminal in the AttackBox, run nmap -sU -F -v MACHINE_IP. A new service was installed since the last scan. What UDP ports are currently open?
Problem:
Start the VM. Using the terminal in the AttackBox, run nmap -sU -F -v MACHINE_IP. A new service was installed since the last scan. What UDP ports are currently open?
Answer: 53
What is the service name according to Nmap?
Answer: domain


You can specify ports to scan instead of the default 1000 ports. Port specification is now intuitive. Let's look at some examples.

Port list: -p22,80,443 Scan ports 22, 80, and 443. - Port ranges: -p1 - scan all ports between 10231 and 1023, -p20-25 - scan ports between 20 and 25.
You can request a scan of all ports using -p-, which scans all 65535 ports. To scan the 100 most common ports, use -F. --top-ports 10 will check the 10 most common ports.
You can control the timing of the scan using -T<0-5>. -T0 is the slowest (paranoid) and -T5 is the fastest. According to the Nmap man page, there are 6 templates.

Paranoid (0)
Mean (1)
Polite (2)
Normal (3)
Aggressive (4)
Crazy (5)
To avoid IDS warnings, you can consider -T0 or -T1. For example, -T0 scans one port at a time and waits 5 minutes between each probe transmission, which gives you an idea of â€‹â€‹how long it takes for a single target scan to complete. If no timing is specified, Nmap uses normal -T3. -T5 is the most aggressive in terms of speed. However, this may affect the accuracy of the scan results due to the increased possibility of packet loss. Commonly used during CTF and -T4 training to learn how to scan a target, while -T1 is more commonly used during real-world engagements where stealth is more important.
You can choose to control the packet rate using --min-rate number or --max-rate number . For example, --max-rate 10 or --max-rate=10 will ensure that the scanner does not send more than 10 packets per second.
You can also control the probing parallelism using --min-parallelism numprobes and --max-parallelism numprobes > . Nmap probes a target to discover which hosts are active and which ports are open. Probe parallelism specifies how many probes can run in parallel. For example, push --min-parallelism=512Nmap to keep at least 512 probes in parallel. These 512 probes are related to host discovery and open ports.
Question:
What is the option to scan all TCP ports between 5000 and 5500?
Answer: -p5000-5500
How can I ensure that Nmap runs at least 64 probes in parallel?
Answer: --min-parallelism=64
What option would you add to make Nmap very slow and paranoid?
Answer: -T0

Summary

This type of scan should start a search for TCP and UDP services running on the target host.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ë„¤íŠ¸ì›Œí¬ ë³´ì•ˆ/Eng/4. Nmap Basic Port Scan.md

item.title: 5. Nmap Post Port Scan
item.description:
When Nmap discovers an open port, it can probe the available ports to discover running services. Further investigation of the open port is essential information, as penetration testers can use it to determine if the service has a known vulnerability. Sign up for Vulnerabilities 101 to learn more about vulnerable service scanning.
-sV Appending to the Nmap command will collect and determine service and version information for the open port. --version-intensity LEVEL Controls the intensity, ranging from 0 for the lightest to 9 for the most intense. -sV --version-light is 2, and -sV --version-all is 9.
Note that using -sV forces Nmap to do a TCP 3-way handshake to establish the connection. Connection establishment is necessary because Nmap cannot discover the version without fully establishing a connection and communicating with the receiving service. That is, selecting the -sS option disables stealth SYN scans. -sV
The console output below shows a simple Nmap stealth SYN scan with the -sV option. Adding the -sV option creates a new column in the output that shows the version of each service detected. For example, if TCP port 22 is open, you would instead get 22/tcp open ssh 22/tcp open ssh OpenSSH 6.7p1 Debian 5+deb8u8 (protocol 2.0). Note that the SSH protocol is assumed to be the service because TCP port 22 is open. Nmap didn't need to connect to port 22 for verification. However, the -sV service banner and the version information you get (e.g. nginx 1.6.2. So unlike the service column, the version column is not a guess.
Practice
Start the target system for this task and start AttackBox. Run nmap -sV --version-light IP address AttackBox. What version is detected for port 143?
Answer: Dovecot imapd
What service doesn't have a version --version-light?
Answer: rpcbind


Nmap can detect operating systems (OS) based on behavior and response signatures. You can enable OS detection using -O. This is a capital O, as in OS. In this example, we ran nmap -sS -O IP address AttackBox. Nmap detects that the OS is Linux. Detected that it was 3.X and then guessed that it was running kernel 3.13.
The system we were scanning and trying to detect the OS version was running kernel version 3.16. Nmap was able to make a close guess in this case. In another case, we scanned a Fedora Linux system with kernel 5.13.14. However, Nmap detected it as Linux. Detected as 2.6.X. The good news is that Nmap detected the OS correctly. The bad news is that the kernel version is wrong.
OS detection is very convenient, but many factors can affect its accuracy. First and foremost, Nmap needs to know at least one You should find one open port and one closed port. Also, the increased use of virtualization and similar technologies can skew guest OS fingerprints, so always take the OS version with a grain of salt.
The system we were scanning and attempting to detect the OS version was running kernel version 3.16. Nmap was able to make a close guess in this case. In another case, we scanned a Fedora Linux system with kernel 5.13.14. However, Nmap detected it as Linux 2.6.X. The good news is that Nmap detected the OS correctly. The bad news is that the kernel version is wrong.
OS detection is very handy, but many factors can affect its accuracy. First and foremost, Nmap needs to find at least one open port and one closed port on the target to make a reliable guess. Also, the increased use of virtualization and similar technologies can skew guest OS fingerprints. So always take the OS version with a grain of salt.
Question:
I'm running nmap with the -O10.10.194.117 option. What OS did Nmap detect?
Answer: Linux


A script is a piece of code that does not need to be compiled. That is, it remains in its original human-readable form and does not need to be converted to machine code. Many programs provide additional functionality through scripts. Scripts also allow you to add user-defined functionality that does not exist through built-in commands. Similarly, Nmap supports scripts using the Lua language. Part of Nmap, the Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) is a Lua interpreter that allows Nmap to execute Nmap scripts written in the Lua language. However, you don't need to learn Lua to use Nmap scripts.
A default installation of Nmap can easily include close to 600 scripts. Take a look at your Nmap installation folder. If you examine the files in /usr/share/nmap/scripts on your AttackBox, you'll see that there are hundreds of scripts, conveniently named starting with the target protocol. The console output below lists all of the scripts in AttackBox that start with HTTP. We found about 130 scripts that start with http . We can expect the number of installed scripts to increase in future updates.
Penetration Tester Terminal

You can specify to use some or all of these installed scripts. You can also install scripts from other users for use in your scans. Let's start with the default scripts. You can choose to run a script in the default category by using --script=default or simply adding -sC. In addition to the default categories include auth, broadcast, brute, default, discovery, dos, exploit, external, fuzzer, intrusive, malware, safe, version, and vuln. They are briefly described in the following table.

Some scripts fall into more than one category. Additionally, some scripts perform brute force attacks against services, while others perform DoS attacks and exploit the system. Therefore, it is important to be careful when choosing which scripts to run, to avoid crashing or exploiting the service.
Run a SYN scan using Nmap on 10.10.194.117 and run the default script from the console, as shown below. The command is sudo nmap -sS -sC 10.10.194.117 . Here, -sCNmap runs the default script after a SYN scan. Below are the new details that appear. Look at the SSH service on port 22. Nmap recovered all four public keys associated with the running server. Consider another example, the HTTP service on port 80. Nmap retrieved the default page title. You can see that the page remains the default.
Penetration Tester Terminal
pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -sS -sC 10.10.194.117
Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-09-10 05:08 BST
Nmap scan report for ip-10-10-161-170.eu-west-1.compute.internal (10.10.161.170)
Host is up (0.0011s latency).
Not shown: 994 closed ports

MAC Address: 02:A0:E7:B5:B6:C5 (Unknown)
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 2.21 seconds
You can also specify scripts by name, using a pattern like --script "SCRIPT-NAME" . If you are not sure what the script does, you can open the script file in a text reader or editor such as . In the case of , it says "Perform a brute-force password audit of an FTP server." Some scripts can be very intrusive, so be careful. Also, some may be server-specific and choosing one arbitrarily will just be a waste of time for no benefit. As usual, make sure you have permissions to initiate these tests on the target server. --script "ftp*"ftp-brutelessftp-brute
http-date Consider a seemingly harmless script that supposedly retrieves the http server date and time. This is actually confirmed by the following description: â€œGets the date from an HTTP-like service. Also prints how much the date differs from local timeâ€¦â€ On the AttackBox, run sudo nmap -sS -n --script "http-date" 10.10.194.117, as shown in the console below.
Penetration Tester Terminal pentester@TryHackMe$ sudo nmap -sS -n --script "http-date" 10.10.194.117 Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-09-10 08:04 BST Nmap scan report for 10.10.194.117 Host is up (0.0011s latency).
Not shown: 994 closed ports PORT Â· STATE SERVICE 22/tcp open ssh 25/tcp open smtp 80/tcp open http |_http-date: Fri, 10 Sep 2021 07:04:26 GMT; 0s from local time.
110/tcp open  pop3
111/tcp open  rpcbind
143/tcp open  imap
MAC Address: 02:44:87:82:AC:83 (Unknown)
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 1.78 seconds
Finally, you can extend the functionality of Nmap beyond the official Nmap scripts. You can write your own scripts or download Nmap scripts from the Internet. Downloading and using Nmap scripts from the Internet carries some risk, so you should avoid running scripts from untrusted authors.
Question:
I know that the Nmap script is stored in /usr/share/nmap/scripts AttackBox. What does the script check for in http-robots.txt?
Answer: disallowed entries
Can you tell me the name of the script that checks for the remote code execution vulnerability MS15-034 (CVE2015-2015-1635)?
Answer: http-vuln-cve2015-1635
Start AttackBox if it is not already started. After ensuring that the VM is shut down in Task 2, start the target computer for this task. Run Nmap with the default script in AttackBox -sC 10.10.194.117. You can see that there is a service listening on port 53. What is the full version value?
Answer: 9.9.5-9+deb8u19-Debian
As per the description, the script ssh2-enum-algos "Reports the number of algorithms (encryption, compression, etc.) supported by the target SSH2 server." What are the names of the key exchange algorithms (kex_algorithms) that depend on "sha1" and are supported by 10.10.194.117?
Answer: diffie-hellman-group14-sha1


Whenever you run a Nmap scan, it makes sense to save the results to a file. It is also important to choose and adopt a naming convention for the file names. The number of files can grow quickly, which can interfere with the ability to find previous scan results. The three main formats are:

Normal
Grepable
XML
There is a fourth option, which is not recommended.

Script Kiddy
Normal
As the name suggests, the normal format is similar to the output that is displayed on the screen when scanning a target. -oN FILENAME; can be used to save the scan in plain format, where N indicates OK. Here is an example of the results:
Penetration Tester Terminal

(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)
(x)pentester@TryHackMe$ cat 10.10.194.117_scan.nmap ë³µì‚¬# Nmap 7.60 scan initiated Fri Sep 10 05:14:19 2021 as: nmap -sS -sV -O -oN 10.10.194.117_scan MACHINE_IP ë³µì‚¬Nmap scan report for 10.10.194.117 ë³µì‚¬Host is up (0.00086s latency). ``` ``` Not shown: 994 closed ports ``` ``` PORT â€‹ STATE SERVICE VERSION ``` ``` 22/tcp â€‹ open ssh â€‹ OpenSSH 6.7p1 Debian 5+deb8u8 (protocol 2.0) ``` ``` 25/tcp â€‹ open smtp â€‹ Postfix smtpd ``` ``` 80/t cp open http nginx 1.6.2 ``` ``` 110/tcp open pop3 | Dovecot pop3d ``` ``` 111/tcp open rpcbind 2-4 (RPC #100000) ``` ``` 143/tcp open imap Â· Dovecot imapd ``` ``` MAC Address: 02:A0:E7:B5:B6:C5 (Unknown) ``` ``` Device type: general purpose ``` ``` Running: Linux 3. hop ``` ``` Service Info: Host: debra2.thm.local; OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel ``` ``` OS and Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ . ë³µì‚¬# Nmap done at Fri Sep 10 05:14:28 2021 -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 9.99 seconds ë³µì‚¬




grepable
The grepable format has a name in the command grep. grep stands for Global Regular Expression Printer. Simply put, it efficiently filters scan output for specific keywords or terms. You can save the scan results in grepable format using -oG FILENAME. The scan output shown above in regular format is displayed in the console below using grepable format. The normal output is 21 lines. The grepable output, however, is only 4 lines. The main reason is that Nmap wants each line to be meaningful and complete when the user applies grep. The resulting grepable output tends to be much longer and less readable than the regular output.
Penetration Tester Terminal
pentester@TryHackMe$ cat 10.10.194.117_scan.gnmap
#Nmap 7.60 scan initiated Fri Sep 10 05:14:19 2021 as: nmap -sS -sV -O -oG 10.10.194.117_scan MACHINE_IP ```
Host: 10.10.194.117 Status: Up
Host: MACHINE_IP â€‹
Ports: 22/open/tcp//ssh//OpenSSH 6.7p1 Debian 5+deb8u8 (protocol 2.0)/, 25/open/tcp//smtp//Postfix smtpd/, 80/open/tcp//http//nginx 1.6.2/, 110/open/tcp//pop3//Dovecot pop3d/, 111/open/tcp//rpcbind//2-4 (RPC #100000)/, 143/open/tcp//imap//Dovecot imapd/ Ignored State: closed ( 994) OS: Linux 3.13 Seq Index: 257 IP ID Seq: All zeros

grep is grep KEYWORD TEXT_FILE;This command displays all lines that contain the provided keyword. Let's compare the output when used on regular grep output and on grepable output. You'll notice that the former doesn't provide the IP address of the host. Instead, it returns 80/tcp open http nginx 1.6.2, which is very inconvenient when you're scanning multiple systems. The latter, however, gets it done by providing enough information on each line, such as the IP address of the host.
Penetration Tester Terminal
pentester@TryHackMe$ grep http 10.10.194.117_scan.nmap 80/tcp â€‹ open http â€‹ nginx 1.6.2 OS and Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ . Penetration Tester Terminal pentester@TryHackMe$ grep http 10.10.194.117_scan.gnmap
Ignored State: closed (994) OS: Linux 3.13 Seq Index: 257 IP ID Seq: All zeros ë³µì‚¬
XML
The third format is XML. You can save the scan results in XML format using -oX FILENAME. The XML format is the most convenient for processing the output in other programs. Conveniently, you can combine -oA FILENAME with plain, grepable, and XML to save the scan output in all three formats. -oN-oG-oX
Script Kiddy
The fourth format is the Script Kiddy. If you want to search the output for interesting keywords or archive the results for later reference, you may find this format useless. However, you can use it to save the scan output, and display the output filename with nmap -sS 127.0.0.1 -oS FILENAME , so that you can see 31337 in front of your non-tech-savvy friends.

item.title: 7. Protocol and Server 2
item.description:
Servers implementing protocols can be subject to various types of attacks. Representative examples are as follows:

Sniffing attack
MITM attack
Password attack
Vulnerability
We will now learn about the above attacks.


Sniffing attack refers to collecting information about the target using a network packet capture tool. If the data is not encrypted during transmission, sensitive information such as private message contents and login credentials can be exposed with a simple network packet capture.
The following types of programs can be used to capture network packets:

Tcpdump is a free, open source CLI program ported to work on many operating systems.
Wireshark is a GUI that can be used on various operating systems including Linux, macOS, and MS Windows.
Tshark is a program for using Wireshark in CLI.
EX) Let's use Tcpdump to capture the ID and password of a user who checks email messages using PIP3.
Before using the command below, please remember that you must access the network traffic through a switch with eavesdropping or port mirroring.
Also, packet capture requires root privileges. So, be sure to add sudo in front.

In the terminal output above, I removed the unimportant packets so that I could focus more on the important ones. In particular, the username and password were each sent in their own packets. The first packet explicitly indicates "USER frank", and the last packet indicates the password "PASS D2xc9CgD".
This time, we are using Wireshark to hijack.
If you input pop in the filter window, you can see that only the pop protocol packets were hijacked. You can hijack it using this method.

Protocols that use plain text communication like this can be easily hijacked.
Question:
What should I add to the sudo tcpdump command to capture only Telnet traffic?
Answer: port 23
What is the simplest display filter I can use with Wireshark to only show IMAP traffic?
Answer: Imap


A MITM (Man-in-the-Middle) attack occurs when the victim (A) believes he is communicating with a legitimate target (B), but is unknowingly communicating with an attacker (E).
This attack can be performed relatively simply if the two parties do not verify the authenticity and integrity of each message. Sometimes, the chosen protocol does not provide secure authentication or integrity checking. In this case, the possibility of a man-in-the-middle attack is high.
The scary thing about MITM attacks is that you cannot recognize them. Many tools such as Ettercap and Bettercap can help you perform such attacks.
MITM can also affect other plaintext protocols such as FTP, SMTP, and POP3. Encryption should be used to mitigate this attack. The defense against this lies in proper authentication along with encryption or signing of the exchanged messages. With the help of Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) and trusted root certificates, Transport Layer Security (TLS) protects users from MITM attacks.
Question:
How many interfaces does Ettercap provide?
Answer: 3
How many ways can Bettercap be called?
Answer: 3


All the protocols introduced so far transmitted packets in plaintext without encryption. However, as time progressed, the need for transport layer security protocols arose, and SSL and TLS were finally created.
You can upgrade existing plaintext protocols to use encryption over SSL/TLS. You can upgrade HTTP, FTP, SMTP, POP3, and IMAP to use TLS. The following table lists the protocols and their default ports before and after the encryption upgrade over SSL/TLS.

Question:
You can also use TLS to secure your DNS. What is the 3-letter abbreviation for the DNS protocol that uses TLS?
Answer: Dot


SSH is a security program that is more secure than Telnet. SSH listens on port 22. To use SSH, you need a username, password, and a private and public key. The keys must be set up on the SSH server in advance.
Here is an example of connecting to a server using SSH.

You can transfer files using the Secure Copy Protocol (SCP) based on the SSH protocol using SSH. An example of the syntax is: scp mark@MACHINE_IP:/home/mark/archive.tar.gz ~. This command copies the named file from the remote system in the directory archive.tar.gz to the root of the home directory of the currently logged in user. /home/mark~
Another example syntax is scp backup.tar.bz2 mark@MACHINE_IP:/home/mark/. This command copies a file from local system to remote system's backup.tar.bz2 directory./home/mark/

Question:
mark Connect to MACHINE_IP using SSH with password as well as XBtc49AB. Use uname -r to find the kernel release?
Answer: 5.4.0-84-generic
book.txt Download a file from remote system using SSH. How many KB is shown as the scp download size?
Answer: 415


Most protocols require authentication. For this, passwords, cards, fingerprints, and other methods are used.
A password attack is an attack on a method of authentication based on information known to the target. In other words, it is an attack to find out a password or password. These types of passwords are as follows:

Password guessing: To guess a password, you need knowledge of the target, such as the name and date of birth of your pet.
Dictionary attack: This approach extends password guessing and tries to include all valid words in a dictionary or word list.
Brute force attack: This attack is the most thorough and time-consuming attack, where the attacker can try all possible character combinations.
The method I will explain this time is a dictionary attack. The hacker obtains a list of passwords that will be leaked and tries to attack based on it.
A tool that can do this kind of attack is THC Hydra.
Hydra supports many protocols, including FTP, POP3, IMAP, SMTP, SSH, and all methods related to HTTP. The general command line syntax is:
hydra -l username -P wordlist.txt server service
The options are described below:

-l username: , i.e. the login name of the target, which must be preceded by -l.username
-P wordlist.txt: A text file containing a list of passwords to try with the provided username, which must be preceded by -P.wordlist.txt
server The hostname or IP address of the target server.
service The service to start the dictionary attack on.
Real world examples)
hydra -l mark -P /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt MACHINE_IP ftp
There are other arguments you can add:

-s PORT Specifies a non-default port for the service.
-V or -vV For verbose output, tell Hydra to display the username and password combination being attempted.
-t n, where n is the number of parallel connections to the target. -t 16 Spawn 16 threads to connect to the target.
-d, for debugging purposes, get detailed information about what's going on. Debugging output can save you a lot of frustration. For example, if Hydra tries to connect to a closed port and times out, -d will display it immediately.
To protect against attacks like the above, you should use the following: Password Policy: Enforce minimum complexity constraints on passwords set by users.
Account Lockout: Lock accounts after a certain number of failed attempts.
Throttling Authentication Attempts: Deliberately delay the response to a login attempt. A delay of a few seconds is acceptable for a human who knows the password, but can seriously hamper automated tools.
Use CAPTCHA: Require machine-proof challenges. This works well if the login page is a graphical user interface (GUI). (CAPTCHA stands for Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart.)
Requires use of public certificates for authentication. This approach works well with SSH, for example.
Two-step authentication: Asks the user to provide a code that can be redeemed via another means, such as email, a smartphone app, or SMS.
There are many other approaches that are more sophisticated or require some established knowledge about the user, such as IP-based geolocation.


In this lecture, we covered a variety of protocols, their usage, and how they work. The three common attacks are:

Sniffing attacks
MITM attacks
Cryptographic attacks
For each of the above, we focused on both the attack details and mitigation steps.
There are many other attacks that can be performed on specific servers and protocols. Here is a list of some relevant modules.

Vulnerability Research: This module provides detailed information on vulnerabilities and exploits. - Metasploit: This module teaches you how to exploit a target system using Metasploit.
Burp Suite: This module explains how to use Burp Suite to intercept HTTP traffic and launch web-related attacks.
It's a good idea to memorize the default port numbers for common protocols. For your convenience, the services we covered are listed in the following table, sorted alphabetically.

Hydra is a very efficient tool that can be started from the terminal to try different passwords. The main options are summarized in the following table.

item.title: 1. Vulnerability 101
item.description:
A vulnerability in cybersecurity is defined as a weakness or flaw in the design, implementation, or operation of a system or application. An attacker can exploit this weakness to conduct an attack.
In this lesson, we will explain five representative vulnerabilities. Here are the representative vulnerabilities. Please check them carefully.
Representative Vulnerabilities

Issue:
The attacker was able to upgrade the privileges of a system account from "User" to "Administrator". What type of vulnerability is this?
Answer: Operating System
The login panel can be bypassed by using cookies for authentication. What type of vulnerability is this?
Answer: Application Logic


Vulnerability management is the process of assessing, classifying, and ultimately resolving vulnerabilities faced by an organization. Frameworks are used for this purpose, and CVSS is a representative example.
CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System)
First introduced in 2005, the CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System) is a very popular framework for scoring vulnerabilities, and has three main criteria:

How easy is it to exploit the vulnerability?
Is there an exploit for this?
How does this vulnerability violate the three elements of security?
There are so many variables that calculating a score using this framework requires a calculator. The table below shows the grades and ranges of the scores.

However, CVSS is not a foolproof security framework. Here are its pros and cons:

Vulnerability Priority Rating** (VPR)
The VPR framework is a much more modern vulnerability management framework developed by Tenable, an industry solutions provider for vulnerability management. . That is, vulnerabilities are scored based on the risk the vulnerability poses to the organization itself, rather than factors such as impact, as in CVSS.
The VPR score takes into account the relevance of the vulnerability. For example, if the vulnerability does not apply to your organization (i.e., you do not use vulnerable software), the risk associated with the vulnerability is not considered. VPR is also quite dynamic in its scoring. The risk a vulnerability poses can change over time, almost daily.
Here is the VPR scoring table:

The pros and cons are as follows:

Question:
In what year was the first version of CVSS published?
Answer: 2005
What framework should you use to assess vulnerabilities based on the risk they pose to your organization?
Note**:** Looking for an acronym here.
Answer: VPR
If you wanted to use a free, open source framework, which one would you use?
Note**:** Looking for an acronym here.
Answer: CVSS


As you get involved in cybersecurity, you will come across a variety of applications and services. Finding all the vulnerabilities in this vast array of services is nearly impossible on your own.
Fortunately, there are websites on the Internet that document vulnerabilities for all types of software, operating systems, etc. Here are two representative ones:

National Vulnerability Database (NVD)
Exploit-DB
Before diving into these two resources, let's make sure we're on the same page with some basic core terminology.



The National Vulnerability Database is a website that lists all publicly cataloged vulnerabilities. In cybersecurity, vulnerabilities are defined as "Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures**" (or CVEs for short).
The format for these CVEs is CVE-YEAR-IDNUMBER. For example, the vulnerability used by the infamous malware WannaCry is CVE-2017-0144.
With NVD, you can filter by category and submission month to view all identified CVEs. For example, it is the 3rd day of August. There are already 223 new CVEs submitted to this database.

This website is helpful for tracking new vulnerabilities, but it is not good for searching for vulnerabilities for a specific application or scenario.


Exploit-DB is a much more helpful resource for us as hackers during our evaluations. Exploit-DB holds exploits for software and applications, stored by the name, author, and version of the software or application.
You can use Exploit-DB to find code snippets (called proofs of concept) that are used to exploit a specific vulnerability.

Question:
How many CVEs were submitted in July 2021 using NVD
?
Answer: 1585
Who is the author of Exploit-DB
?
Answer: Offensive Security


Here we will show you how to find exploits that work on each version of a program.
Often, you will want to combine multiple vulnerabilities throughout the assessment to get results. For example, in this exercise, we will use the " Version Public**"** vulnerability to find out the version of the application. In this version, you can use Exploit-DB to find exploits that work on a specific version.
For example, in the screenshot below, we can see that the application's name and version number is "Apache Tomcat 9.0.17".

With this** information, let's**use the**search filter of Exploit-DB**** to** find exploits that can be applied to" Apache Tomcat 9.0.17"**.

After searching Exploit-DB, I found that there are a total of 5 exploits that could be useful for this particular version of the application.
Question:
What type of vulnerability did you use to find the name and version of the application in this example?
Answer: Version Disclosure
+) Showcase: Exploiting Ackme's Application
If you follow the showcase that exploits ACKme's application all the way to the end, you can search for flags. What is this flag?
Answer: THM{ACKME_ENGAGEMENT}

item.title: 2. Vulnerability Exploitation
item.description:
Vulnerability scanners are a convenient way to quickly investigate flaws in an application.
For example, the vulnerability scanner Nessus comes in both a free (community) edition and a commercial version. The commercial version, which costs thousands of pounds for a one-year license, is likely to be used by organizations that provide penetration testing services or audits.
The table below details the pros and cons of using a vulnerability scanner.

Frameworks like Metasploit often have vulnerability scanners for some of their modules.
Manual scanning for vulnerabilities is often the weapon of choice for penetration testers when testing individual applications or programs. In fact, manual scanning involves the same vulnerability searches and uses similar techniques as automated scanning.
Ultimately, both techniques involve testing an application or program for vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities include:
| | | |---|---|
|Vulnerability|Description|
|Security Misconfiguration|Security misconfiguration includes vulnerabilities due to developer oversight. For example, server information is exposed in messages between an application and an attacker.|
|Broken Access Control|This vulnerability occurs when an attacker gains access to parts of an application that are otherwise inaccessible.|
|Unsafe Deserialization|This is the insecure handling of data transmitted through an application. An attacker can pass malicious code to the application, causing it to execute.| |injection|An injection vulnerability exists when an attacker can input malicious data into your application. This is because the input is not checked to make sure it is not malicious.|
Question:
You have an upcoming penetration test deadline and need to quickly scan your web application. Would you like to use an automated scanner? (Yes/No)
Answer: Yay
You are testing your web application and have discovered that it is possible to input and retrieve data from your database. What is this vulnerability?
Answer: Injection
You have successfully impersonated another user. What is this vulnerability?
Answer: Broken Access Control


Rapid**7**
Like other services like Exploit DB and NVD, Rapid7 is a vulnerability research database.

The database also contains instructions for exploiting the application using the widely used Metasploit tool.

GitHub
GitHub is a popular web service designed for software developers. The site is used to host and share the source code of applications to enable collaboration. However, security researchers have chosen this platform for the reasons mentioned above. Security researchers store and share their proof of concept (PoC) on GitHub, turning it into an exploit database.
Since anyone can create an account and upload, GitHub is very useful for finding rare or new exploits. There is no formal process like an exploit database, because anyone can upload. That said, there is also the downside that PoCs may not work if support is little or not available at all.

GitHub uses a tagging and keyword system. That is, you can search GitHub for keywords such as "PoC", "vulnerability", etc. At the time of writing, there are 9,682 repositories with the keyword "cve". You can also filter results by programming language.
SearchSploit
Searchsploit is a tool available for popular penetration testing distributions like Kali Linux.
It is an offline copy of the Exploit-DB, which contains copies of exploits on your system.
You can search searchploit by application name and/or vulnerability type. For example, the snippet below searches searchsploit for Wordpress-related exploits that you can use. No downloading required!

Question:
If you were a security researcher, what website would you use to upload a proof of concept?
Answer: Github
I'm performing penetration testing on a site that isn't connected to the internet. What tools can I use to find exploits to exploit?
Answer: Searchsploit


If you can execute commands on a target that is running a vulnerable application or service, you can read files or execute commands that the application or service alone could not do before. You can also use this to gain a foothold on the machine. A foothold is access to the console of the vulnerable system, from which you can exploit other applications or systems on the network.

We will use the exploit to remotely execute commands on the vulnerable system, enabling remote code execution in the application in task 2.
Getting Started Before It is important to note that the exploit is rarely usable out-of-the-box and is ready to use. It often requires some configuration before it will work on your environment or target. The level of configuration varies depending on the exploit, so it is common to find multiple exploits for the same vulnerability in an application. It is up to the user to determine which exploit is most appropriate or useful for them.
For example, in the snippet below, you can see that several options have been changed to reflect the IP address of the system being attacked.
Modify Exploit (Before)
nano exploit.py
mymachine="192.168.1.10"
port="1337"
Modify Exploit (After)
nano exploit.py
mymachine="10.13.37.10"
port="1337"
Now that we have the exploit configured correctly, let's read it in detail and understand how to use it. In the snippet below, we can see that we need to provide two arguments when running the exploit.
Listing arguments for the exploit
exploit.py --help
To use this exploit, provide the following arguments:
-u The URL of the application
-c the command that you wish to execute
With this information in mind, we are now ready to use this exploit on a vulnerable system. We will do the following:

Using the exploit, we will upload a malicious file containing the command we wish to execute to the vulnerable application. The web server will then execute this malicious file, executing the code.
The file will contain a basic command that we will use to first verify that the exploit worked.
We will then read the contents of the file on the vulnerable system.
Run the exploit to print the name of the user the application is running as.
exploit.py -u http://10.10.10.10 -c "whoami"
www-data
Run the exploit to print the contents of files on the target system
exploit.py -u http://10.10.10.10 -c "cat flag.txt"
THM{EXPLOIT_COMPLETE}
Question:
What type of vulnerability was used in this attack?
Answer: Remote Code Execution
+) Practical: Manual Exploitation
Find the version of the application that is running. What is the name and version number of the application?
Answer: Online Book Store v1.0
Use this exploit against vulnerable systems. What is the value of the flag in the web directory?
Deep: THM{BOOK_KEEPING}

item.title: 2st Hacking Response
item.description:
A secondary hacking incident occurred on the same server that we previously responded to. It seems that my earlier concerns were valid; the server remained vulnerable due to the lack of VPN usage. Fortunately, the databases and procedures remained intact. This document will outline the response and the steps taken to reset the server.


The computer that was hacked again had its password changed. To resolve this, I followed the steps outlined in the 1st Hacking Response to reset the locked password and gain access. Upon investigation, I discovered that a virtual machine was running on the server using VMware, and it was being used to mine cryptocurrency.
Identified Risks

Forced installation of a virtual machine on the server for cryptocurrency mining.
Network settings were altered.
Password was changed.


While I initially planned to reset the server and implement VPN configurations, the client requested a migration to AWS Cloud. Before temporarily formatting the physical server, I conducted a root cause analysis. The server was then shut down to prevent further damage.


The connection between the server and the network was severed to prevent the virus or hacker from potentially accessing other entities.


Although I have certifications and experience with Azure, I am less familiar with AWS. To address this, I familiarized myself with the basics of AWS configurations and operations before proceeding with the recovery.
Instance Configuration

Created an instance on the AWS service owned by the client to host the service being recovered.
Settings Location: Seoul Instance Image: Windows Server Instance Type: Cost-effective paid option IP Address: Determined as per the clientâ€™s requirements
Security Configuration


Inbound Rules: Only essential service ports are accessible. Source: Access limited to specific IPs
Detailed configurations are not mentioned here.
Server Setup

Set up the IIS server as per the previous configuration.
Database Setup

Configured MSSQL using AWS RDS.
Detailed server configurations are not mentioned here.
Restoring Backed-Up Database

Connected to the database using SSMS and performed a restoration of the backed-up database.
Problem Encountered

During the database restoration in MSSQL, the process halted, and not all data was restored.
This issue persisted even when using SQL CMD instead of SSMS.
Root Cause Identified

The issue was caused by malicious binary image files inserted into the database from the CMS server.
The excessively large image files exceeded the memory allocated to MSSQL, causing it to halt.
This revealed that one of the hacking methods involved a file injection attack.
Solution

I used Windows commands to split the SQL file, removed the malicious images, and then performed the backup again.
The server was successfully restored following this process.


One of the attack vectors used against the server was a file injection attack. This occurred because the server logic failed to verify the integrity of uploaded files and text. The files were uploaded as binary code, which the server did not adequately filter. As a result, I strengthened the integrity verification logic in the server and redeployed it. This incident reinforced the critical importance of security.
