item.title: 3. Subdomain Enumeration
item.description:
Subdomain enumeration is the process of finding valid subdomains for a domain. But why should we do this? We try to expand the attack surface to discover more potential vulnerabilities.


SSL/TLS Certificates
When a Certificate Authority (CA) issues an SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) certificate for a domain, the CA participates in a "Certificate Transparency (CT) Log." This is a publicly accessible log of all SSL/TLS certificates generated for domain names. The purpose of the Certificate Transparency log is to prevent the use of malicious or mistakenly issued certificates. We can use this service to identify subdomains belonging to a domain by searching through searchable certificate databases provided by sites like crt.sh and https://ui.ctsearch.entrust.com/ui/ctsearchui.
You can search for a domain on the above sites to find the corresponding logs. To find logs related to certificates, you can search using sites like the ones mentioned above.


Search Engines
Search engines contain links to trillions of web pages across billions of websites, making them an excellent resource for discovering new subdomains. Using advanced search methods like the site: filter on websites like Google can help narrow down search results. For example, "-site
.domain.com site:*.domain.com" will include only results that link to the domain name domain.com and exclude links that lead to www.domain.com. This will display only the subdomain names belonging to domain.com.


Bruteforce DNS (Domain Name System) enumeration involves trying tens, hundreds, thousands, or even millions of possible subdomains from a predefined list of commonly used subdomains. This method requires many requests, so tools are often used to automate the process to make it faster.
In this exercise, we used a tool called dnsrecon.


Automation with Sublist3r
To speed up the OSINT subdomain discovery process, you can automate the methods mentioned above using tools like Sublist3r.


Some subdomains are not always hosted on publicly accessible DNS results, such as development versions of web applications or management portals. Instead, DNS records may be kept on private DNS servers, or the domain name can be mapped on the developer's computer in the /etc/hosts file (or for Windows users, in the c:\windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts file) to an IP address.
When a client requests a website, the web server can host multiple websites on a single server because the server knows which website the client wants from the Host header. By changing this Host header and monitoring the response to see if a new website is discovered, you can leverage this Host header.
Like DNS Bruteforce, you can automate this process using a word list of commonly used subdomains.
Practical Exercise
First, launch the Attack Box from the website and enter the given command in the terminal.
ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/SecLists/Discovery/DNS/namelist.txt -H "Host: HOST" -u http://IP_ADDRESS
The above command specifies the word list to be used with the -w switch. The -H switch adds/edits the header (in this case, the Host header). Typically, the FUZZ keyword is used in place of a subdomain, where all options in the word list will be tried.
This command will always produce valid results, so you need to filter the output. You can do this by using the -fs switch with the page size result. Replace {size} with the most frequently occurring size value from previous results, and edit the command as below:
ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/SecLists/Discovery/DNS/namelist.txt -H "Host: HOST -u http://IP_ADDRESS -fs {size}
The syntax for specifying the desired size has been added. After checking the size from previous results, replace the argument and enter it in the terminal to get the desired values.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ì›¹ í•´í‚¹ ì†Œê°œ/Eng/3. Subdomain Enumeration.md

item.title: 4. Authentication Bypass
item.description:
Learn how to bypass login and other authentication mechanisms to allow access to unauthorized areas.


When searching for authentication vulnerabilities, a useful exercise is to create a list of valid usernames that can be used later for other tasks. For example, on a practice site provided, if you enter the user id admin and fill in the other information with false data, an error message indicating that a user with this username exists will be displayed. Using this, we can verify the validity of usernames against a list of used usernames. In this exercise, we will briefly go through this process using a tool called ffuf.
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/SecLists/Usernames/Names/names.txt -X POST -d "username=FUZZ&email=x&password=x&cpassword=x" -H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" -u http://<IP_ADDRESS>/customers/signup -mr "username already exists"
Just enter this command in the terminal, and it will be completed quickly. To explain the arguments of the command above:
Explanation

-w: Selects the file location on your computer that contains the list of usernames to check.
-X: Specifies the request method, with GET being the default request.
-H: Used to add extra headers to the request.
Content-Type: Specifies that form data is being sent to the web server.
-u: Specifies the URL to which the request is sent.
-mr: The text on the page that indicates whether a valid username has been found.
It can be easily used by installing it on Windows or Linux and using the terminal.


A brute force attack is an automated process where commonly used passwords are tried against a single username or, as in our case, a list of usernames. You can conduct a brute force attack using ffuf, which was installed earlier. The exercise can be completed by entering the commands provided on the page, so I wonâ€™t describe it further.
Command Explanation:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
ffuf -w valid_usernames.txt:W1,/usr/share/wordlists/SecLists/Passwords/Common-Credentials/10-million-password-list-top-100.txt:W2 -X POST -d "username=W1&password=W2" -H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" -u http://<IP_ADDRESS>/customers/login -fc 200
Arguments Explanation

W1: Selected a valid username list and W2 a password list to try.
Multiple word lists are again specified with the -w argument but separated by a comma.
The -fc argument is used to check for an HTTP status code other than 200 for positive matches.
Oh, and this command requires that the verified user information text file from the previous step is already saved. Please keep this in mind.


What are logic flaws?
There are cases where the authentication process has logical flaws. A logic flaw occurs when the typical logical path of an application is bypassed, circumvented, or manipulated by a hacker.
Logic Flaw Example
The mock code example below checks whether the clientâ€™s path starts with /admin, and if so, further checks if the client is indeed an admin. If the page does not start with /admin, the page is displayed to the client.
php
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
if( url.substr(0,6) === '/admin') { # Code to check user is an admin } else { # View Page }
Since the PHP code example above uses three equals signs (===), it finds an exact match in the string, including the same case. This code illustrates a logic flaw because an unauthenticated user requesting /admin can view the page without checking their authorization.
Logic Flaw Practical
Practical
Letâ€™s proceed with the exercise. The practice site provided has a password reset function.

Enter the email address provided for testing and then the username, and you will see the following screen.

At this stage, you might wonder what the vulnerability of this application is since you need to know both the email and username, and the password reset link is sent to the account ownerâ€™s email address.
In the second step of the reset email process, the username is submitted to the web server in the POST field, and the email address is sent in the GET field from the query string request.
I will explain this by manually creating a request to the web server using the curl tool.
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
curl 'http://<IP_ADDRESS>/customers/reset?email=robert%40acmeitsupport.thm' -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' -d 'username=robert'
The -H option adds extra headers to the request. In the case of Content-Type, setting it to application/x-www-form-urlencoded tells the web server that form data is being sent, so the request can be understood correctly.
The application uses the query string to look up the user account but later sends the password reset email using the data in the PHP variable within the application logic.
The PHP $_REQUEST variable is an array that includes data received from both the query string and POST data. If the same key name is used in both the query string and POST data, the application logic for this variable will prefer the POST data field over the query string, so you can control where the password reset email is sent by adding another parameter in the POST format.
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
curl 'http://<IP_ADDRESS>/customers/reset?email=robert%40acmeitsupport.thm' -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' -d 'username=robert&email=attacker@hacker.com'
In the next step, you need to create an account in the Acme IT support customer section. This will provide a unique email address that can be used to create a support ticket. The email address is in the format @customer.acmeitsupport.thm.
Now, if you rerun Curl Request 2 but enter @acmeitsupport.thm in the email field, a ticket with a link to log in as Robert will be generated in the account.
Now, using that, you can log in and solve the problem.
In the command used above, enter the email created in the email part, and after running it, check the Support Tickets for the account you just created, and youâ€™ll find a link to reset Robertâ€™s account password.
After that, by going to that link, you can check the answer in the Support Tickets.

The reason this method is possible is that there is no validation between the userâ€™s name and the email they use.
In other words, itâ€™s a logic flaw.
Identifying these kinds of loopholes and hacking them can be considered an interesting challenge.


Inspecting and editing cookies set by the web server during an online session can result in various outcomes such as unauthorized access, access to another userâ€™s account, or elevated privileges.
Plain Text
The contents of some cookies might be plain text, and their functionality may be evident. For example, if it's a cookie set after a successful login:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
Set-Cookie: logging_in=true; Max-Age=3600; Path=/ Set-Cookie: admin=false; Max-Age=3600; Path=/
Here, one cookie (logged_in) appears to control whether the user is currently logged in, and the other (admin) controls whether the visitor has admin privileges. By changing the contents of these cookies and making a request, you may be able to change your permissions.
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
curl -H "Cookie: logged_in=true; admin=false" http://<IP_ADDRESS>/cookie-test curl -H "Cookie: logged_in=true; admin=true" http://<IP_ADDRESS>/cookie-test
This command returns different results from before, as both cookies are now set to true.
Hashing
Sometimes cookie values might look like random long strings. These could be hashes, which are irreversible representations of the original text. Here are some examples you might encounter.

Base64 Encoding
At other times, values might look like this:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
c2VjcmV0X21lc3NhZ2U=
This is not hashed. Itâ€™s encoded using the Base64 encoding method, which is easy to reverse. There are various Base64 decoders available on the internet, including a command-line tool for Linux.
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
echo "c2VjcmV0X21lc3NhZ2U=" | base64 -d
When the above command is executed, the result will be as follows:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
secret_message
Understanding these processes can lead to insights into how cookies can be manipulated.


There are three properties associated with session cookies: randomness, expiration, and uniqueness.

Randomness: A session cookie should be random and non-sequential so that a hacker cannot guess it.
Expiration: A session cookie should expire after a certain period, usually after a user logs out, and definitely after a certain amount of time has passed since the last activity.
Uniqueness: A session cookie should be unique for each user and session.
Imagine a session cookie like this:
bash
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
SESSIONID=1
Itâ€™s clear that an attacker might try to exploit such a session cookie.
After understanding the structure and properties of session cookies, you can use tools like Burp Suite to analyze and manipulate session cookies.
In Burp Suite, you can intercept requests and manipulate cookies to see how the server responds. This can reveal vulnerabilities such as weak session management or poor cookie handling.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ì›¹ í•´í‚¹ ì†Œê°œ/Eng/4. Authentication Bypass.md

item.title: 5. IDOR
item.description:
IDOR stands for Insecure Direct Object Reference and is a type of access control vulnerability.
This type of vulnerability occurs when a web server receives input from a user to search for an object (file, data, document) and trusts this input too much without validating it on the server side.
Example

For example, if you can input a different person's ID value in a path like http://address/profile?user_id=1305 and view others' information without restriction.


Encoded IDs
When transferring data between pages via post data, query strings, or cookies, web developers often encode raw data first. Encoding allows the receiving web server to understand the content. Encoding typically converts binary data to an ASCII string using padding characters such as a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and =. The most common encoding technique on the web is base64 encoding, which is generally easy to find.
You can decode a string using websites like https://www.base64decode.org/, then edit the data and re-encode it using https://www.base64encode.org/, and resubmit the web request to verify changes.
Base64 encoding can indeed be decoded to reveal the original value. By finding and examining the path using this method, you can detect IDOR vulnerabilities.
However, simply hiding paths with encoding isn't enough; more fundamental defenses are needed.


Hashed IDs are a bit more complex than encoded IDs, but they may follow predictable patterns, like a hashed version of an integer value. For example, if ID number 123 is hashed using md5, it becomes 202cb962ac59075b964b07152d234b70.
You can find the original value of a hash by using web services like https://crackstation.net/ that have billions of hash databases. By inputting the hash, you can see if there are matching entries.
Thus, relying solely on hash functions can be risky.


Unpredictable IDs
If you can't detect IDs using the methods above, an excellent way to detect IDOR is to create two accounts and exchange IDs between the two accounts. If you can use the ID number from one account to view content belonging to another user while logged in as a different account (or while not logged in at all), you've found a valid IDOR vulnerability.


The vulnerable endpoint may not always be visible in the address bar. It could be content loaded through AJAX requests or referenced in JavaScript files. Sometimes, endpoints might have unused parameters pushed to production that were used during development. For example, you might see a call to /user/details that shows user information authenticated through a session. However, through parameter mining, you might find a parameter called user_id (e.g., /user/details?user_id=123) that can be used to display information for other users.
So, you must thoroughly check all content and URLs.


Practical Exercise
First, access the website provided by the site and create an account. After logging in, click on the account tab.

After this screen appears and you refresh, you will see a call to the endpoint /api/v1/customer?id= in the developer tools.
This page returns user ID, username, and email address in JSON format. The displayed user information is fetched from the ID parameter in the query string.

Check the "customer" here. You can inspect the parameter and test for vulnerabilities.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ì›¹ í•´í‚¹ ì†Œê°œ/Eng/5. IDOR.md

http://webapp.thm/get.php?file=../../../../boot.ini  ë˜ëŠ”

item.title: 7. XSS
item.description:
XSS is based on JavaScript, so having a basic understanding of the language is helpful. However, none of the examples are overly complex and also include a basic understanding of client-server requests and responses.
Cross-Site Scripting, commonly known as XSS in the cybersecurity community, is classified as an injection attack where malicious JavaScript is injected into a web application with the intent to be executed by other users.


What is a Payload?
In XSS, a payload is the JavaScript code that you want to execute on the target computer. The payload consists of two parts: the intent and the modification.
Here are a few examples of XSS intents:
Proof of XSS:
This is the simplest payload that just needs to show that XSS can be achieved on the website. This is often done by causing a popup alert box with a text string like the following:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<script>alert('XSS');</script>
Session Hijacking:
User session details, such as login tokens, are often stored in cookies on the target system. The following JavaScript retrieves the target's cookies, encodes them with base64 to ensure successful transmission, and then posts them to a website controlled by the attacker. With these cookies, the attacker can take over the target's session and log in as the user.
Key Logger:
The following code acts as a key logger, meaning all input on the webpage is sent to a website controlled by the attacker. This can be highly damaging if the payload is installed on a site where users log in or enter credit card details.
Business Logic:
This payload is much more specific than the examples above. It concerns particular network resources or JavaScript function calls. For example, imagine a JavaScript function user.changeEmail(), which changes a user's email address. The payload might look like this:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<script>user.changeEmail('attacker@hacker.thm');</script>
Reflected XSS
Reflected XSS occurs when user-supplied data in an HTTP request is included in the web page source without validation.
Example Scenario:
A website that displays an error message when invalid input is entered. The error message content is pulled from the error parameter in the query string and is directly included in the page source.
Potential Impact:
The attacker can send a link with a JavaScript payload included in an iframe from another website, tricking the victim into executing code in their browser and potentially exposing session or customer information.
Testing for Reflected XSS:
You should test all possible entry points, including:

URL query string parameters
URL file paths
Sometimes HTTP headers (although the risk is lower in practice)


Stored XSS
As the name suggests, the XSS payload is stored in the web application (e.g., database) and is then executed when other users visit the site or webpage.
Example Scenario:
A blog website where users can post comments. Unfortunately, these comments are not checked to see if they contain JavaScript or malicious code. Posting a comment with JavaScript will store it in the database, and now every user who visits the article will execute JavaScript in their browser.
Potential Impact:
Malicious JavaScript can redirect users to another site, steal users' session cookies, or perform other actions on the web site while impersonating the visiting user.
Testing for Stored XSS:
Test all possible entry points where data is stored and then re-displayed to other users. Examples include:

Blog comments
User profile information
Website listings
Sometimes developers mistakenly believe that limiting input values on the client side is sufficient protection, so testing stored XSS can involve changing values unexpectedly (e.g., trying a malicious payload in a field that expects an integer). Test forms manually by sending requests without using dropdown menus.


What is DOM-Based XSS?
DOM stands for Document Object Model, a programming interface for HTML and XML documents. It represents the structure, style, and content of a document so programs can modify it. A web page is a document, and this document can be displayed in a browser window or as HTML source. An HTML DOM diagram is shown below.
How DOM is Used
DOM-based XSS occurs when JavaScript execution happens directly in the browser without loading a new page or submitting data to the backend code. This execution occurs when web page JavaScript interacts with input or user actions.
Example Scenario:
A websiteâ€™s JavaScript writes content from the window.location.hash parameter into the current page section. Since the hash content is not checked for malicious code, an attacker can inject JavaScript into the webpage.
Potential Impact:
An attacker can send a crafted link to a potential victim, redirecting them to another website or stealing content from the page or user session.
Testing for DOM-Based XSS:
Testing for DOM-based XSS can be challenging and requires some knowledge of JavaScript. Look for specific code sections that handle variables attackers can control, such as "window.location.x" parameters.
Once you find such code snippets, you should check how they are processed, whether values are recorded in the page's DOM, or if they are passed to unsafe JavaScript methods like eval().


Blind XSS
Blind XSS is similar to stored XSS in that the payload is stored in the website for others to see, but in this case, the attacker cannot see or test the payloadâ€™s execution themselves.
Example Scenario:
A website with a contact form that allows users to send messages. The message content is not checked for malicious code. These messages are then converted into support tickets visible in a staff memberâ€™s personal web portal.
Potential Impact:
An attackerâ€™s JavaScript can use a correct payload to call back to the attackerâ€™s website, exposing the staff portal URL, staff cookies, and the contents of the portal page. The attacker could potentially hijack the staff session and access the personal portal.
Testing for Blind XSS:
When testing for Blind XSS vulnerabilities, ensure that the payload includes a callback (typically an HTTP request) so you can determine if and when the code is executed.
A widely used tool for Blind XSS attacks is xsshunter. While it is possible to create your own tool with JavaScript, this tool automatically captures cookies, URLs, and page content.


Practical Exercise
A payload is JavaScript code designed to execute in another user's browser or to prove the vulnerability of a website.
Payloads can range from showing a JavaScript alert box to extracting information from the web page or user session.
The type of payload used depends on how the JavaScript payload is reflected in the target website's code. To demonstrate this, click the green start machine button on the right, and when the machine loads, open the link in a new tab.
Each level's goal is to execute a JavaScript alert function using the string THM. For example:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<script>alert('THM');</script>

A form appears asking for a name, and when you enter a name, it is displayed below. For example:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<script>alert('THM');</script>
When you click Enter, a popup alert with the string THM will appear, and the page source will reflect the result.

Similar to the previous level, a prompt to enter a name is shown. This time, the name is reflected inside the input tag.
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
"><script>alert('THM');</script>
The important part of the payload is closing the input tag with "> and then closing the tag. This will allow the JavaScript payload to execute properly.

A form asking for a name appears, and the name is reflected inside a textarea tag. Use the following payload to escape the textarea tag:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
</textarea><script>alert('THM');</script>
The important part of this payload is closing the textarea element with </textarea>, so the script can be executed.

The form asks for a name, which appears to be similar to Level 1. However, the page source shows that the name is reflected inside some JavaScript code.
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
';alert('THM');//
The payload ends the current command with ;, and // makes everything after it a comment. This way, the JavaScript code will be executed.

This level looks similar to Level 1, but the payload doesnâ€™t work as expected due to a filter removing potentially dangerous words like <script>.
Original Payload:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<sscriptcript>alert('THM');</sscriptcript>
Filtered Text:
html
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<script>alert('THM');</script>
The payload uses <sscriptcript> which is filtered and then executes as <script>.

This level requires escaping from the input tag value attribute, similar to Level 2 but with different results. Check the page source to determine why the payload doesnâ€™t work.

item.title: 8 - 2. Command Injection
item.description:
Information Gathering
Initially, the given IP address is entered as is.

The above result occurs.
Upon testing with different IP addresses, it was discovered that the input value is appended after ping. Based on this, search for usable payloads.
Findings:

Commands like curl were not usable, but special characters such as | were usable.
Attack

| whoami & whoami
With these two commands, the first answer could be obtained.

| cat /home/tryhackme/flag.txt
& cat /home/tryhackme/flag.txt
With these two commands, the second answer could be obtained.
Conclusion:

The vulnerability in the above issue is due to inadequate filtering of input values.
item.guid: Achive/tryhackme/Jr Penetration Tester/ì›¹ í•´í‚¹ ì†Œê°œ/Eng/8 - 2. Command Injection.md

item.title: 8. Command Injection
item.description:
In this session, we will explore the web vulnerability known as command injection. After understanding what this vulnerability is, we will demonstrate its impact and the risks it poses to applications.

How to identify command injection vulnerabilities
How to test and exploit these vulnerabilities using payloads designed for various operating systems
How to prevent command injection vulnerabilities in applications
Finally, you will apply the theory to practice in the hands-on exercise at the end of the session.
First, let's understand what command injection is. Command injection is an exploitation of an application's behavior to execute commands on the operating system with the same privileges as the application is running. For example, if command injection is performed on a web server running under a user named "joe," the commands will be executed under the "joe" user, gaining all the permissions that the "joe" user has.
Command injection vulnerabilities are also known as "Remote Code Execution" (RCE) because attackers can trick the application into executing a series of payloads that ultimately allow them to run commands on the system without direct access (e.g., through an interactive shell). The web server processes this code and executes it according to the permissions and access controls of the user running the application.
Command injection is also referred to as "Remote Code Execution" (RCE) because it allows for remote execution of code within the application. These vulnerabilities are often most advantageous to attackers because they imply that the attacker can interact directly with the vulnerable system. For example, attackers may be able to read system or user files, data, and other similar items.
For example, using command injection to abuse an application to run a command like whoami to list the user account under which the application is running is a classic example of command injection.
Command injection was listed as one of the top 10 vulnerabilities in the 2019 Contrast Security AppSec Intelligence Report (Contrast Security AppSec., 2019). The OWASP framework also consistently includes such vulnerabilities as one of the top 10 in web applications (OWASP Framework).


This vulnerability exists because applications often use functions from programming languages like PHP, Python, and NodeJS to pass data to the system operating system and make system calls. For example, they might receive input from a field and search for items in a file. Let's look at a code snippet to illustrate this.
In this code snippet, the application retrieves data entered by the user in a field named $title and searches for directories related to song titles. Let's break this down into a few simple steps.

Process
1. The application stores MP3 files in directories included in the operating system.
2. The user inputs the song title they want to search. The application stores this input in the $title variable.
3. The data in this variable is passed to a command $title that searches for a text file called songtitle.txt for the item the user wants to search for. _grep
4. The search result of the song title in the _.txt_ determines whether the application informs the user whether the song exists.
This kind of information is generally stored in a database. However, this is an example of a case where an application receives input from a user to interact with the applicationâ€™s operating system.
Attackers can exploit this application by injecting their own commands to have the application execute them. Instead of using grep to search for items in songtitle.txt, they might request the application to read data from more sensitive files.
Exploiting applications in this manner can occur regardless of the programming language used. Command injection can occur as long as the application processes and executes commands. For example, consider the following code
4o mini

ë‹¤ì‹œ ìƒì„±í•´ì¤˜ ì¤‘ê°„ì— ì§¤ë ¸ì–´

ChatGPT

In this session, we will explore the web vulnerability known as command injection. After understanding what this vulnerability is, we will demonstrate its impact and the risks it poses to applications.

How to identify command injection vulnerabilities
How to test and exploit these vulnerabilities using payloads designed for various operating systems
How to prevent command injection vulnerabilities in applications
Finally, you will apply the theory to practice in the hands-on exercise at the end of the session.
First, let's understand what command injection is. Command injection is an exploitation of an application's behavior to execute commands on the operating system with the same privileges as the application is running. For example, if command injection is performed on a web server running under a user named "joe," the commands will be executed under the "joe" user, gaining all the permissions that the "joe" user has.
Command injection vulnerabilities are also known as "Remote Code Execution" (RCE) because attackers can trick the application into executing a series of payloads that ultimately allow them to run commands on the system without direct access (e.g., through an interactive shell). The web server processes this code and executes it according to the permissions and access controls of the user running the application.
Command injection is also referred to as "Remote Code Execution" (RCE) because it allows for remote execution of code within the application. These vulnerabilities are often most advantageous to attackers because they imply that the attacker can interact directly with the vulnerable system. For example, attackers may be able to read system or user files, data, and other similar items.
For example, using command injection to abuse an application to run a command like whoami to list the user account under which the application is running is a classic example of command injection.
Command injection was listed as one of the top 10 vulnerabilities in the 2019 Contrast Security AppSec Intelligence Report (Contrast Security AppSec., 2019). The OWASP framework also consistently includes such vulnerabilities as one of the top 10 in web applications (OWASP Framework).


This vulnerability exists because applications often use functions from programming languages like PHP, Python, and NodeJS to pass data to the system operating system and make system calls. For example, they might receive input from a field and search for items in a file. Let's look at a code snippet to illustrate this.
In this code snippet, the application retrieves data entered by the user in a field named $title and searches for directories related to song titles. Let's break this down into a few simple steps.

Process
1. The application stores MP3 files in directories included in the operating system.
2. The user inputs the song title they want to search. The application stores this input in the $title variable.
3. The data in this variable is passed to a command $title that searches for a text file called songtitle.txt for the item the user wants to search for. _grep
4. The search result of the song title in the _.txt_ determines whether the application informs the user whether the song exists.
This kind of information is generally stored in a database. However, this is an example of a case where an application receives input from a user to interact with the applicationâ€™s operating system.
Attackers can exploit this application by injecting their own commands to have the application execute them. Instead of using grep to search for items in songtitle.txt, they might request the application to read data from more sensitive files.
Exploiting applications in this manner can occur regardless of the programming language used. Command injection can occur as long as the application processes and executes commands. For example, consider the following code snippet written in Python.

Understanding the syntax of these applications is not required, but the steps of how this Python application works are briefly explained.

The "flask" package is used to set up the web server.
The "subprocess" package provides the functionality to execute commands on the device.
The web server uses the provided path to execute everything. For example, to run whoami, one would visit http://flaskapp.thm/whoami.


As you will see in the hands-on session of this room, it is often possible to determine whether command injection can occur due to the application's behavior.
Applications that use user input to fill system commands are often susceptible to unintended behavior. For example, shell operators such as ; (or more) can combine system commands using & and && to execute both.
Command injection can typically be detected in one of the following two ways:

Blind Command Injection
Verbose Command Injection
The table below defines these two methods and explains them in detail in the following sections.
Table

Detecting Blind Command Injection
Blind command injection is when command injection occurs, but the output is not immediately visible due to the lack of displayed output. For example, the command might execute, but the web application does not display a message.
To detect this type of command injection, you should use payloads that induce some time delay. For example, the ping and sleep commands are useful payloads for testing. For instance, the ping command will cause the application to pause for a number of seconds related to the ping count specified.
Another way to detect blind command injection is to force some output. This can be done using redirection operators like > and <. For example, you can execute a command on the web application that redirects whoami to a file, and then use a command like cat to read the contents of the newly created file.
Testing command injection in this way can be complex and often requires a lot of experimentation due to differences in command syntax between Linux and Windows.
The curl command is a good method for testing command injection because it can be used to pass data between applications. For example, a simple curl payload can be used for command injection:
curl [http://vulnerable.app/process.php%3Fsearch%3DThe%20Beatles%3B%20whoami](http://vulnerable.app/process.php%3Fsearch%3DThe%20Beatles%3B%20whoami)
Detecting Verbose Command Injection
Detecting command injection in this way is undoubtedly the easiest of the two methods. Verbose command injection occurs when the application provides feedback or output about the action or process occurring or running.
For example, the output of commands like ping or whoami is directly displayed on the web application.
Useful Payloads
Below is a compilation of several important payloads for both Linux and Windows.
Linux

Windows



Command injection can be prevented in various ways. From minimizing the use of potentially dangerous functions or libraries in programming languages to filtering inputs without relying on user input. Below are some more detailed explanations. The examples below are in PHP, but the same principles can be extended to many other languages.
Vulnerable Functions
In PHP, many functions interact with the operating system and execute commands via the shell. These include:

exec
passthru
system
Consider the snippet below where the user input is directly used in the command. This is a classic example of vulnerability:
php
ì½”ë“œ ë³µì‚¬
<?php $title = $_GET['title']; system("grep " . escapeshellarg($title) . " songtitle.txt"); ?>
Prevention
To prevent command injection:

Validate Inputs: Ensure all input is validated and sanitized. Only allow a specific format or set of characters that the input can contain.
Use Safe Functions: Where possible, use functions that do not execute system commands. For example, use mysqli or PDO for database queries instead of concatenating user inputs into system commands.
Escaping: Use escaping functions specific to the programming language and environment. For example, in PHP, use escapeshellarg() to escape arguments passed to shell commands.


At the end of the session, you will apply your knowledge in a practical exercise. This hands-on task will involve identifying and exploiting command injection vulnerabilities in a controlled environment. You will:

Identify Vulnerabilities: Using the techniques discussed, find command injection vulnerabilities in a sample application.
Exploit Vulnerabilities: Test various payloads to exploit the vulnerabilities and understand their impact.
Mitigate Risks: Apply preventive measures to secure the application and ensure it is not vulnerable to command injection.
By the end of the session, you should have a solid understanding of command injection vulnerabilities, how to exploit them, and how to prevent them.

item.title: Using the Application
item.description:
This section teaches you how to manually review a web application for security issues using only the tools built into your browser.
Below is a brief explanation of the built-in browser tools you will use:

View Source - View the human-readable source code of a website using your browser.
Inspector - Learn how to inspect page elements and change them to view usually blocked content.
Debugger - Inspect and control the flow of JavaScript on a page.
Network - Review all network requests made by the page.

Even basic browsing can lead to important information or access to certain pages. Using these functions, you can conduct simple security checks.
Below is a useful URL for website exploration provided by Tryhackme.




Let's start the practice. First, connect to the website provided. Of course, make sure to boot up the virtual machine within the website.
Once you boot it up, you'll see a screen like the one below.

At first, I thought I needed to find a flag within the HTML of this page, so I searched here and there using developer tools.
But that wasn't what the challenge was asking for. Let's first look at the HTML code.

If you look carefully, youâ€™ll see some "href" tags pointing to certain locations. So I started investigating these tags. I used the method of simply following the tags to see where they led.
However, I couldn't find any answers within the links embedded in the navigation (nav) section. But while searching through the comments, I discovered something at the very top:

I found this part. You need to follow the page mentioned here.
URL + the above-mentioned page.
Then you'll see something like this:

This is the answer to the first question.
The second challenge follows a similar approach.

This is the code I showed you earlier. If you look closely, youâ€™ll notice an unused path /secret-page. You need to access this page using the same method as before.
If you do this:

Youâ€™ll find another answer.
The third challenge took me quite a bit of time. I initially thought that entering random links would give me the answer. But if you read the question carefully, you'll find the solution.
â€œHTML code can be used to include external files such as CSS, JavaScript, and images. In this example, we can see that these files are all stored in the same directory. If you view this directory in a web browser, there is a configuration error. Instead of a blank page or a 403 Forbidden error page (indicating you don't have access to the directory), directory listing is enabled, which lists all the files in the directory. Sometimes this isn't an issue, and all files in the directory are publicly viewable. However, in some cases, backup files, source code, or other confidential information might be stored there. In this case, you will find the flag in a flag.txt file.â€
It clearly mentions that directory "listing" is enabled. We can view the directories that make up the source using developer tools.
Specifically:

This one here. I initially tried the approach of accessing the answer by entering the URL + assets + flag.txt, but thereâ€™s another method that I will describe here.
The first method is as described: URL + assets + flag.txt.
You can directly access the flag file, which contains the answer.
The second method involves entering:
URL + assets.
If you do this:

You'll see the files inside. Among them, you need to access flag.txt to find the answer.
The last challenge was more difficult than expected because it required a step-by-step approach. Let's proceed in order. When you look at the comments, you'll see that the framework currently in use is mentioned with a link.

When you access the link,

you'll see a screen like this. I see it in Korean because my browser is set to automatic translation. We saw earlier that the version mentioned in the comments was 1.2, but the current version is 1.3. Keep this difference in mind. Let's head over to the documentation from here.

The documentation states that if you use this framework, you can create that link and log in with that information. So, what does the change log say? Let's take a look.
We can learn many things here, but we need to focus on version 1.3. Before this update, a file called tmp.zip was created in the directory, and it was accessible. So, we should check that, right? However, in the assets directory, which we have access to, there was no such file. Therefore, we need to log in on the login page we saw earlier, right? Please log in using the information you remembered earlier.

After logging in, you might see a flag similar to the one above. But that's not the answer. We clearly saw that the issue of accessing tmp.zip was fixed in version 1.3. However, we are currently accessing a website that uses version 1.2. Therefore, we should be able to access that file.
So, if you add tmp.zip to the link, you should be able to download that file. If you read the file, you'll find the answer. This practice was something I've done before, but it was the first time I approached it by carefully gathering and deducing information step by step. It made the process more interesting, and I feel like I still have a lot to learn. ### 3. Developer Tools â€“ Inspector All modern browsers come with developer tools. These are toolkits that help web developers debug web applications and allow you to peek inside a website to check your progress. As penetration testers, we can leverage these tools to gain a much better understanding of web applications. We are particularly focused on three features of the developer tools: Inspector, Debugger, and Network. ## Practice This practice is a continuation of the previous one. Move to the article page and manipulate the CSS and HTML of the third article.

When you first access the page, you'll see a screen like this. Now, let's look at the HTML and recognize the situation to resolve it. The top-level tag hiding the screen is

as shown above. The CSS class is also mentioned. Let's check that part.

When we look at the CSS, we see something like this. However, the display is set to block. So, what should we do? You need to change the display value to none. After making this change, the answer should appear on the screen. ### 4. Developer Tools â€“ Debugger This panel of the developer tools is for JavaScript debugging, an excellent feature for web developers who want to figure out why something isn't working. However, as penetration testers, it provides us with options to dive deep into the JavaScript code. In Firefox and Safari, this feature is called Debugger, while in Google Chrome, it is called Sources. ## Practice First, enter the contact section of the link, and in the assets folder, you'll see a file called flash.min.js.

This small piece of JavaScript removes the red popup from the page. We can utilize another feature of the debugger called breakpoints. This allows us to force the browser to stop processing the JavaScript and pause the current execution. Click on the line number that contains the above code, and it will turn blue. You have now inserted a breakpoint on this line. If you refresh the page, you'll notice that the red box remains on the page and contains the flag. By doing this and double-clicking, you can stop at the breakpoint you've marked and find the answer. ## 5. Developer Tools â€“ Network Using the Network tab in the developer tools, you can track all external requests made by a webpage. Click on the Network tab and refresh the page to see all the files being requested by the page.

Try this on the contact page. If the list becomes a bit cluttered, you can clear it by clicking on the trash icon. With the Network tab open, fill out the contact form and press the Send Message button. You will see the event in the Network tab, and this is a form submission using a method called AJAX. AJAX is a method of exchanging data with a web application in the background, without interfering with the current webpage. Inspect the new item generated in the Network tab by the contact form, and you will see the page where the data was sent to reveal the flag. This practice also takes place on the CONTACT page. --- Let me know if you need any more translations or explanations!

item.title: INFORMATION SYSTEMS AUDITING PROCESS - 1
item.description:
IS Audit Charter
A comprehensive document that defines the roles and responsibilities of the audit function. It details responsibilities, authority, and duties, and must be approved by the board or a sponsor.
IS Audit Program
A document that records the process of planning and executing an audit. It must be approved before the audit begins and can only be urgently modified in critical situations. It describes the field audit procedures.
IS Audit Work Papers
Documents that record all audit procedures and techniques used during the audit. Electronic audit work papers must have well-managed access controls and be documented for quality assurance, reference by other auditors, and litigation purposes.


The IS auditorâ€™s findings and recommendations are reviewed to determine if the follow-up conducted by management was appropriate.


Audit evidence is evaluated based on the following criteria:



Here are commonly tested types of risks:
Inherent Risk
Threats that inherently exist, which can be reduced through compensating controls but are difficult for auditors to control.
Control Risk
The risk of not detecting and correcting errors, which cannot be significantly improved in the short term but can be addressed through the auditor's recommendations in the medium to long term.
Detection Risk
Divided into sampling risk and non-sampling risk.

Sampling Risk: The risk that a sample may not represent the population.
Non-Sampling Risk: Occurs when problems arise in audit procedures, often due to auditor mistakes or incompetence. It can be mitigated through training, education, and adjusting the audit's intensity.
Audit Risk
The risk that an auditor issues a report without properly identifying problems. Audit risk is calculated as the product of inherent risk, control risk, and detection risk.
Business Risk
Management defines acceptable risks, and auditors should set audit risk lower than business risk.


Effective risk management involves a thorough understanding of the organization's risk appetite. What is the best document for understanding the organizationâ€™s risk appetite?
Risk Management Strategy Sequence

Define risk appetite: For example, issues related to accounting.
Identify risks: For example, exposure of accounting records.
Develop risk management strategies: Based on the information above.
Five Ways to Control Risk

Avoidance (Eliminating the cause of the problem): Completely removing the cause of the risk. It is the most definitive method but can be costly.
Mitigation (Reducing the risk): Internally implementing measures to reduce risk. For example, using VPNs to restrict access if API security is vulnerable.
Transfer: Using third parties to handle or transfer responsibility. Example: Insurance, outsourcing.
Acceptance: Acknowledging the risk without taking action. Auditors must ensure that risk acceptance is appropriate.
Ignorance: Not being aware of the risk and not addressing it.
Risk Management Process

Risk Identification: Identify assets.
Risk Analysis/Evaluation: Analyze and evaluate risks.
Risk Control: Apply controls. Evaluate and confirm existing controls.
Continuous Monitoring: Residual risk remains after controls, which should be mitigated based on auditor recommendations. Management must determine acceptable risk levels.
Periodic Reporting: Regular reporting is required.


Risk Analysis Cycle

When significant changes or threats occur (Priority 1).
At least once a year (Priority 2).
Risk Analysis Methods


Delphi Technique: Consulting experts anonymously.
Questionnaire Method: Analyzing through questionnaires.
Scenario Method: Analyzing through various scenarios.


Expressing threat probabilities numerically: Quantitative approach.
Complex Methods: Analysis may be complex.


Not all errors or fraud can be completely eliminated.
Apply the principle of materiality, and auditors must exercise professional judgment.
Focus on high-risk areas to use resources efficiently.
2. Security Principles

item.title: INFORMATION SYSTEMS AUDITING PROCESS - 2
item.description:
Annual Audit Planning
Individual Audit Planning
Field Audit Planning
Reporting
Follow-Up
Field Audit
Field audit planning is broadly divided into General Controls (testing the environment and operations) and Application Controls. It is important to distinguish between these and make accurate judgments.


Evaluate whether the control is suitable for the current situation or environment.


Tests the organizationâ€™s environment as a whole.
Tests compliance with rules or the appropriateness of the rules.


Verifies the quality of actual performance.
Demonstrates controls that are not well followed.
Verifies the integrity of actual processing.
Validates the results.
Actually performs tests (e.g., checking if the financial statements are correct).
Reporting

Discuss findings with the auditee. Ensure they understand and agree with the findings.
Conduct an exit meeting with the auditor and distribute the audit report.
Follow-Up

Review to determine if corrective actions by management on recommendations have achieved the intended purpose.
No documentation or follow-up is necessary if management has decided to accept the risk.
**What is the purpose of the IS auditorâ€™s review of managementâ€™s corrective actions? To determine whether the corrective actions have been successfully implemented to reduce or eliminate the risk, based on the auditorâ€™s recommendations.



Independence (often a common issue in exams)
Professional judgment/standards
Competency: Proper qualifications
Materiality



Established under the Board of Directors and composed of external directors who do not participate in management (external directors at the management level)
Provides authority and independence to the audit function.
Monitors managementâ€™s misconduct.


These are definitely included in exams

Preventive Controls: Controls that prevent problems before they occur.
Segregation of duties (task separation, job rotation), physical access controls, transaction approval procedures, etc.
Detective Controls: Controls that detect and report problems.
Hash totals, checkpoints, audits, access logs
Corrective Controls: Controls that minimize threats and restore systems to normal operation.
BCP (Business Continuity Planning), recovery and backup, risk reduction through corrective actions.
Compensating Controls: Controls that supplement existing controls to address potential or existing risks.
Reduces inherent risks through compensating controls.
Example: Finding patches to address vulnerabilities in irreplaceable existing modules.
Governance is always the Boardâ€™s responsibility Management responsibility lies with senior executives and officers



Understand the environment and review documentation - Review workplace operations, previous audit reports, analyze other company materials, and understand the environment.
Analytical review procedures.
Surveys.
Kick-off meetings, preliminary meetings.


Control Testing (Compliance Testing)

Verifies whether control procedures are followed as defined.
Tests compliance with rules and their effectiveness.
This is an environmental test.
Uses attribute sampling.
Substantive Testing

Verifies the integrity of actual processing.
Tests the integrity of specific processes or applications (more detailed).
Uses variable sampling.
Actual performance tests.



Statistical Sampling: Provides an objective measure of error rates with an objective standard.
Random Sampling: Sampling is done randomly.
Systematic Sampling: The first sample is randomly selected, and subsequent samples are selected at regular intervals.
Non-Statistical Sampling: Sampling is done arbitrarily.
Attribute Sampling: Used for compliance testing and general controls.
Divided into interval sampling and discovery sampling.
Interval Sampling: Continues sampling until the sampleâ€™s population error rate is lower than expected results, and stops when a population meeting the expected results is obtained.
Discovery Sampling: Sampling used to detect errors or fraud.
Variable Sampling: Used for substantive testing and application controls.
Verifies the integrity of actual results.
Stratified Sampling: Divides the population based on specific criteria. Reduces sample size by limiting the sampling target population.



GAS (General Audit Software): General-purpose audit software.
SAS (Specialized Audit Software): Software used for specific purposes.
White Box: Audits by looking into the internal logic.
Black Box: Audits by examining external functionality only.


Refers to self-auditing.
Identifies high-risk areas.
The auditor acts as a facilitator.
Can boost the morale of internal staff.
Conducted in workshop format.
Evaluation is done by management.
CSA is led by operational managers.


ISACA establishes this code of ethics to provide guidance on the professional and personal conduct of its members and certification holders.
ISACA members and certification holders must adhere to the following:
Support and promote adherence to effective governance, management, auditing, controls, security, and risk management standards and procedures applicable to information systems and technology.
Perform their duties with objectivity, due diligence, and professional care according to the standards of their profession.
Maintain high standards of conduct and integrity, avoid actions that may discredit their profession or association, and contribute to stakeholdersâ€™ benefits through lawful means.
Maintain the privacy and confidentiality of information obtained during the performance of their duties unless required by law. Information should not be used for personal gain or disclosed to inappropriate parties.
Agree to perform work only if they have the necessary skills, knowledge, and ability to complete it effectively.
Disclose all significant facts that may distort the results of their work and communicate the results to appropriate parties (to the audited department, not to other departments!).
Support the understanding of stakeholders about the governance, management, auditing, controls, security, and risk management of information systems and technology by promoting their professional education.




Corporate Governance: Controls to achieve corporate objectives.
Information Protection Governance: Aims at protection and improving operational efficiency.
IT Governance: Strategic alignment, value delivery (benefit-based), performance measurement (using BSC for IT performance measurement) -> Sharing organizational strategy. Includes resource management and risk management.
Management recognizes risks.
The ideal situation is understanding the organizationâ€™s risk appetite.
Responsibility always lies with the organization.
Compliance (Policy Management)



Continuously monitors policies, laws, regulations, etc.
Reviews IT governance and identifies areas for improvement.
Recommends best practices to management.
Assists in ensuring policy compliance.
Evaluates with an independent and objective perspective.
Objectives: Increase resource efficiency, protect resources, implement IT strategy.

Strategic alignment between business and IT.
Effective IT governance.
Demonstrate leadership to ensure assurance.
Ensure proper organizational structure.
Support the effective execution of processes.



Responsibilities: Prioritize projects, schedule projects, allocate project resources, mediate opinions between teams.



Expected Benefits of Information Protection Governance:
Provides reliability to trading partners and customers.
Offers better efficiency.
Enhances corporate image.

item.title: Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management**
item.description:
Officially authorizes the existence of a project.
Grants the project manager the authority to use organizational resources.
Approved by a senior executive or sponsor.



Important for exams
Conducted to address organizational strategic objectives or business issues.
Essentially answers the question: Why is this project being undertaken?
Key Issues

Necessity: Why is this project needed?
Legitimacy: Is this project legal and legitimate?
Expected Benefits: What benefits will this project bring to the organization?
Tip

The business case should be included in the project charter.
The business case is performed during the feasibility study.
It may be reviewed and modified later.
It must be approved by senior management or sponsors.
Any changes require approval from senior management.



A consultative body consisting of senior representatives.
Chairperson: Project Sponsor (Project Owner)
Provides strategic direction for the project, represents the interests of various groups, and holds full responsibility.
Tip

All responsibility for the project lies with the Steering Committee.
Holds the authority for corrective actions and project termination.
With great responsibility comes great authority.


Audit Committee (Composed of external directors not involved in management)

Symbolizes the independence and authority of the audit function.
Thus, extensive discussions are held with the Audit Committee to ensure independence during the audit process.
IT Strategy Committee

Provides strategic direction and advice to ensure the organization's strategy aligns with its IS (IT) strategy.
IS Operations Committee

Ensures that "project" activities align with the organization's information strategy objectives, providing strategic direction and advice.



A review conducted 6 to 12 months after project completion to assess whether the project has met its objectives.
Tip

Performed by the end-users and the project development team.
Different from a post-project review.


Important for exams
Source Lines of Code (SLOC)

Estimates project size based on the number of lines of code. Function Point Analysis (FPA)
Estimates project size based on the size of each function.
The most effective and preferred technique. Delphi Technique
Gathers expert opinions anonymously. Regression Analysis
Uses historical data for analysis.


PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique)

Views the project as a set of related activities and expresses their relationships.
Path: A sequence of tasks without loops.
Shortest Project Completion Time: The longest path.
CPM (Critical Path Method)

Uses the average of the shortest and longest completion times.
Slack Time: The difference between the minimum and maximum completion times.
Allocating more resources to the critical path (CP) can shorten project completion time.
Gantt Chart

Displays time on the horizontal axis and project activities on the vertical axis, using bars to represent tasks.
Time Boxing

Requires delivering results within a set time frame.
Allows defining outcomes with limited time and resources.
Milestone

Marks important events or points during the project. -> These points must be reached for the project to continue.
Used for schedule management.


Waterfall Model

Progresses sequentially, emphasizing strict project management and standardization.
Used when the project is stable, and requirements do not change significantly. Important for exams
Prototyping Model

An interim model shaped according to user requirements. Types
Experimental Prototyping: Created only for communication with users, then discarded.
Evolutionary Prototyping: Created for communication and as an initial version. Spiral Model
Combines evolutionary prototyping with risk management.
Involves iterative cycles of planning, risk analysis, development, and customer evaluation.
Focuses on risk management. Iterative Model
A combination of Waterfall, Prototyping, and Spiral models.
All phases are repeated iteratively.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain3/Eng/Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management.md

item.title: Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management
item.description:
Feasibility Study (Is it really necessary?)
Requirements Definition
Design (Detailed Design), Development, Testing
Implementation (Acceptance Testing, etc.) - Post-Implementation
Feasibility Review

Must be conducted to increase the probability of project success.
Expectation of benefits, development costs, risk analysis, management review, execution.
Should be reviewed periodically.
Requirements Definition

Basic Design: Define and analyze user requirements (involving users and management).
Officially document system requirements.
Review whether an embedded audit model is needed; if so, include conceptual design.
Business Case preparation stage.
Acceptance test requirements are determined at this stage.
Design (Detailed Design)

Detailed Design
Focused review by CISA.
Verify if the program is coded with appropriate control procedures.
Ensure all changes have been approved by management.
Baseline: Can mitigate issues related to scope changes.
Baseline serves as the standard for configuration management and is subject to change management.



Development by connecting components.
Reduces development time, costs, improves quality, and promotes modularization.



System flexibility.
User convenience.
Provides integration with existing systems.
Cost-effective.
Platform-independent and implements standardized business logic.
Operation Process

Define and Register Service
Search for Web Service
Locate Web Service
Request Web Service
Execute Web Service



Reflects user requirements as much as possible when developing part or the whole system. Considerations
Increased threats but reduced assets or time.
Difficult to control.
If too focused on user requirements, development control may be neglected.
Harder to manage changes than with other methods.
Frequent design or requirement changes can make quality management, approval, and management difficult.



Increases asset efficiency and maintains quality while accelerating development speed.
Development and Testing SWOT.
Uses evolutionary prototyping, automated development tools, integrated environments, and a central repository.
Strict adherence to development time (Time boxing technique).



Achieves greater benefits by rapidly adapting to a fast-changing environment.



Consider existing business processes and radically redesign them.
Requires medium to long-term improvements due to significant overall changes.
Post-improvement evaluation is conducted simply.
CISA Auditor's Perspective

Exam Tip
After BPR, verify what impact it has on existing controls.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain3/Eng/Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management 2.md

item.title: Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management
item.description:
Feasibility Study
Analysis
Design
Development
Testing
Implementation
Feasibility Review

Must be conducted to increase the likelihood of project success.
Review expected benefits, development costs, risk analysis, quality management, and execution.
Should be reviewed periodically.
Requirements Definition (Basic Design, Basic Analysis)

Basic Design: Define and analyze user requirements (involving users and management).
Officially document system requirements.
Review whether an embedded audit model (EAM) is needed; if so, include conceptual design.
Business Case preparation stage.
Review user acceptance test specifications.
Acceptance test requirements are determined at this stage.
[Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management 2 > ^34c1ec]
Design (Detailed Design)

Detailed Design
Focused review by CISA.
Verify if the program is coded with appropriate control procedures.
Ensure all changes have been approved by management.
Baseline: Can mitigate issues related to scope changes.
Baseline serves as the standard for configuration management and is subject to change management. Development
Coding standards for source code become important standards.
Ensure errors in the programming process are properly addressed.


Unit Testing

Tests individual modules or programs to ensure functionality matches specifications.
Integration Testing

Tests connections and integrations between components.
System Testing

Tests multiple modules and functions as a complete system.
Types
Recovery Testing: Tests whether recovery processes work well. Security Testing: Tests access controls and checks for security vulnerabilities. Stress and Volume Testing: Tests load and limits. Performance Testing: Tests performance.
Acceptance Testing

Tests whether the system meets user requirements (final user verification).
Upon completion, users sign the acceptance document.
Other Testing
Types
Alpha Testing: Conducted by internal users within the organization. Beta Testing: Conducted by a limited number of external users (potential security vulnerabilities). White Box Testing: Examines the internal logic of the program. Black Box Testing: Tests the external functionality of the program. Parallel Testing: Compares results between the current system and the new system. ITF (Integrated Facility): Inputs test data into the currently operating computer and compares results with expected values. Regression Testing: Tests to ensure that new program introductions or updates do not introduce issues. Usability Testing: Tests whether there are issues when new programs or systems are introduced.


Bottom-Up Testing

Tests from small modules to the entire system.
Easier to detect early module errors.
Easier to implement.
Top-Down Testing

Proceeds from large parts to smaller parts in a top-down manner.
Easier to detect interface errors.
Examines functionality and critical processes.
CISA involves transitioning implementation from development to operations.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain3/Eng/Information System Acquisition, Development, and Management 3.md

item.title: Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management
item.description:
Controls unauthorized traffic.
Vulnerable to internal attacks.
A preventive control.


Exam Topic
Service Overview Concepts

SLR: Service Level Requirement (business proposal)
SLA: Service Level Agreement (acceptance of business)
SLM: Service Level Management (performance management)
SLP: Service Level Plan (plans for service improvement if service is lacking)
SLO: Service Level Objective (performance targets, rewards, and penalties - rewards for good performance, penalties for poor performance)



Every deployment (release) has a serial number/version.
Types
Major Release: Significant changes, follows deployment processes. Minor Release: Smaller or minor changes, follows deployment processes. Emergency Release: Rapid or urgent deployment.


Quality Assurance

Managing programs, source code, and object code using libraries.
Asset Management

The most important asset is people.
Hardware Maintenance Plan

Proposals are sent in the form of RFP (Request for Proposal) or ITT (Invitation to Tender), and vendors submit proposals.


What Should Be Included in an RFP

User requirements
Additional requirements
Evaluation criteria
What Should Not Be Included in an RFP

Detailed specifications (not necessary for the contract)
Security configurations
Budget


External Schema

The database that users or programs can access.
View

A subset of the database.
Also known as a sub-schema and serves as a preventive control.
Prevents damage by protecting original data.


Normalization

Reduces redundancy, increases efficiency.
Focuses on integrity.
Ensures compliance with structural and non-structural queries in relational databases.
Aims to minimize the amount of necessary data.
Denormalization

Increases redundancy, increases efficiency.


Checkpoints

Create checkpoints for backups.
Similar to snapshots.
Database Reorganization

Cleans up garbage values or space in the database.



Entity Integrity: Primary key.
Referential Integrity: Foreign key.
Domain Integrity: Range issues.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain4/Eng/Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management 1.md

item.title: Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management
item.description:
An agreement where a third party holds the source code and provides it if the business fails or is unable to maintain/repair it for various reasons.
The developer can protect their copyright, and the customer can have assurance of maintenance/repair at a minimal cost.
Contract Requirements

Source code, electronic equipment, developer contact information (not highly critical).


Session Layer
Devices: Gateway, L7 switch

The initial layer to apply security functions.
Data Link Layer
Devices: Switch

Error detection using CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check).


Parity Check

Maintains the number of bits as always odd or even for error detection.
Only capable of detecting errors.
Cannot detect errors if multiple errors occur simultaneously.
Block Summation Check

Performs both horizontal and vertical parity checks for more reliable detection.
CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check)

Uses hashing -> Classified as a detection control.
Strong and easy to implement, capable of detecting frame-level errors -> Used in the Data Link Layer.
Can detect multiple bit errors.



Definitely on the exam.
Types
Checksum: Transmission control, most effective control. Parity Check: Transmission control, related to the integrity of transmission messages. Check Digit: Used to verify the accuracy of identification numbers, account numbers, etc.; an input control (accuracy verification). Check Digit, Badge Register Key Verification: Input control. Exception Reports: Output control. Reconciliation, Adjustment: Processing control. Parity Check, Checksum, CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check): Transmission control. File Updates: File control.


Forward Error Correction

Error detection and correction are possible at the receiving end. Used for long or costly transmission paths.
Backward Error Correction

Only error detection is possible at the receiving end.
WAN Technologies

X.25: Retransmits upon error detection. Slow speed and high overhead.
Frame Relay: High transmission efficiency, error handling is managed at the endpoints; not efficient for video or voice transmissions.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain4/Eng/Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management 2.md

item.title: Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management
item.description:
BCP (Business Continuity Planning)

Protect essential business processes.
The organization is more important than the customer.
Testing is usually structural walkthroughs (document testing).
However, actual testing is the most reliable.
BIA (Business Impact Analysis)

Identify critical business processes and determine recovery times and documentation methods.
DRP (Disaster Recovery Planning)

Protect essential business processes.



Accepts risk.
Emphasizes availability.
Targets residual risk.
Treated as confidential.



Strategy for operating from a secondary site for up to 30 days.



Focuses on saving lives.
Saving people is the highest priority.


Mirror

Everything is identical, including data.
Hot

Everything is identical except data.
Warm

Some equipment is available.
Cold

Almost nothing is available.


Owned

Implemented by the organization itself.
Joint Investment

Co-invested to implement a secondary site.
Challenges include determining priority vendors during recovery.
Commercial Service

Purchase secondary site services.
Security and reliability are crucial.
Reciprocal Agreements

Implemented through mutual agreements between companies.
The least expensive option.



Should not be susceptible to the same disaster as the primary site.
Requires appropriate hardware and software compatibility.
Monitor workload.
Agree on recovery priorities.
Testing is mandatory.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain4/Eng/Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management 3.md

item.title: Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management
item.description:
This topic appeared on the exam
Emergency Response Team

Prevents loss of life and the spread of incidents.
Damage Assessment Team

Analyzes the cause and performs initial damage assessment.
Subsequently declares a disaster.
Cause/Analysis: Generates information for disaster recovery, marking the start of recovery.
Damage Management Team

Executes BCP/DRP.
Coordinates and communicates with each team: Disaster Supervisor.



Compare with government policies.
Participate or not in testing.
Evaluate the storage of secondary sites. -> Assess the adequacy and currency of the plan.
Audit IS and user departments. -> Evaluate employees' emergency response capabilities.


Fail-Safe

Stops all functions to prevent a failure.
Provides complete protection.
Fail-Soft

Stops non-essential functions to mitigate a failure.
Reduces impact of the failure.
Fail-Over

Provides service from an alternative site (or equipment) during a failure.
Overcomes failures.
Fail-Tolerant

Maintains internal operations despite a failure, with external operations continuing normally.
Tolerates failures.
Uses load balancing to provide services from two sites during normal operations, and the functioning site during a failure.



Should be conducted by IS managers and auditors, not operators.
Hardware Control: Ensures commands are properly executed.
Parity Check: Verifies accuracy when transferring from one medium to another.



Indexing: Creates an index using keys to speed up search.
Normalization Cautions: Should be applied based on the situation, not blindly.
FEP (Front-End Processor): Reduces repetitive communication tasks for the CPU.
Multiplexing: Combines multiple inputs into a single output.
item.guid: Achive/CISA/Domain4/Eng/Information System Operation, Maintenance, and Management 4.md
