item.title: Protection of Information Assets
item.description:
SSID Broadcasting Disabled: Hide the network name by disabling SSID broadcasting.
SSID Hiding and Manual Attacks: Even if the SSID is hidden, attacks can still occur.
Security Standards: WEP (128-bit or higher) < WPA < WPA3 in terms of security.
MAC Address Filtering on APs: Use MAC address filtering on Access Points (APs) to enhance security.



Data Owner: Approves and documents data access permissions and passes this documentation to the security administrator, who then determines the security classification based on the provided classification level.
Security Administrator: With the help of the data owner, regularly reviews access permissions and provides physical and technical security.
Note: For brute force attacks, it is more effective to use long passwords rather than making it difficult to guess user names.



Executives: Do not directly develop security policies but approve and support them. Development is handled by senior management.
Board of Directors: Responsible for policy oversight.
Security Administrator: Implements (transfers to operations) and regularly reviews security policies but does not develop them directly. Does not have approval authority.



Concept: An attack where data is inserted or modified on raw documents during data entry. Often performed by insiders.
Prevention: Compare raw documents with entered data and review logs and work records. For example, a bank employee manipulating terminal data to embezzle money is considered data diddling.


Causes of Security Incidents:

Disasters > External Attacks > Internal Threats > Errors/Omissions
Worst Vulnerability:

Incorrect parameter settings.
Birthday Attack:

A technique used to find different messages with the same hash.
Positive / Negative Authentication:

Positive Authentication: An authentication method where only the legitimate user can authenticate (e.g., biometrics).
Negative Authentication: Authentication methods that can be used by anyone who is not the legitimate user (e.g., passwords, tokens).



Concept: Authentication method where a single login provides access to all systems.
Benefits:
Promotes the use of stronger passwords.
Enhances user authentication.
Simplifies access management.
Auditors: Should review whether the current level of single sign-on strength is appropriate.



Must be covered in exams.

Identify relevant regulations and issues.
Identify privacy flows.
Establish solutions.



Concept: Documenting changes to software modules or functions.
Evidence: Demonstrates that security requirements are maintained even after changes.

item.title: Untitled
item.description:
Packet Filtering Router: Fast and cost-effective, but vulnerable in terms of security, difficult to manage packet logs, and lacks audit trails.
Circuit-Level Gateway: Proxy handling all applications.
Application-Level Gateway: Proxy for each application, providing strong filtering.
Bastion Host: Host with a proxy installed, but not a firewall itself.

The most robust firewall is the screened subnet firewall.



Encrypt the sender's private key using the recipient's public key for transmission.



Provides authentication, non-repudiation, and integrity.
Does not provide confidentiality
Encrypt the message with the sender's private key and send it to the recipient.
The recipient decrypts with the sender's public key.
-> In this process, the recipient must receive the sender's private key from a trusted third party.

This is where CA (Certification Authority) comes in. Thus, a trusted third party (CA) is necessary for digital signatures.



Send the hash code to the recipient in advance.
The recipient then compares the received messageâ€™s hash code with the pre-sent hash code.
If they match, integrity is verified.



Symmetric key encryption
Provides confidentiality
Used in message transmission.



This will definitely be on the exam.
Slow computation speed, used for signing/key exchange.
Provides authentication and confidentiality.
-> Does not provide integrity


Client/Server

Security management is weak.
Multiple access paths make security vulnerable.
Regular security reviews by region are necessary.
Fast speed.
Efficiency and availability can be ensured.
Mainframe

Limited access paths.
Strong security.
Integrity can be ensured.

item.title: GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 1
item.description:
Here is the translated content into English:



Governance is entirely the responsibility of the board of directors.
Governance is carried out to gain a competitive advantage for the organization.

Delegate: Information Security Officer
Responsibility: Board of Directors
INFORMATION SYSTEMS AUDITING PROCESS - 2^Information Security Governance
INFORMATION SYSTEMS AUDITING PROCESS - 2 > ^6af541






BIA (Business Impact Analysis)
Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is the process of analyzing the importance of business processes or components. It helps in disaster recovery or continuity planning by determining which processes to recover first and how to recover them.
DRP (Disaster Recovery Plan)
Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) is a plan to recover a company's IT systems and data in the event of a disaster or incident. DRP clarifies recovery procedures and responsibilities, and defines the resources and procedures for system recovery.
GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 1 > ^8760a0
RTO (Recovery Time Objective) and RPO (Recovery Point Objective)

Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is the maximum acceptable time for a system or service to be restored after a disruption. It serves as a crucial criterion for setting recovery goals.

Recovery Point Objective (RPO) is the maximum allowable period of data loss. It defines the point in time to which data must be recovered following a disruption.
CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility)
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is the concept that a company should operate ethically and sustainably, taking responsibility for its impact on society and the environment. CSR includes contributing positively to the community and engaging in environmental protection.


IT Strategy Committee
The IT Strategy Committee focuses on setting the IT strategic direction and establishing long-term goals. This committee ensures that IT strategies align with the organizationâ€™s business objectives and develops strategic plans to address future IT environment changes.

Setting IT strategic direction
Establishing long-term IT goals and plans
Ensuring alignment between IT strategy and business objectives
The IT Strategy Committee must maintain official minutes for all meetings.
IT Operations Committee
The IT Operations Committee manages and oversees the daily operations related to IT systems. This committee focuses on practical aspects such as system monitoring, budget approval, and resource allocation to enhance operational efficiency.

Monitoring and maintaining IT systems
Approving budgets and allocating resources
Managing daily IT operations
The IT Operations Committee must also maintain official minutes for all meetings.




A tool to measure the efficiency of an organization's IT.
Demonstrates the effectiveness of IT.
Used as a reporting tool for the board of directors.
A means to share organizational strategy.


The process of structurally documenting all organizational assets.
Helps guide investments and efficiently manage assets.
When should EA be used? When deciding on investment direction.


Initial: A stage with simple development and no processes.
Repeatable: Processes are consistently repeated, with processes for projects.
Defined: Processes are fully defined.
Managed: Data for processes is automatically collected, allowing for comprehensive process improvements.
Optimizing: The stage where processes can be improved qualitatively and quantitatively.


Portfolio Management

1. Strategy Development -> 2. Investment -> Execute starting with the highest priorities.
Investment Management

1. Business Case -> Understand the business case.
2. Program Planning -> Execute the program.

Quantitative Analysis Techniques

Expresses the probability of risks numerically and objectively.
Mainly used in Business Impact Analysis (BIA).
Important Aspects of Risk Management

The responsibility for risk management lies with management.
Quantitative risk management is more accurate than qualitative risk management.
Special care is needed for high-impact events, even if the probability is low.


Human Resource Management


Excessive separation of duties can be counterproductive.
Large companies find it easier to separate duties, but smaller companies may face challenges due to financial constraints.
Should be considered appropriately based on the situation.


Helps maintain operational continuity.
Employees learn additional tasks while performing their main duties.
May increase risk vulnerability.


Can prevent or detect employee fraud or misconduct.
Employees should be given mandatory leave at least once a year, and their duties should be performed by someone else during this period. For departing employees, all access rights should be immediately revoked or deleted.
Job Descriptions

Details the requirements for performing a job rather than roles and responsibilities.
Access to specific areas of work is based on job descriptions.
Performance Measurement Metrics

Critical Success Factors (CSFs)
Key Goal Indicators (KGIs) -> Measured at the beginning of the year: Setting our goals.
Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) -> Measured at the end of the year: Evaluating goal achievement.
Metrics used to assess how well objectives are achieved.


A technique for evaluating IT functions or processes through process management assessments.


A systematic method of comparing performance with peers and competitors to identify best practices.

item.title: GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 2
item.description:
Sure! Hereâ€™s the translation:

- IPF refers to all computer hardware, software, and data. - These include data stored on hard drives or USBs.
- Database management is one of the most important aspects for an auditor to consider.
Why is database management one of the most important aspects for an auditor to consider? Because the DBA has access to all data.

DBAs must enforce strict separation of duties.
All actions performed by the DBA must be approved by management.
The DBA is responsible for defining and managing backups and recovery.
By controlling updates and concurrency, the DBA ensures data integrity.


Manages the control and versions of all programs within the computer.



Quality assurance, development/design/maintenance, and operations roles cannot be held concurrently by the same individual.
DBA, quality manager, security manager, and roles in development/design/maintenance and operations cannot be held concurrently by the same individual.


Suitable vendors are selected through a benchmark RFI (Request for Information) process.
If a suitable vendor is found, an RFP (Request for Proposal) is sent to request a proposal.
Based on the proposals received from the candidate vendors, the most suitable vendor is selected.
* It's okay not to choose just one vendor.
* It's okay to select multiple vendors and choose one as the main vendor.

ITF (Integrated Facility Infrastructure)

Used during online audit system audits.
Test values are inserted into the computer in actual operation and compared with expected values.
Used during online audit system audits.
Test values are inserted into the computer in actual operation and compared with expected values.

Completeness Check
Checks whether data is missing or if there are any duplicates.
**e.g., parity check, run-to-run checks, transaction logs, badge registers
Accuracy Check

Checks to determine if the data is accurate.
* e.g., check digits, rationality checks
Controls Corresponding to Each Check â€“ This is guaranteed to appear on the exam.


BIA (Business Impact Analysis)

The most critical part of BCP (Business Continuity Plan); after performing BIA, risk response strategies are implemented.
GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 1 > ^c01be9
GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 1 > ^27954f
BCP

Includes preventive, detective, and corrective controls.
The most reliable evidence of BCP effectiveness is through testing and training. Important aspects of information systems must be included in BCP/DRP (Disaster Recovery Plan) when outsourced. Review the standards set by BIA and re-evaluate the BCP accordingly.
GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 1 > ^dfa646
DRP

Disaster Recovery Plan, which is part of BCP.
The responsibility for BCP lies with the management. Consistency is crucial for BCP.
GOVERNANCE & MANAGEMENT OF IT - 1 > ^dfa646


Even when outsourcing to the cloud, the responsibility remains with the headquarters.
The responsibility does not transfer to the outsourcer.

item.title: Important Concept
item.description:
Before an Audit:
It is crucial to input information related to "threats" (threat assessment) because audits are related to threats.
Information Classification:
Performed to prevent data loss and ensure protection.
KRI (Key Risk Indicator):
Detects unacceptable threat levels or changes in threats, not the discovery of new threats.
Auditor's Actions:
If findings are discovered, it is preferable to report them to the audit committee or the subject before documenting them. For example, the audit manager.
Information Security Framework:
Includes compliance with regulations and legal requirements. The framework is broader than policies and is crucial in developing information security policies.
Development Methodologies in IT Management and Standards:
Must include risk management techniques to meet information security requirements.
Control Summation:
Ensures "processing integrity."
Small Organizations:
When role separation is difficult, monitoring is usually the most appropriate option compared to review.
BCP (Business Continuity Planning):
Testing is more critical than having updates; a lack of testing is a more significant issue.
Escrow Agreements:
Performed to ensure continuity. Therefore, escrow agreements should always be implemented to guarantee continuity. For example, an escrow repository must always have the latest version of the code.
Certificate Lifespan:
Managed by the Certificate Authority (CA). The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) only provides a list of revoked certificates.
Checksum:
Is a "preventive" control.
Information Security Policy:
Should consider the risk management process. Although considering the information security framework is also a good approach, it may not account for specific organizational circumstances.
Balanced Scorecard (BSC):
Measures the efficiency of IT governance.
Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB):
Provides visibility and control over data in the cloud.
Program Changes:
Must be "thoroughly tested" to ensure integrity, confidentiality, and compliance with requirements.
Data Classification:
The first step in data protection.
Configuration Management System:
One of its purposes is to define and manage "software baselines."
Enterprise Risk Management (ERM):
The responsibility of the Board of Directors.
Tokenization and Masking:
Tokenization: Replaces sensitive data with randomly generated tokens, storing the tokens in the database and keeping the actual data elsewhere for confidentiality.
Masking: Obscures some or all parts of sensitive data. It maintains confidentiality while allowing users to recognize their own identification information.
SIEM (Security Information and Event Management):
Collects and consolidates various logs and events into a single source of information.
Information Security Policies:
Should consider the risk management process.
Automated Internal Controls:
Capable of reviewing large-scale data.
Help Desk:
The most critical aspect is the customer's evaluation since it is used by customers frequently.
Agile Development Methodology:
Requires rigorous release management due to rapid changes and deployments.
Auditing Projects:
When planning or selecting an audit project, it is important to consider the project's benefits and justification. Therefore, reviewing the business case of the project is crucial for audit project selection.
Asset Disposal Process:
The most important aspect is the data stored on the asset, followed by ensuring the process securely disposes of the asset.
Audit Committee:
Best suited for reporting findings and disputes due to its independence from operations.
IT Governance:
The starting point for ensuring responsibilities are met is making the information widely known across the organization.
DLP (Data Loss Prevention):
Training on information assets and security alongside DLP significantly contributes to preventing data leaks.
Portfolio Management:
Aligns projects with organizational requirements and strategy. If this alignment is lacking, projects may not meet organizational needs and remain unused.
DLP Systems:
Should detect and monitor malicious traffic.
Disk Destruction:
If a disk is to be reused and cannot be destroyed, it should be overwritten multiple times.
Incident Management Reporting:
Should be independent.
Thin Clients:
Reduce the need for management.
Most Comprehensive Information on Risk:
Provided by risk assessment.
Evidence:
Should be extracted from "copies" rather than originals.
Visitor Procedures:
For data centers or servers, the best procedure is for employees to escort the visitors.
Outsourcing Critical Processes:
Requires audit rights to prevent significant issues like fraud. Continuous monitoring is essential.
Incident Response Capabilities:
The most important aspect is documenting lessons learned to avoid repeating the same incidents.
Using Risk Assessment in Audits:
The main reason is to allocate resources efficiently to the audit area.
Disaster Situations:
For data center or server backups, ensure that backups are stored "off-site" due to potential complete destruction of the data center or server building.
Outsourcing:
The main advantage is accessing skilled personnel and services at a lower cost.
Virtual Infrastructure Risks:
Standardization of images is crucial to avoid major risks.
Checksum:
Ensures integrity, i.e., the correctness of data.

Security has two major domains:

"Offensive"

"Defensive"

In this article, I will introduce the basic areas of security.
Offensive Security
Offensive security involves the process of finding vulnerabilities in applications to infiltrate computer systems, exploit software bugs, and gain unauthorized access to applications.
In short, it means acting like a â€œhackerâ€ to stop hackers.
This concept is similar to the image we have of hackers.
Defensive Security
Defensive security differs somewhat from offensive security because it involves two main tasks.

Intrusion prevention and response tasks encompass a variety of defensive security activities. The primary tasks include:
User Cybersecurity Awareness
Asset Documentation and Management
System Updates and Patching
Preventive Security Device Configuration
Logging and Monitoring Device Setup The Blue Team is central to defensive security. The primary tasks of the Blue Team include:
Establishing policies in advance and educating employees
Preparing defenses against attacks on the system In essence, the Blue Team primarily handles defensive security. It involves establishing policies in advance, educating employees, and preparing the system to defend against attacks.


This document explains two key topics related to defensive security: SOC handling threat intelligence and DFIR (Digital Forensics and Incident Response). The SOC plays a central role in maintaining the security of an organization, detecting, analyzing, and responding to threats. The SOC uses security devices and technologies to monitor the network in real-time, identify potential threats, and address them quickly.
Threat Intelligence: The SOC uses Threat Intelligence to gather and analyze information on new threats and vulnerabilities. This intelligence is crucial for improving security policies and preparing defenses against threats.
Real-Time Monitoring: The SOC team monitors networks, systems, and applications in real-time to detect suspicious activities and investigate them promptly.
Incident Response: The SOC recognizes incidents quickly and minimizes threats through appropriate response procedures. DFIR combines Digital Forensics and Incident Response, focusing on investigating and responding to security incidents within an organization. Malware analysis plays a crucial role in this process.
Digital Forensics: Digital Forensics within DFIR involves collecting and analyzing evidence after a security incident to determine the cause and impact of the attack.
Incident Response: Incident response involves the quick handling and recovery process following a security incident. The goal is to minimize damage and take preventive measures to avoid similar incidents in the future.
Malware Analysis: Malware analysis is a significant part of DFIR, focusing on understanding the behavior and structure of malicious software to identify the attackerâ€™s intent and strategy. This helps in formulating response strategies and strengthening security systems.



Preparation: A prepared and trained team is essential to handle incidents. Ideally, various measures should be taken to prevent incidents from occurring in the first place.
Detection and Analysis: The team should have the necessary resources to detect incidents and further analyze the detected events to assess their severity.
Containment, Eradication, and Recovery: Once an incident is detected, it is crucial to stop it from spreading to other systems, eradicate the threat, and ensure the affected systems are restored. For example, if a system is infected with a virus, containment would involve preventing the virus from spreading to other systems, eradication would involve treating the virus, and recovery would ensure proper system restoration.
Post-Incident Activity: After a successful recovery, a report is generated, and lessons learned are shared to prevent similar incidents in the future. Malware refers to malicious software, including programs, documents, and files that can be stored on a disk or transmitted over a network. There are various types of malware, and the main types include the following:
Virus: A virus is a piece of code (a part of a program) that attaches itself to a program. It is designed to spread from one computer to another and can modify, overwrite, and delete files on the infected computer. The results can range from slowing down the computer to rendering it unusable.
Trojan Horse: A Trojan horse is a program that appears to perform a desirable function but actually performs malicious activities. It can create a backdoor in the system, allowing unauthorized access.
Worm: Unlike viruses, worms do not require a host program and can spread autonomously. They often exploit vulnerabilities in operating systems or applications to replicate and spread across networks.
Ransomware: Ransomware is a type of malware that encrypts the victimâ€™s files and demands a ransom for the decryption key. It can cause significant damage to organizations and individuals.

â€œPasted image 20240812103222.pngâ€ could not be found.
2. Security Principles
Here is the English translation of your text with the specified formatting:
"A penetration test is an authorized audit of the security and defenses of a computer system, which the system owner has agreed to. In this sense, it has the legitimacy of penetration, but it must not exceed the agreed-upon scope.
Exceeding this scope would turn the test into hacking.

ROE is a document created at the early stages of a penetration testing contract. Penetration testing can have various objectives and goals within its scope. Therefore, penetration tests are not all the same, and there is no one-size-fits-all approach to how penetration testers should proceed. The steps performed by a penetration tester during an engagement are referred to as the methodology. A practical methodology involves actions taken in a smart way that are relevant to the current situation. Each situation may require a different methodology. For example, the methodology used to test the security of a web application may not be practical when testing the security of a network, as these are different domains. OSSTMM: The OSSTMM provides a detailed framework for testing strategies for systems, software, applications, communications, and the human aspect of cybersecurity. This methodology mainly focuses on how these systems and applications communicate, so it includes methodologies for:
Communications (telephone, VoIP, etc.)
Wired networks
Wireless communications

item.title: Security Principles
item.description:
â€œPasted image 20240812105418.pngâ€ could not be found.

Principles of information security to protect data and safeguard systems from abuse. The model of confidentiality, integrity, and availability (CIA) consists of these three principles and has become an industry standard today. This model helps in making decisions about the value of the data and what is needed in a business. Confidentiality is about protecting data from unauthorized access and misuse. Organizations always store some form of sensitive data within their systems. Providing confidentiality is about protecting this data from unintended access by anyone other than the authorized individuals. Integrity ensures that data remains unaltered except for authorized changes. Data can be changed due to careless handling, system errors, or unauthorized access. In security principles, integrity is maintained if information remains unchanged during storage, transmission, and usage, ensuring unauthorized individuals cannot alter the data (e.g., data breaches). To be useful, data must always be accessible and available to users. Availability is an essential element. It is important to manage and correctly define various levels of access to information technology systems that individuals need. The level of access granted to individuals is determined by two basic factors:
The role/function of the individual within the organization
The sensitivity of the information stored in the system Two key concepts used in assigning and managing user access rights are PIM (Privileged Identity Management) and PAM (Privileged Access Management). Initially, these two concepts may seem similar. However, they are different. PIM is used to translate user roles within an organization into access roles within the system. In contrast, PAM primarily deals with managing the privileges associated with system access. A critical aspect of access and privilege control is the principle of least privilege. In simple terms, users should be given only the minimum privileges necessary to perform their duties. PAM integrates more than just access assignment. It also includes security policy enforcement such as password management, policy auditing, and reducing the attack surface of systems. Before discussing security models in detail, let's consider the three elements of CIA: confidentiality, integrity, and availability. According to security models, any system or technology that stores information is referred to as an information system, and this is how systems and devices are referenced in this context. Let's look at some popular and effective security models used to achieve the three elements of CIA. The Bell-La Padula Model is used to achieve confidentiality. This model assumes a hierarchical structure within an organization where everyone's responsibilities/roles are well defined. This model operates by granting access to data (referred to as objects) based on a "write-up, read-down" rule. It ensures that individuals can access only the data they need. The Biba Model is similar to the Bell-La Padula Model but focuses on integrity rather than confidentiality in CIA. This model applies rules summarized as "write-up, read-down." This means that a subject can write to information at its own level or lower but can only read data at its level or higher. The Biba Model is used in situations or organizations where integrity is more critical than confidentiality. For example, in software development, developers may need access only to the code necessary for their tasks and not to other critical information. Threat modeling is the process of reviewing, improving, and testing security protocols in an organization's IT infrastructure and services. An important step in the threat modeling process is identifying potential threats and vulnerabilities that a system or application may face. The threat modeling process is similar to risk assessments performed in the workplace for employees and customers, following similar principles.
Preparation
Identification
Mitigation
Review To assist, frameworks such as STRIDE (Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, and Elevation of Privilege) and PASTA (Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis) are available. Below, we will discuss STRIDE in detail. STRIDE, developed by two Microsoft security researchers in 1999, remains influential today. STRIDE includes six key principles. Security breaches are referred to as incidents. Despite stringent threat models and secure system designs, incidents do occur. The actions taken to address and remediate threats are known as Incident Response (IR) and are a crucial part of a career in cybersecurity. Incident response processes are often covered in security certifications such as those offered by CISA. Incidents are classified using urgency and impact ratings. Urgency is determined by the type of attack faced, the location of the affected system, and the impact on business operations. Incidents are responded to by Computer Security Incident Response Teams (CSIRTs) that are pre-organized with technical knowledge of the current incident. To successfully resolve an incident, the following six steps of incident response are often listed in the table below.

item.title: Ubuntu Docker Capacity Management(Eng)
item.description:
We encountered a difficult error while using Docker at work. The 4TB allocated to Ubuntu was insufficient, so the existing service was down. At first, we thought we could deal with it by deleting files or logs that were taking up a lot of space, but that wasn't the fundamental problem.
Since I spent a lot of time on this issue, I decided to share my solution for developers like me, especially those who develop and maintain Docker servers like me.


When using Docker, you may see that disk usage suddenly increases. Then, you enter the Docker container and check the capacity of the db or the files in the container, but you cannot find the cause.
Why is that?
The reason is simple.
This is because containers share disk volumes, and garbage data values â€‹â€‹from the server accumulate on those disk volumes for a long time.
It is mainly accumulated in the server container that handles logic, but if left for a long time, it will also accumulate in other auxiliary containers such as databases.

I also had a ton of garbage accumulated in mariaDB, nginx, Grafana, phpadmin, etc.
To put it simply, the cause is that the volumes of deleted or unused images or containers have piled up, creating this situation.
What should be done in this situation?
For times like this, Docker has prepared commands.
It is docker system prune .
First, let me explain the method.
docker ps -a ë³µì‚¬
First, check the currently running containers with the above command and select containers with large capacity.
(In fact, if the server's capacity is insufficient, all containers are in trouble.)
Then the
docker stop <container_id> --------------------------------- All containers are stopped docker stop all ë³µì‚¬
Stop the container with the above command.
Then delete the container with the command below.
docker rm <container_id> ---------------------------------- Delete all containers docker rm $(docker ps -a -q) ë³µì‚¬
This part will only mention the commands. (Usually it is not necessary. Run it when there is no change in capacity -> But be careful to delete only unused images.)
Check all existing images:
docker images ë³µì‚¬
Delete a specific image:
docker rmi $(docker images -q) ë³µì‚¬
Next, it's time to delete any unused data from Docker.
Delete unused volumes:
docker volume prune ë³µì‚¬
Delete all unused containers, images, volumes, and networks:
docker system prune -a ë³µì‚¬
Re-creating and running containers to fulfill the above assumptions would provide a dramatic increase in capacity.
I got 3 terabytes.
Normally, you can just use the docker volume prune command to delete the above volume, but I had to deal with capacity issues again in less than 3 months when I did that the first time I tried.
So docker system prune -a to delete unused images, volumes, containers, networks, etc.
was used.
Of course, I'm not saying you should always use that command, because you never know what problems might arise.
I hope that you won't have any problems with capacity when using Docker on Ubuntu using this method. It was a meaningful event to learn again that volume management is important.

item.title: Zombie Process Killing
item.description:
It was detected that the Linux server running at the company had a large number of zombie processes.
When I first heard the term "zombie process," I wondered if it was a hacking issue, but I soon realized that it was simply a process that hadn't released its assigned resources.
Zombie Process Explanation
Zombie Process

ps -ef | grep defunct | grep -v grep ë³µì‚¬
First, use the above command to find the zombie processes and identify the PIDs of the zombie process and its parent process.
kill -9 [Parent Process PID] ë³µì‚¬
Next, kill the parent process using the command above.
After that,
C:\cmd> top ë³µì‚¬
Use a command like the one above to verify that no zombie processes remain.

item.title: Reasons why a database might not be attachable using an .mdf file
item.description:
To restore a database from a backup, you need to attach the .mdf file in MSSQL.
However, even though the backup is intact and there are no apparent issues in SSMS (SQL Server Management Studio), the .mdf file fails to attach. What situation might we suspect? Ah, it seems that MSSQL doesn't have sufficient permissions to access the .mdf file!
Answer
That's right. The issue was resolved by going into the properties of the .mdf file and ensuring that all users or MSSQL had execute and read-write permissions enabled.

I wandered around for 10 minutes without knowing this.
Anyway, this method allows you to execute the .mdf file. ** However, you must also apply the same settings to the log file; otherwise, an error will occur.
item.guid: Project/ì„œë²„ ê´€ë¦¬/MSSQL/Eng/Reasons why a database might not be attachable using an .mdf file.md

item.title: 1st Hacking Response
item.description:
While developing servers at the company, I heard news that an external server had been hacked. Since it was just a CMS server managing specific contents externally, it wasn't a massive issue, but quick recovery was essential for content management. As someone with a background in security and ongoing study, I started addressing the problem.

Having recently obtained CISA Associate, I will attempt to write this according to the incident response process.
However, I had not studied CISA itself at that time, so there may be discrepancies with the process.



Collect host computer information (briefly conducted as information was already available)
Login to server/DB host computers
Check server and DB status
Search for malicious files and processes
Collecting Host Computer Information

Detailed information not provided, but collected operating system information, etc.
Login to Server/DB Host Computers
Server login failed

It was found that the admin account's password had been changed by the hacker.
However, the guest account password remained intact. ** Since guest account login was possible, I decided to use it to exploit the vulnerability known as privilege escalation.
Privilege escalation occurs when a user or process gains more privileges than intended. In this case, access control failed, allowing me to utilize this vulnerability. I should note that these actions were taken to recover the server and were agreed upon by the company.
1. Login with the guest account 2. Run CMD as administrator CMD:\> net user Administrator new_password 3. Login with the admin account ë³µì‚¬
This process was successful as planned.
Success
It was confirmed that I successfully accessed the server computer. Permissions were not configured as I had expected, but this only applied to the server computer and not the DB computer.
DB login failed
It was found that even the guest account for the DB had been changed. In this case, I needed to find another method instead of the previous approach. I needed to prepare the following:
Preparation: Windows USB same version as the host computer.
Step 1: Create Windows Server 2012 installation media on an accessible computer. Step 2: Insert it into the locked Windows Server 2012 computer and repeatedly press the boot key to enter BIOS. Set the installation disk as the first boot option, then press **F10** to save and exit. Step 3: Enter language and other basic settings, then click **Next**. Step 4: Click **Computer Recovery** in the bottom left corner. Step 5: Click **Troubleshoot** in the **Choose an option** window. Step 6: Click **Command Prompt** in the **Advanced options** window. Step 7: Enter the following commands, pressing **Enter** at the end of each line. 1. D: 2. CD Windows\system32 3. Ren utilman.exe utilman.exe.bak 4. Ren cmd.exe utilman.exe 5. WPEUtil reboot The computer will automatically restart. *** However, Step 7 did not work for me because CMD itself stated that I did not have permission to change the password. In that case, try replacing cmd.exe with netplwiz.exe in the command. Alternatively, executing that process from CMD can easily change the password. ë³µì‚¬
Successful Access
I was able to access through this method.


Successfully identified the current malicious processes and locations of malicious files.
Both the server and DB were attacked, and the DB contained a dormant SQL-related virus.
Threat Control

Isolated the server/DB environment under threat, including malicious code and processes.
Also ensured continuity by performing backups and continuity assurance tasks.
Threat Removal

Deleted all malicious code and processes.
Blocked access to problematic paths to prevent further breaches.
Recovery and Restoration

As no data was lost or damaged, only the recovery of the server and DB hosts was conducted.
Redeployed any processes that were damaged in the process.
Feedback and Clarification

Upon reviewing the hacking incident, it was determined that it occurred due to external access to servers and DB computers connected to the internal network.
While external access is necessary for user access, leaving it as it was posed a significant risk.
Therefore, I proposed enhancing server confidentiality through VPN access, but the company rejected this and opted to restrict access to specific IP addresses for the server and its web applications.
This incident was resolved for now, but issues still remained. Finding a brute-force script text file left by the hacking script suggested potential server breach via brute force or vulnerabilities in web applications. From this point, I focused more on studying security to effectively respond to such incidents.
item.guid: Project/í•´í‚¹ ë° ë³´ì•ˆ ëŒ€ì‘/í•´í‚¹ ëŒ€ì‘/Eng/1st Hacking Response.md

í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, ê²ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ ê³„ì •ì˜ ë¹„ë°€ë²ˆí˜¸ëŠ” ìœ ì§€ë˜ê³  ìˆì—ˆë‹¤.
** ê²ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ ê³„ì • ë¡œê·¸ì¸ì€ ê°€ëŠ¥í•˜ë‹ˆ ì´ë¥¼ í†µí•˜ì—¬ ë³´ì•ˆ ì·¨ì•½ì  ì¤‘ í•˜ë‚˜ì¸ ê¶Œí•œ ì—ìŠ¤ì»¬ë ˆì´ì…˜ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ê¸°ë¡œ í–ˆë‹¤.

ë¯¸ë¦¬ ë§í•´ë‘ì§€ë§Œ, ì„œë²„ ë³µêµ¬ ìœ„í•´ì„œ ìˆ˜í–‰í•œ ê²ƒì´ê¸°ì— íšŒì‚¬ì— í•©ì˜ê°€ ëœ ì‚¬í•­ì´ë‹¤.
1. ê²ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ ê³„ì •ìœ¼ë¡œ ì ‘ì† 2. ê´€ë¦¬ì ê¶Œí•œìœ¼ë¡œ CMD ì‹¤í–‰ CMD:\> net user Administrator ì›í•˜ëŠ” ë¹„ë°€ë²ˆí˜¸ 3. ì–´ë“œë¯¼ ê³„ì •ìœ¼ë¡œ ì ‘ì† ë³µì‚¬
ì´ ê³¼ì •ì„ ìˆ˜í–‰í•˜ì˜€ë‹¤. ì›ë¦¬ëŠ” ê°„ë‹¨í•˜ë‹¤.

item.title: Active Directory?
item.description:
Active Directory centralizes the management of common components of a computer network in a single repository called Active Directory (AD). To explain it more simply, you can think of it as a database that stores information about company employees' account information (ID, password), computer information, and policies you want to enforce (ex: password is 9 or more characters long). I'm familiar with it because I manage a company server, but it can be a bit confusing when you first hear it. The server running this Active Directory is called a domain controller (DC).
Advantages
Centralized identity management: Easily control and control all users on your network.
Security policy management: Configure security policies directly in Active Directory and apply them to users and computers across the network as needed.
There is convenience in being able to impose policies on the network and terminals within the network at will. It is very cumbersome to change settings on each computer, so this method is very convenient.
Configuration
At the heart of every Windows domain is Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS). This service acts as a catalog that holds information about all "objects" that exist on the network. Objects include users, groups, printers, shares, etc.

Users can be represented by two types of objects:

Person: A user generally refers to a person within an organization who accesses the network, such as an employee (company employee).


Services: You can define services to use for services such as IIS or MSSQL. In this case, the user only has the permissions necessary to run the specific service.



A machine is for any computer that joins an AD domain. Machines are considered security principals and are assigned accounts just like regular users. This account has limited permissions within the domain.
The computer account itself is a local administrator on the computer to which it is assigned and is usually accessible to anyone other than the computer itself, but can be logged in with a password.
Caution!: Your computer account password is automatically rotated and usually consists of 120 random characters.


It is literally a user group. You can easily manage users by adding them to groups. The user automatically inherits all privileges attached to the group. Security groups are also considered security principals and therefore have permissions to network resources.
You can sleep.
Caution!) A group can have both users and computers as members. Other groups may also be included if necessary.
Below is an example of a group.
Domain Group Description

Domain Administrator: Users in this group have administrative rights to the entire domain. By default, they can manage all computers in the domain, including DCs.
Server Administrator: Users in this group can administer domain controllers. Management group membership cannot be changed.
Backup Operator: Users in this group can access all files, ignoring permissions. Used to perform data backups on your computer.
Account Administrator: Users in this group can create or modify other accounts in the domain.
Domain Users: Includes all existing user accounts in the domain.
Domain Computers: Includes all existing computers in the domain.
Domain Controller: Includes all existing DCs in the domain.

A container object that allows you to categorize users and systems. It is primarily used to define sets of users with similar policy requirements. For example, employees in the sales department are likely to have a different set of policies in place than employees in the development department. And remember that a user can only belong to one OU at a time.
Automatically created organizational units

Embedded: Contains default groups that can be used on any Windows host.
Computer: All computers connected to the network are placed here by default. You can move it if necessary.
Domain Controller: The default OU that contains the DCs in the network.
User: Default users and groups that apply to the domain-wide context.
Managed Service Account: Holds the account used by services in the Windows domain.
Added) Different policies can be deployed individually for each OU via Group Policy Objects (GPOs). GPOs can contain policies targeting users or computers, allowing you to set criteria for specific computers and identities.

Difference between security group and organizational unit
Organizational unit: Mainly used to apply policies
Security Group: Used to grant permissions to resources

This part is similar for both users and machines. The idea is to separate devices and users based on their purpose. Just as it is good to separate intranet computers, development team personal computers, etc. from each other.

If you use Windows Domian, all credentials are stored on the domain controller. The user uses these credentials to authenticate to the service, and the service asks the domain controller to confirm the authentication is correct.
Two protocols can be used for authentication: These are protocols that I occasionally encountered while studying hacking.
Kerberos: Used in newer versions of Windows. This is the default protocol for recent domains.
NetNTLM: A legacy authentication protocol maintained for compatibility.
Although I've heard that NetNTLM is often deprecated, both protocols live on most networks.

As your company grows, your network also grows. It's a natural result. As the number of services increases and the information to be managed increases, the size of the network also increases. We know how it grows. Whether it's an algorithm or a flow chart, it's a structure you'll definitely see.
you're right. It is a tree structure.

Active Directory supports multiple domain integration, allowing you to partition your network into independently manageable units. By making them share the same namespace, you can combine the domains in a tree form.
If your domain is split into two subdomains for UK and US branches, you can build a tree with a root domain and two subdomains called thm.local and thm.local, each with their own AD, computers, and users.
This partitioned structure gives you more control over who can access what in your domain. UK IT staff will have their own DC that manages only UK resources. For example, UK users cannot manage US users. In this way, the domain administrator at each branch has full control of its DCs, but not the DCs of other branch offices. You can also configure policies independently for each domain in the tree.
However, it is also common for companies with different namespaces to merge. What should I do in times like this? you're right. Just as the two Chinese characters for tree and neck come together to form the Chinese character for bush and forest,
the domain can also be a forest. Integrating multiple trees with different namespaces into the same network is called a forest.
By organizing multiple domains into trees and forests, you can have a nicely compartmentalized network in terms of management and resources. However, at some point, THM UK's users may need to access shared files on one of MHT ASIA's servers. To achieve this, domains arranged in
trees and forests are joined by trust relationships.
Simply put, a trust relationship between domains allows you to grant users from another domain access to resources in another domain. This relationship can be unidirectional or bidirectional.
This is how I looked into Active Directory. Normally, when managing a server, I only knew the concepts and moved on, but when I reflected on my knowledge properly, my perspective opened up more broadly. I need to gain more security and network knowledge in the future.

item.title: Zombie Process
item.description:
A zombie process refers to a defunct process that has terminated and released all its resources but still remains in the system process table. It can be seen as a process that has ended its execution but has not yet been removed from the system.
Causes
Typically, a process terminates by calling the exit() system function, requesting the operating system to delete it. When the process ends, the resources it was using are reclaimed by the operating system.
However, at this time, the process remains in the system process table where its exit status is stored. This process remains until its parent process calls the wait() system function.
In other words, a zombie process is a process that has terminated but remains in the system process table because its parent process has not yet called the wait() system function.

All processes become zombie processes upon termination, but they remain in this state for a very short time. Once the parent process calls the wait() system function, the data and process identifier (PID) of the zombie process are returned to the operating system from the system process table.
Therefore, the fact that a process remains as a zombie process indicates that the parent process has not called the wait() system function, leaving the already terminated process lingering in the system process table.

Are Zombie Processes Dangerous?
A zombie process is a terminated process that has already returned its resources, so it does not consume system resources.
However, a zombie process retains the process identifier (PID) it was assigned.
The Linux operating system generally has a limited number of 32,768 PIDs (2^15). If zombie processes accumulate rapidly, they can occupy a significant portion of the available PIDs, potentially hindering the execution of other normal processes.
(A small number of zombie processes are a bug, but they do not pose a significant issue to the system.) ** In practice, there weren't major errors while managing the server, but there was a noticeable impact on CPU usage.
Finding Zombie Processes
$ ps -ef | grep defunct | grep -v grep $ ps aux | egrep "Z|defunct" ë³µì‚¬
Zombie processes can be identified using the two commands above.
top -b -n 1 | grep zombie ë³µì‚¬
You can also use the top command to see the current state of processes and quickly identify how many zombies are present.
Killing Zombie Processes
Since a zombie process has already completed the resource return and termination process, the kill command will not work on it. Therefore, you must use another method to eliminate it.
Another method is to send a SIGCHLD signal to the parent process to notify it that the child process has terminated, prompting the removal of the zombie process from the system process table. However, the fact that a zombie process has appeared indicates that this mechanism did not function when the child process ended, so this method may not work either.
(SIGCHLD: A POSIX signal that informs the parent process when a child process has terminated.)
For this reason, the most certain way to kill a zombie process is to terminate the parent process itself.
However, terminating the parent process will also end all of its child processes, so it is important to consider the side effects.
